text:
Apparence : Noire, beau col brun fonc√©, carbonatation moyenne entretenant un col qui s¬íestompe laissant une l√©g√®re dentelle. 
Nez : Chocolat noir, torr√©faction, r√©glisse noire, m√©lasse, vanille en arri√®re-plan et pr√©sence de notes de bois br√ªl√©. 
Go√ªt : Chocolat noir, belle pr√©sence d¬íesters d¬íalcool, r√©glisse noire moins pr√©sente qu¬íau nez, premi√®re gorg√©e pr√©sentant une amertume herbac√©e en finale qui s¬í√©teint au fil des gorg√©es. √âquilibre des saveurs et ar√¥mes au final. 
Sensation : Bonne densit√©, effervescence douce, bonne longueur en bouche. 
Bref : Agr√©ablement surpris par celle-ci. Difficile d¬í√™tre surpris par une bi√®re jouissant d¬íune telle renomm√©e me direz-vous, mais la version m¬íavait laiss√© sur une impression d¬íamertume br√ªl√©e trop prononc√©e en finale, venant quelque peu g√¢cher le reste. M√™me chose pour la Black Butte XVIII. Celle-ci m¬ía paru plus √©quilibr√©e et, pour moi, plus int√©ressante. Juste la bonne quantit√© de sucre pour ne pas tomber dans la d√©cadence.

Bottle 2015 Reserve. Pours a very dark reddy coke colour with a tan head. Big dark fruit, treacle, with prunes, rum, char... medium to full body, light to medium carb. Lots of rum raisin, vanilla, prune, toffee, woody... its a bit thin, but it's tasty. Not all that though. Just a good impy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 A: Pitch black with a nice one finger brown head N: Ash, bourbon, oak, vanilla, coffee, liqourice root T: Ash, hint of plum, liqourice(!), liqourice root, oak, coffee, hint of berries(?) O: Quite liqourice root forward and very nice balanced smokiness! Nice!

On tap to snifter. Pours jet black with rapidly receding tan head. Big aroma of coffee with subtle vanilla and some chocolate. Taste follows. Heavy coffee with bitter cocoa. A little boozy warming aftertaste. Very good imperial stout.

It sounds like a slight, or maybe a back-handed compliment, to say that this beer is not different from a whole bunch of other barrel aged imperial stouts. But it¬ís a style that I love when it is done well, and it¬ís done well here. This beer pours black with a little bit of tan head. There is heavy licorice on the aroma, along with the usual oak/vanilla barrel notes and an herbal quality. The flavor adds some bitter malt/baker¬ís chocolate stuff to that mix, and it all goes down very smoothly. There is nothing about this that I don¬ít like.

Bottle from Kensington wine market in Calgary. Pours midnight black with a creamy brown head with slightly reddish hues. Nose is sweet, vanilla, toffee, fudge, barrel, whiskey, coffee, roast. Tastes sweet, bitter, brown sugar, hot abv bite. This is a dynamite brew, can¬ít believe I gave a bottle away.

It took me a long time to get to this one, but it was worth the wait! Huge complex profile and rich depth of flavor. It isn¬ít just coffee or chocolate, there¬ís some other sticky sweet notes here, and just enough bitterness to balance it all out. The mouthfeel is thick enough to coat your tongue. It¬ís amazing.

Piwo totalnie w stylu Deschutes - na≈Çadowane s≈Çodami -melasa, toffi, karmel, goryczkowe z silnym akcentem beczki dƒôbowej, gdzie≈õ tam w tle lekkie winno-taniczne klimaty. Bourbonu nie jest tutaj za wiele - zaledwie lekka wanilia. Cia≈Ço pe≈Çne, ulepkowate, piwo s≈Çodowo-goryczkowe. Piwo na pewno znajdzie swoich wielbicieli. Dla mnie 4.1.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2017 Bouteille, r√©serve 2016. Merci √† Alex! Robe pratiquement noire et surmont√©e d¬íun l√©ger col de mousse brun√¢tre et rocailleuse. Ar√¥mes de malt grill√©, datte s√©ch√©e, feuille de laurier, caramel, √©pices, caf√©, chocolat. En bouche, malt grill√©, chocolat noir, datte br√ªl√©e, vanille et feuille morte. Saveurs moins prononc√©es de caf√©, √©pices s√©ch√©es, raisins blancs, bois cendr√©. Texture huileuse et corps moyen.

Only at the very bottom of a tulip glass to you discern light in an almost red shade. Head is mocha with a matching set of lace. Nose is layered; espresso, hint cherries, bubbling brown sugar, and a touch of wood. Bittersweet is an understatement. Middle is velvety dark chocolate, understated bourbon flourishes, and a kiss of black liquorice. Finish is all of the above wrapped together for a long lasting contemplation. Try it.

On tap at APEX (Portland). Black color with a brown head. Dark chocolate alcohol aroma. Dark chocolate roasted malt bitter flavor. Heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pitch black color with creamy, mocha head. Aroma has some acidic malt note and slightly tart fruity notes. Taste starts bitter and fruity up-front, continues with roasted malts and coffee bitterness on the finish. Full bodied, really smooth on the palate. Overall it¬ís a really complex stout, well balanced and easy drinking for its ABV.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2017 Bottle at home, 2016 vintage. Pitch black pour with a fine-grained espresso head. Just perfect-looking. Compared to the previous vintage, it has a ton more roast in it, espresso, smoke, dark malts, licorice, dark chocolate and much more subtle but again, very well integrated barrel notes - light oak, light red wine, a bit of vanilla and bourbon. Medium to high roasty bitterness, light sweetness, full body, thick but not cloy. So much roast in this beer, making it quite distinct from other big US stouts. Loving it! Not sure if the extra roast is just the freshness or if this batch is slightly different. I might need to get a bottle or two and cellar it for a while.

Bottle shared at a tasting, 2015 vintage. Pitch black pour with a fine-grained datk tan head that is slow to rise to the surface. Notes of coffee, chocolate, wine barrel, molasses, licorice, bourbon barrel, very subtle oak barrel sourness, dark cherry bitterness, a bit of rye. Very complex, well-balanced and rich in flavour.
Draft at Casual Pint. Pour was black, tan head. Aroma was sweet bourbon, coffee, smoke, wood. Taste was bittersweet, dark chocolate, bourbon, oak, roasted malt.

Pours black into tulip, frothy tan head. Remarkably hearty nose...Wood, smoke, dark chocolate, like an old candy store on a warm afternoon...A candy store that also roasts coffee. A bit more bourbon on the tongue, a pile of roasted wood, caramel, molasses, chicory, vanilla, a trace of cherry or currant. Fudge... Like the main course, dessert and after dinner drink at a nice steak house all rolled into one.  it¬ís all here. Long lingering finish that lasts until the next sip. Velvety smooth despite the richness and abv. Feels aged though it¬ís not. Outstanding and I¬íll drink the other one I bought in a few years.

650 ml bottle from Canada Craft Club. Pours a nearly black colour with moderate-sized mocha-coloured head. Aroma is molasses, roast, cherry, dark chocolate and oak. Flavour is big and rich with lots of molasses and roast, dark cherry, anise, bourbon and oak. Fine carbonation. Impressive.

2009 Reserve: poured completely opaque dark, almost motor oil black with rich brown head. A robust smell and taste of bourbon, vanilla and wood grilled meat. One of the most complex Russian imperials I¬íve had.

Draught at Beer Hall SF. Black color, brown head. Bitter taste with roasted malts, espresso, hops, nuts, wood and dark fruits. Really dry body. Bitter finish with roasted malts, espresso, nuts, dark fruits, wood and a bit of earthy notes. Excellent imperial stout, a bit too dry for my taste though.
bomber pours black with thick brown head aroma was chocolate and a little booze taste was at first bitter cherry followed by chocolate and finished with a warming alcohol

Z okazji narodzin mojego drugiego syna Alana musia≈Çem wyciƒÖgnƒÖƒá z le≈ºakowni jakie≈õ dobre piwo. Wyb√≥r pad≈Ç na The Abyss 2015. Twoje zdrowie Alanku! üí•üç∫üéÇ  
 Potƒô≈ºny RIS uwarzony z dodatkiem melasy z trzciny cukrowej, lukrecji, kory drzewa wi≈õniowego i wanilii.
21% trunku le≈ºakowana by≈Ça w dƒôbowych beczkach po Bourbonie, 8% w czystych dƒôbowych beczkach i 21% w dƒôbowych beczkach po winie.  
 Wersja:  The Abyss 2015 Reserve  
 Alkohol:  12,2% obj. 
 Data wa≈ºno≈õci:  12.08.2016 
 Kolor:  Piekielnie czarny, smolisty jak czelu≈õcie piek≈Ça. 
 Piana:  Ciemnobe≈ºowa, gƒôsta i zwarta jak na azocie.
Szereg drobniutkich pƒôcherzyk√≥w powietrza r√≥wniutko przylegajƒÖcych do siebie.
Piana przez wiele minut utrzymuje siƒô na powierzchni.
Po przechyleniu TeKu pozostawia barwne, r√≥≈ºnokszta≈Çtne wstƒôgi.
W og√≥le nie chce odkleiƒá siƒô od g√≥rnej warstwy trunku. 
 Zapach:  Pierwsze nuty zapachowe to przeogromna, masywna bourbonowa bomba.
Drewno, potƒô≈ºna wanilia, kokos i mn√≥stwo karmelu.
W tle majaczy odrobina czerwonego wina.
Dalej pralinki czekoladowe, lukrecja, masa wysokiej jako≈õci kawy, wi≈õnie w czekoladzie, ≈õliwki i odrobina toffi.
Po ogrzaniu ujawnia siƒô lekki sosik sojowy.
A≈º dech zapiera w piersiach od g≈Çƒôbi dozna≈Ñ aromatycznych. 
Bezapelacyjnie 10/10! 
 Smak:  Gigantyczna s≈Çodycz beczkowa. Tony wanilii, kokosu, dƒôbowego drewna.
W kolejnym ≈Çyku cukier trzcinowy, kogel-mogel, likier Advocat, kawa Latte polana gƒôstym syropem karmelowym.
Podobnie jak w aromacie odrobina czerwonych winogron i beczki po czerwonym winie.
Jest tak≈ºe sporo karmelu, bary≈Çek czekoladowych wype≈Çnionych likierem, lody waniliowe, ciasto czekoladowe.
Nieko≈ÑczƒÖca siƒô euforia smakowa.
Tekstura Abyssa jest jedwabista, kremowa, a jednocze≈õnie oleista i gƒôsta jak budy≈Ñ.
Alkohol rozgrzewa od ≈õrodka i podkre≈õla szlachetne w≈Ça≈õciwo≈õci trunku.
Goryczka jest umiarkowana, s≈Çodki wyklejajƒÖcy usta finisz.
Beczka zapewni≈Ça niesamowite doznania.
Bourbon i dƒôbina a≈º ociekajƒÖ po ≈õciankach szk≈Ça.
Abyss to p≈Çynny nektar Bog√≥w.
Doznanie jakiego siƒô nigdy nie zapomina. 
Sztos sztos√≥w! 
 Wysycenie:  Niskie. 
 Podsumowanie:  

Wybitne piwo! Warte ka≈ºdego wydanego $.
Piwo warto przele≈ºakowaƒá. Je≈õli kto≈õ ma wersje 2016, obawiam siƒô, ≈ºe alkohol mo≈ºe byƒá wyra≈∫ny. 

The Abyss to jedno z najlepszych piw le≈ºakowanych w beczce po bourbonie jakie pi≈Çem. 
Beczka daje gigantyczne akcenty wanilii, kokosu, mokrego dƒôbowego drewna.
Ca≈Ço≈õƒá uzupe≈Çnia intensywna s≈Çodycz cukru trzcinowego, karmelu, toffi, kawy Latte z syropem karmelowym, likieru Advocat oraz najlepszych belgijskich pralinek.
DrugƒÖ stronƒô trunku stanowiƒÖ nuty beczki po winie oraz wi≈õni w czekoladzie.
Piwo ma wyborne, jedwabistƒÖ cia≈Ço i oleistƒÖ teksturƒô.
Alkohol jest widoczny, rozgrzewa od ≈õrodka, ale nie dominuje.
Piwo robi piorunujƒÖce wra≈ºenie.
Majstersztyk!

This is a great beer, but it is also one of the strangest beers I¬íve ever had. It kinda smells like bacon/salami, and it does have a taste of cured meat on the finish until it warms further. Which, this might sound bad, but it¬ís actually super cool and really good.

2014 vintage. Pitch pour with mild, wet sand head. Nose is very dense, off the bat is full of dried berries, and a sleek vanilla oak. Deep into the nose, you may find a desireable, peppery-pine herbaceousness, similar to thyme or eucalyptus (but not menthol-like), tons of fresh-split wood. Gentle molasses, and there¬ís almost a quality of port-barrels in it (must be the licorice). This nose conjures up a lot of imagery. Run-down barn among tall leaning reeds. I digress...

Flavor is just as powerful. You get a huge creamy texture, starting off with dried berries and extremely unique herbaceous notes, folding over into a quality of easygoing cocoa and dark brown sugar with some bitterness. Sticky linger, very dense beer. 

I was gifted this beer from a co-worker after swearing to stop rating beers. But this one was so unique that I had to write about it. This beer has been one of the most unique ones I¬íve had in a long while.

(Deschutes The Abyss) Bottle 650ml at home, tasted side to side with Abyss Cognac and Abyss Rye Whiskey. ABV 11%
 Black coloured body, half a finger of dark brown head with very good retention.
Aroma of roasted malts, molasses, chocolate, alcohol.
Taste also of roasted malts, alcohol, chocolate, ash, coal, wood, tanines, light vanilla, light bourbon too and a fruity sourness for a moment.
Thick body with soft carbonation.
Fantastic.

Now there is complex and there is complex. Abyss is complex. A difficult find, well worth the wait. The label says bottled on 12/8/16. I pour into my best tulip glass and see a jet black body topped by a gorgeous chocolate-brown head that slowly dissipates.The scent is cocoa and I swear, mahogany wood if it smells. Interpret as you like. Follow on with a sip and I taste dark chocolate, caramel, dark red cherries and a liquor overtone. A nice bitter finish that sticks. Imperial stouts are a favorite, others have been great. This one is a little bit better. One to drink now and one to save. It has been a good day.

Very nice balance, smooth all the way, subtle roasted malts, light licorice, some not too impressive bourbon BA impact. Moderate sweetness with moderate bitterness, nice balance, enjoyable brew, but didnt met expectations.
C. Pours a black color with dark brown head. Full flavor, but harsh finish.
2016. The cherry (bark) really came through for me but worked well with the sweetness from the licorice and vanilla character. Complex and keeps it interesting as it warms.

2014 Reserve: Pours a dark black with a nice thick khaki head.The aroma is amazing with this beer. There is dark chocolate brownies, some vanilla, oak, some aroma of alcohol is present, cherries, red licorice, and dark fruits. The flavor is dark cherries, chocolate, and even some light roasted coffee notes are being picked up. There is some oak flavor notes in there as well. This beer has really mellowed out after cellaring for three years.
On tap at Mikkeller Bar. Chocolate and vanilla aroma. Hugely bitter flavour. Very good.

22 oz bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Molasses, cocoa, and coffee aroma, touches of vanilla, smoke, anise, bourbon. Dark cocoa and molasses flavor, coffee, anise. Touches of oak and bourbon. Thick and syrupy. A really good one.
Pours a dark black color with a rolled oats aroma. Taste is light boozy with a tinge of vanilla. Black licorice and bourbon flavor throughto the beer. Nicely balanced and aged.
From 22oz bottle to snifter. Pour is a black-brown color, thick tan head. Nose is thick roasted malt, oat, vanilla. Taste is medium-thick, thick head. Oily finish. Love these beers.

Pitch black with a tall, extremely dark head. Powerful bourbon, molasses, roasted malt, chocolate, light anise. Full, oily body. Finish is sweet with some mild bitterness. Complex but coordinated. Very nice

2015 bottle - Pours a pitch black with a brown head. The smell is bourbon, rich dark malt, chocolate, molasses. The taste is Rich roasted malt, molasses, bourbon ending crisp, fruity and roasty. Full bodied with elegant carbonation. I unfortunately had this beer after HF Genealogy of Morals and although very good it paled.

22oz bomber 2016 vintage. Pours pitch black with a one finger dark mocha head. Aroma is barrel, cherry, vanilla, chocolate. Taste is barrel/vanilla/cherry on the front of the palette, with a very hoppy bitter astringency attacking the mid-back palette with a minimal chocolate note. Mouthfeel is creamy with a medium body. Overall, this beer needs to age 9-12 months to let the bitter happiness recede and let the chocolate sweetness become the dominant back palette note. I¬íll sit on my other bottles and see what happens in the fall.

Bottled. 2016. Pours deep dark black. The smell is oaky chocolate and a smell of dark fruit. The palate is thick and creamy. The taste is complex. Chocolate and a lot of dark fruit. The hops is bitter and the oak and woody bourbon is a nice finish. The taste lingers on for a while. Starts tasting better when warms up

Make sure you eat some food first! At 11% this brew will wreck you! Oh so delicious with its oak and bourbon flavor. The sweetness of the molasses is subtle and absolutely perfect. I¬ím not sure I was able to single out the licorice flavor but that just didn¬ít matter because this brew is word class good!

2012 bomber - beautiful pour of an intensely black, thick liquid with a thick brownish tan head with gold speckles. Huge aroma of massive roastiness, molasses, peat, brandy and burnt sugar. Velvety intense flavors - burnt toast, molasses, coffee, chocolate, cherrywood and a light tannic mouthfeel. Long lasting burnt toast finish.

2015 Reserve
Deep black beer with light brown fine head, smell is red wine, dark chocolate, caramel, taste is very mild, soft, not too bitter and not too sweet, chocolate, cherry, full body, creamy, finish is chocolate and very nice,
(I have one pint 6 fluid ounces bottle with best after 12/08/16 and 12.2% alc/vol)

Here is a RateBeer problem with their reviews (some generated by people submitting them incorrectly): Deschutes makes MANY different Abyss beers. This one is for a 2015 reserve. Note the description for their 2014. Couldn¬ít find a 2015 description and I did try. ANYWAY...here is my review...Pours black with light brown head that dissipates to lacey. Nose of dank oak, molasses, and wine. Malty sweet front pallet taste with both bourbon and wine flavors and oak undertones and just a bit of vanilla taste. It has a lingering finish with a licorice & molasses bitterness that is almost too bitter. This was their 2015 reserve opened on 1/20/2017.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2017 Reserve 2015 bottle (12.2% abv.)/ Reserve 2016 tap@ harry¬ís hofbrau San Leandro (11.1% abv.): THIS IS RATE FOR RESERVE 2015: pours oily black, opaque with lasting creamy brown head. Aroma: roasted barley, dark malts, vanilla, licorice, cherries, molasses, sherry-like bourbon...flavor: intense, rich roasted grain, dark malts flavors which takes on milk chocolate, coffee, cacao nibs, ash, supported and perfectly integrated with vanilla, licorice, vanillin, molasses, sherry-like bourbon note, port wine-like notes & slightly astringent red wine-like notes, which never come on sour-like side (that really amaized me)...all is perfectly balanced and incorporated. Finish is dry. Body is full, texture almost creamy (velvetly), carbonation is low to moderate. F**** good, especially when it warms up. RATE FOR RESERVE 2015: 7-5-10-5-18=4.5
RATE FOR RESERVE 2016 ON TAP: 8-5-9-5-18=4.5

22 bomber to tulip. Pours black with deep brown head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, toffee, roasted malts, creme brulee, bourbon, oak, dark fruit like black cherry. Taste of same with toffee, pine, toast, brown sugar, slight licorice. Extremely balanced. Heat in finish is smooth yet warm. Pretty smooth for 11%.

2014 bottle Pours a deep dense brownish black with a dense dark beige head. The nose has roast and sweet wood, some christmas fruits and light vanilla. The taste is rich with an array of flavours from roasted malt, licorice, vinous barrel, coffee and dark chocolate. The mouthfeel is somewhat light but very creamy. Slightly bitter and lasting aftertaste.

2015 vintage. Pours deep black from the bottle and leaves a creamy light brown head. The aroma is bourbon with a vinous undertone that reminded me of sherry. Taste is bittersweet with a rich cornucopia of flavors - bourbon, oak, molasses, licorice. The mix is very nicely balanced which is maybe the beer¬ís best asset. The molasses could make it too sweet, but it does not. The bourbon is present, but does not overwhelm the vinous notes or the roasted malt flavors. Heavy bodied, thick, rich with mild carbonation. Goes down velvet smooth with no rough edges or jarring notes. My glass just dissappeared. Seldom have I been so sad to finish a bottle. Dangerous stuff! Excellent!

Waxed topped bomber into tulip glass, opaque black color with dark tan head. Aroma notes of licorice, bourbon, chocolate, red wine, berries, vanilla, dates, brown sugar and light wood. Taste adds heavier oak, vanilla cream, cinnamon, coffee, dark chocolate, dried dark fruits, smoke and semi-tart berries. Heavy body, low carbonation, creamy, rich with lingering oak, smokey malt and fruity finish. Just excellent.

An awesome imperial stout with very complex flavors. Pours a super deep black with a brown head. Smells of vanilla, cinnamon, coffee, chocolate and bourbon. Taste is vanilla and cinnamon upfront, followed by coffee and chocolate. Finish has licorice, nuts, some bitter coffee. Hint of bourbon throughout. Had the 2016 vintage in bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nose chocolate and cherry. Taste good subtle bourbon in background with chocolate coffee and especially sour cherry flavor small caramel maybe vanilla. Velvety but compared to others bit thin. Aftertaste is pleasant bittersweetness long lasting but also could be more intense.
Poured from 650mL bottle [2014 reserve]. Jet black with dark tan head. Chocolate, wood, mild coffee and licorice. Balanced, well done, fairly simple.

2014 vintage, cellared almost two years, bottled at 11.1%. Pours dark creamy bloody brown, minimal head. Smell sweet date, brown sugar, wood, bit of booze, licorice, buttered toast, liquid smoke, splash of cherry and bourbon, and more. Tastes like getting high for the first time, the first sip sets your mind at ease instantly and draws you in with its smooth and calming nature. Everything seems so simple and flawlessly done despite its clearly intricate balance of flavors and feelings. By far one of the absolute best stouts I have ever, and probably will ever, have. Saved this for my last night on active duty in the AF, a special brew for a special point in my life. I only wish I could be sharing it with someone, that would make this moment twice as tasty.

22 ounces bottle. 2015 vintage. Thanks Brian. Aroma: great mix aroma of licorice, molasses, vanilla, cherry, wood, light bourbon, light cocoa. App: very dark brown, medium mocha frothy head leaving beautiful lacing. Taste and palate: medium to full body, creamy, light to moderate bitter finish mixed with a light sweetness. Overall: quite enjoyable. Not usually a big fan of licorice but here, it is really well blended with everything else. Also the beer is not too sweet which I appreciate a lot. Another great beer from Deschutes.

2015 Reserve (12.2% ABV). 
Black, minimal brown head, some lacing. Strong roasted malts aroma, vanilla and wood. Not as thick as expected in the palate, but very complex flavours due to the multi-barrel aging. Lots of wood, bourbon, licorice, vanilla, some coffee and chocolate. Boozy and warm finish. Fantastic!

Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupe≈Çniania profilu na ratebeer. 2010 vintage. Fantastycznie dojrza≈Ço, doskonale u≈Ço≈ºy≈Ç siƒô alkohol, czekolada i melasa kr√≥lujƒÖ, d≈Çugi, kawowy finisz. Wy≈õmienity Imperial Stout.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Panel #5 Rami Rami is drinking The Abyss (2015, Rye Whiskey Barrel Aged) by Deschutes Brewery at Chmielarnia Marsza≈ÇkowskaCzekolada kawa jakby papryczki geste wanilia i lukrecja nie mocne alko mineralnosc fajne cialoOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).

So this was another stout on the Thanksgiving 2016 celebration. This was a 2014, so it had been cellared for two years. Very complex aroma and taste. Smells of raisins, malts, soy sauce, cherries, molasses, chocolate, coffee, yes, all kinds of stuff going on. But the taste was not what I was looking for. It did have a soy sauce taste, some chocolate and and heavy on the malts. There is a sour note to this beer as well. But there was too much going on I think. Was in the top three of six, but not ahead of Expedition and Bomb.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled, 2015 reserve. Pours pitch black, tan, thin head. Aroma has so much going on. Molasses, Cherry, wine, tart cherry, oak, licorice, vanilla. Super involved. Flavor is smokey, oak, wood barrel aged, coffee bitterness, cherry, chocolate, roasted malt. Not much bourbon barrel character. Maybe a bit of vanilla. Really solid.

Tasting with Alex and George. 650ml bottle from Bottle Jockey. Vintage 2015. Pours an opaque very dark brown with a dark beige head. Aroma is bourbon barrel, wine barrels, licorice, dark fruits, roasted malt and seeds. Taste is the same with medium level sweetness. Excellent.

650ml bottle at Ace¬ís. 2014 Vintage. Pours a rich black with a brown head. Nose of bourbon, vanilla, oak, and a roasted character. Flavour is intense, toasted malts, molasses, dark chocolate, dry cacao, caramel, sweet, slight bitterness and a warming finish. A lovely Imperial Stout, complex, and has aged well mellowing the bitterness and allowing other flavours to come forth.

Pours pitch black like you¬íd expect from a beer called ¬ìThe Abyss¬î. It¬ís thick as hell and looks oily & syrupy; medium, dense head that¬ís a beautiful beige and burnt umber. Smells like a bunch of dark chocolates, licorice, dark roast coffee, smoky malts, and a bit of vanilla. Smells sweeter with dark fruit notes after it warms up. Presents a strong malt backbone throughout. Initially a lot of chocolate that¬ís followed by more chocolates. The middle shows off some toasted malts, creamy vanilla, and molasses. The finish brings out all the bitter coffee notes, oak, and alcohol. At 12.2% ABV, it¬ís hard to hide the booze; the alcohol mostly shines in the finish, and it warms you on the way down. The aftertaste is a long, lingering combination of dark chocolates and coffee. With time in the glass, the molasses & licorice flavors dominate the palate with some smoky, toasty malty flavors still sticking around to balance it out. After warming up, flavors also take on a dark fruit quality reminiscent of dates, raisins, figs. Silky smooth with a bold, full, chewy; carbonation is absent; sticky on the lips and dry at the finish. Delicious and complex with a long glass life to showcase the variety of flavors. It¬ís a big, strong beer that tastes as bold as its alcohol strength.

2016-10-07 Sample from bottle @ Stockholm Beer & Whisky Festival. 2014 vintage. Tastes a bit like coffee that have stayed too long in the coffee machine (some sourness to the coffee taste), ash, liquorice, chocolate and salt. Dry aftertaste.
22 oz. from Whole Foods. Pour was dark brown/black. Aroma was largely molasses with some licorice.
22 oz bottle pours black with a brown head. aroma of licorice, coffee and chocolate. Taste is bourbon, chocolate and malt.
I honestly felt let down by this one. I had a 2013 cellar aged for a year and it was overpowered by the wine barrel aging, and finished more tart than I feel it should have.
Aroma of raisins, licorice, plum, wood, burned malts. Taste of clearly burned malts, tannin, chocolate, wood, licorice. A bit too roasted without enough backbone. Very dry.

2016 Philly Beer Week draft at the Deschutes Street Pub. 2014 version. Pours ink black with a small tan head, almost the color of peanut butter. Aroma of bourbon over notes of coffee and wood. Full-bodied and oily, with a lightly astringent finish. Flavor of coffee with some barrel char, giving way to bourbon and some boozy heat.
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2016 Bottle, 2011 version. Melass, licorice, cocoa, dark fruit. Dry mouthfeel, oily. Very good and complex.

2015 reserve poured into a wineglass showing pitch black and no head.

The nose shows a big mix of all the elements - the oak, the wine, roasted malts, and chocolate.

The palate is surprisingly light bodied and moderately carbonated. Flavors of light cherries, roasted malts, molasses, and subtle vanilla. Big dark burnt espresso bitterness on the end. Complex but slightly unharmonious; needs more time to age and settle.

650 ml bottle from Blackwell's Beer Run. Fantastic aromas of toasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. Flavour is bold and matches. Definitely one to savour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2016 2015 vintage. Aroma- Dark chocolate, dark roast coffee, licorice root, Mexican vanilla, wood chips Appearance- Inky black, completely opaque when held to the light. Half finger of brown foam. Taste- Dark chocolate, cherry wood, coffee, light vanilla, coffee crisp chocolate bar, pic price root. Palate- Thick and creamy, slightly acrid in a pleasant way. Average carbonation. Overall- Fantastic imperial stout, hard to believe it¬ís as strong as it is. The alcohol comes through only in warm finish. Impressive.

2012 vintage on tap at World of Beer (Charlottesville, VA). Aromas of charred, raisiny cherry, oak, soft vanilla, some cacao. Black with a fairly lasting cream-colored head. Dry, woodsy, some herbaceous flavors, almost minty, licorice, chocolate-covered raisins. Full bodied, sticky, lingering flavors of dried fruit, raw cacao, and heavy roast.
On tap at original gravity, San Jose. Complex imperial stout; bourbon is smooth and subtle. Excellent beer.

Sweet, overripe, dark fruits, bourbon, wood, vanilla, toasted malts, sweet chocolate and coffee. Black, small, creamy, beige head. Medium sweet. Intense, dark, toasted malts, caramel, molasses, dark chocolate, dry cacao, sweet, dark roast coffee, light alcohol, bitter and warm finish. Beautiful Imperial Stout, immensely complex aroma and palate, nice bourbon flavours. Keg at Map Room, Chicago.

Bottle thanks to Neil. Pours pitch black with a medium brown head which recedes to a lacing. Aroma is cocoa, vanilla, oak, raisins. Taste is raisins, vanilla sweet, oak, bourbon, slight tartness, a lot of wood, sugar sweet.
Bottle. Pours black. Aroma and taste are oak, molasses, bourbon, dark fruits, roasted malts, and vanilla.

Wow. 22 oz bomber split with Marc and JoJo at CC. Pours black, nice tan, clingy head. Aroma of molasses, licorice, Bakers chocolate, vanilla bean, wood, roast, slight char, mellow coffee notes. Taste is a fantastic potpourri of bittersweet chocolate, treacle, anise, vanilla, bourbon, oak, and espresso. Mouthfeel is rich and full; thick without being chewy, smooth. Absolutely fantastic.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 2014 shared. Black with big brown head. Blackberries, coffee, lots of roasted malts, cocoa, red wine, light vanilla, licorice, rye, a touch of smoke. Over medium sweet and medium bitter. Full bodied but not crazy so like the Surly Darkness we¬íve had before. Very good.

Les classiques ne le deviennent pas sans rison et surtout pas en un jour. Cette bi√®re figure parmi les chefs de file dans le style et je comprends pleinement pourquoi. Wow! Liquide √† la robe noire et satin√©e formant une majestueuse mousse aliment√©e par des bulles de toutes les dimensions, formant ainsi une v√©ritable oeuvre d¬íart sur mon verre! Un look absolument sublime! Ar√¥mes parfaitement √©quilibr√©es allant du chocolat noir, au vin de Porto en passant par le toffee et le caramel mou. C¬íest coh√©rent, √† la fois d√©licat et autoritaire et d¬íune riche complexit√©.Ce triple vieillissement en baril est responsable d¬íune remarquable homog√©n√©it√© des ar√¥mes. Texture soyeuse comme la peau d¬íun nourrisson, je suis charm√© par cette douceur chocolat√©e et vanill√©e. Une fine bulle titille mon palais r√©chauff√© par cette boisson dont je ne sens aucunement le moindre pourcentage d¬íalcool. Longue en bouche sans jamais √™tre lassante, je pourrais boire des pintes de cette bi√®re!

On draft at Pittsburgh Craft Beer week 14 April 2016. Caliente Pizzeria.
Rich nose, notes of coffee, licorice and maybe raisin. Dark brown pour with rich, tan foam. Toasted malt and chocolate flavor with surprisingly dry finish. Very busy in the background, some coffee, some oak. It rewards patient drinking. Comparatively light mouthfeel for a stout. Lives up to the advertisement.

2010 Vintage shared @oldmanriver¬ís with anonymous thanks to the Oregonian soul, 3 lambieks to the wind, interning at De Cam who kindly parted with this at the 2014 Nacht van de Grote Dorst. - Lives up to its reputation and rights the wrongs of many an infused US ImpStout by sheer depth and subtle complexity of natural flavours: jet black mocha pour, oozing with burnt caramel, cr√®me br√ªl√©e, bitter chocolate glazing, tobacco, liquorice sticks, oak and soft vanilla bourbon. - Flavour offers a time-clocked plunge thick with synaptic bliss into those flavours, where the aging seems to have reserved separate layers and deep niches of all notes in that aromatic register: Kahlua coffee liquor matured into vintage port sidling up to a Wiener Kaffee and candied liquorice sticks. Lovely wood (oak), vanilla and bourbon notes to top it all off, sanding off all uncouth edges (if there were any) in the young brew.

Kindly shared by [email¬†protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */¬ís bachelor¬ís farewell tasting, thanks a lot! This 6 year old work of art offers a taste experience that lives up to its well-chosen name. For sure, aging has added to this three-dimensional impression. Molasses and sweet licorice descend into burnt toast deepening into layers and layers of bitter chocolate getting fruitier and more and more wine-like, with sherry and port notes towards the finish.

2015 batch. Pours a dark, inky black with a brown head. Smells of oak, bourbon, vanilla, coffee and maybe some licorice. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, molasses, cherry, followed by wood and bourbon. A very complex flavor. Mouthfeel is rich and creamy. Well balanced. Abyss was my first big beer and it still holds up.
This is the 2008 version. Very boozy. Extremely rich and complex.Surprised the whisk is still so strong.

Aroma is molasses, caramel, toffee, coaco and coffee beans , vanilla and roasted malts. Taste is richly toasted malts, vanilla, toffee, espresso, caramel and coffee bean hinted by vanilla. Light tartiness on the finish. Appearance is black with a dark brown head that retains quite well. Complex and delicious.
Snifter at WoB Fort Worth - pours dark black - slight head - dissipated quickly - smells fantastic - taste coffee molasses licorice - all the rumors on this beer are true.

Bottle picked up in Austin, TX. Pours an opaque black with minimal brown head, which dissipated quickly. Aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate and anise. Taste follows with a heavy licorice forward flavor followed by toasty malt. Alcohol is well hidden. Outstanding stout!

2015 Edition on tap at Shamrocks. Poured a virtual black color with a nice thick head and ample lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, roasted malt and bit of chocolate. Taste of dark fruit, roasted malt, bit of molasses and chocolate. Nominal bitterness and a dry finish. Fairly fully body, smooth with a rich texture and subtle touch of alcohol. Very enjoyable and well worth the journey.
Bottle at Imazato. Great stuff, booze, bit of treacle, light spice. Hints of dark fruit. Bit of smoke. Boozy, bourbon. Very enjoyable.

Bomber purchased from Bottle Jockey in Burnaby, BC. A very dark and inky looking brew with minimal carbonation and a very heavily roasted nose, through which I detect a hint of whisky and vanilla. The taste is evocative of chocolate, coffee, licorice, whisky, and yes, vanilla. No hop detected. I attribute the slight bitterness to the heavily roasted malts. The mouth feel is oily. Yes! 4.1

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2016 This is the 2013 edition. The nose is treacle at first and then gives way to raisins, dates and a bit of smokiness. Taste and moth fee are wonderful. A bitter, but not harsh, backbone with a moderate sweetness, all wrapped up in a creamy body. Slight alcoholic warmth as it goes down, and a satisfying creamy-bitter finish. Wonderful.
500 mL bottle. Biiig. Complex. Dark. So much going on, and it doesn¬ít get muddled at all. Roast, mocha, licorice, maraschino cherries, vanilla, molasses. Outstanding.

Alcohol aroma. Strong red winy. . Pours black with a tan head. Taste is very sweet. Some roast bitterness balances, but it lingers in not a good way. It¬ís just way sweet at first and way bitter after. It¬ís not bad, but I¬ím not getting a lot besides the slight stone fruit flavor which is disappointing
Near black pour with tan head and Aroma of sweet roast malt. Taste is dry roast chocolate malt. Very creamy and bitter finish.
2015 Reserve. Delicious. Full bodied. Pretty much what you would expect. Not hot. Good smokiness. Tight bite in the back.

Deep opaque black brown, quite deep brown, ample head. Cinnamon, nutmeg, molasses, light coffee. Light tang, some bitterness, some sweetness. Very complex, very long quite dry finish. Medium heavy body, fairly syrupy. Very good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A great stout but recent versions have lacked some robustness for my taste. Get it if you can however.
From bottle into wine glass. Black large brown head. Intense malted barley, chocolate, blueberry. Sweet, medium bitterness, dry finish. Huge body, nice.
Molasses and cherry notes on a rich imperial stout. Lots of alcohol on the palate, long finish, some coffee and licorice.

Shared 22 oz. bottle. 2015 edition. Bottle states ¬íBest after 12/08/2016¬í. Couldn¬ít wait that long; wanted to try this. Pours like oil and is almost black with a thick, creamy brown head. Aroma of bourbon, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and molasses. Tons of flavor. Taste is bourbon, oak, molasses, chocolate, coffee, and has hints of licorice and vanilla. Maybe faint vinous notes as well. Thick, full-bodied and extremely rich. This is made for slow sipping. My only complaint is that there might be a little too much bourbon flavor, but it¬ís not nearly as strong as some of the other barrel-aged stuff out there. Looking forward to aging this. Fantastic!

Aroma: chocolatey, malty and boozy; Appearance: inky black with very dark tan head that dissipates very slowly; thick lacing that sticks; Taste: huge mouthful of chocolate, malt while balanced with bourbon and some hops; extremely complex and layered taste that changes with time; Palate: viscous, oily, heavy as lead; Overall: amazing. my favorite imperial stout yet.

2014 bottle... Thick black pour with beige head. So much thick goodness going on. Slight cherry raisiny awesomeness covered in oak-aged malty goodness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The abyss ¬í14, consumed on 12.03.16

Pours a pitch black color with a surprisingly big, spongy head.

Does smell of an earth entangled grape ripeness, which does not turn sour by any means as for a balancing, subtle integrated oak quality. A fantastic, multilayered chocolate aroma slowly evolves from scorched malts, leading to a restrained, yet enjoyable Bourbon spiciness, adding to the chocolate richness of the nose. A flowery wood bark note completes the utmost originally and well composed aromas, which get pleasantly dominated by the wine barrel and matured hops. 

Drinks with a world class mouthfeel to it, due to a huge amount of whipped cream, effectivly blending into soothing chocolate. While its carbonation is certainly on the lower end, it is still able to add a subtle, bubbly refreshment during the finish.

Tastes of chocolate dipped cherries, evolving to an even fruitier stage in which juicy, matured grapes become visible, which get wrapped up by a pungent blend of burned malts and bitter chocolate. A divine creaminess caresses the tongue while oak, licorice and burned wood bark get recognizable, tied together by a subtle wine tartness, which also produces a nice sweeter quality, enhanced by caramel and rock sugar. Cocoa nibs and matured, grassy hops provide a surprisingly aggressive hop punch during the finish, immediately soothed by the rich creaminess, while molasses, oak and milk chocolate are able to cut through.

Wow, this is certainly one of the most complex beers I¬íve ever had, which may be due to its rich chocolate maltiness, which only gets carefully accentuated by the different barrels instead of getting dominated by them. This allows to unfold a decadent, rich creaminess, shining for its very silk mouthfeel, which finds it antagonist in dry, scorched earthen malts.
Bottle from Green Dragon in Portland. Black with a minimal tan head. Nicely balanced with roasted malt, bourbon, oak and some vanilla. Also notes of chocolate. A nice one.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2016 Thick boozy molasses aroma. Deep black color. Taste has grassy and floral notes but dark sour fruit that?s over ripe. Burnt coffee and vanilla. Very good. Nice palate for how high this abv is. Tap

Had 2013 in bottle in sept 2016. Holy wow. Smooth as hell. Boozy, but amazing. Molasses, raisins, licorice, and tobacco. Tar black. Bottle

Aroma - big roast, alcohol, molasses, and qualities of dark fruit
Appearance - the body is black. The head is fallow brown and well over 2+", and settles very slowly. Subsequent pours result in varying coloration of the head. Very cool. Alcohol cloying pulls beautiful brown suds.
Taste - rich dark roast, black strap molasses, licorice, marshmallow, oak, alcohol, vanilla, and a hint of dark cherry.
Palate - full body, texture is thick and slick, the carbonation is average, the finish is full of astringent dark dry roast and some alcohol that fires from both barrels.

2015 reserve bottle, dated "best after 12-08-16" and 12.2% ABV. I¬íve been wanting to try this for a long time; I hope it doesn¬ít disappoint. Great aroma of molasses, oak, leather, roast, lactose sweetness and booze. I am getting more wine barrel than bourbon barrel in the aroma and I am also getting some of the cherry bark and vanilla. The appearance is a clear 5. Shiny black color with a light brown tuft of foam. The taste is very strong and complex - heavy oak, red wine, cherry bark with only a touch of molasses from the aroma. Very roasty, hoppy and a bit sour with no sweet or rich flavors to balance it out. Not bad, but I have tasted better. Maybe I should have aged it longer. The palate is not as thick as I would like but does have a good amount of carbonation. Overall I must say I am a tad disappointed; I was expecting this to be a top 10 Imperial stout for me and it fell short of that.
Aptly named, this is dark and thick. Tons of black licorice, black plum and burnt mocha coffee. Finishes on a spicy note with subtle vanilla and bourbon underneath. Long finish.
Amazing stout. Pitch black minimal head. Aromas of cherry cordial, molasses, black licorice. Roasty, dry mouthfeel. Very complex.

Poured from bomber into a snifter
 Appearance ¬ñ The beer pours a super dark, nearly pitch black color with a two finger head of brown colored thick foam. The head has a fantastic level of retention, slowly fading over time to rings of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
 Smell ¬ñ The aroma of the beer is huge of a roasted malt smell mixed with a big showing of coffee and caramel with other notes of vanilla and chocolate being rather strong as well. Along with the these super robust aromas, comes smells of char and smoke as well as a good showing of dark fruits of raisin and prune. A bit of a boozy bourbon aroma is there as well, overall producing a smell that is very dark and roasty with a big showing of a warmingly sweet smell.
 Taste ¬ñ The taste begins as the nose would suggest with a massive dark roasted malt flavor and a good showing of coffee. There is a huge rich milk chocolate sweetness upfront which is accompanied by other sweet flavors of molasses and brown sugar. As the taste advances the roasted malt waivers ever so slightly, but with the coffee, is still the overall dominant taste of the brew. With the lightening of the roastiness (which is sorta odd to write as it is still super robust in dark flavors) comes a little bit of a raisin taste as well as a decent showing of vanilla; both of which join the other sweet and chocolate flavors quite nicely. As one may expect for a 12.2 % brew, there is a bit of a bourbon boozy taste that develops later in the tongue, which creates a nice warming feel. Flavors of char and a woody hop develop at the very end, combining with the alcohol, roasty, and sweet nicely to create rich, dark, and warming taste to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel ¬ñ The beer is thick and creamy with a very low level of carbonation level. The feel is nearly perfect for the big mix of dark, sweet and boozy flavors of the brew, coating the tongue and bathing it in all the grandiose tastes of the brew.
 Overall ¬ñ This is a very nicely crafted imperial stout. While slightly on the sweeter side all the other attributes of the brew match the sweeter and rich flavors very well. Even while sweet, it not necessarily so, and was still drinkable (in a very slow sipping way) unlike some other imperial stouts of similar strength. Overall I was rather impressed by this brew.
Aroma is chocolate, molasses, licorice, and oak. Taste has a lot going on- many flavors coming together, a little hot. Wish I would have aged out more so things could have mellowed out a bit more

2015 reserve edition. Pours black with a nice lasting brown head. Aroma of vanilla oak, dark fruit, toasted bread and chocolate. Taste is very smooth with chocolate malt, vanilla and almost a little tartness from the licorice.

Aroma is a bit of licorice, roasty grain. Taste is licorice, dark chocolate, coffee and that molasses tangy sweetness. Lots of dried, dark fruit. A bit boozy for my tastes. I think it gets lots more complex as it warms. Good stuff.

Doing a comparison between the 2014 version and 2015. Both poured completely black with the 2014 having a little more tan head than the 2015. Both smell strongly of barrel aging but on the 2014 it's mellowed a bit and you can smell some li organs molasses. The flavor of the 2015 is really hot from the liquor barrels and in the 2014 you get a better melding of the flavors. My recommendation is to let this beer age past the best after date. If you get multiple bottles is great to compare what it taste like fresh versus aged.

Aroma: bourbon, woody, vanilla, vinous, licorice, molasses, 
Appearance: black with a brown head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: full body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, 

Excellent

Nearly jet black in color with a tan head. Complex aroma of oak, dark fruits, reminds me of drinking a red wine at times. Well-integrated palate with roasted malt and a hint of dark fruit. Bitterness is completely in balance and becomes more assertive on the back of the palate. Full-bodied. You would not guess this is an 11% ABV beer. This is an exceptionally well made beer.

Draft at Kasey¬ís Tavern. Jet black pour with a thin ring of mocha head. The nose is dominated by fresh roasted coffee. Tastes of thick molasses, licorice, and sweet black coffee up front. Warming brings on some fruity notes of cherry and cassis. The oak and bourbon come out as well, giving it a faint smokiness. Bitter and dry finish, with a touch of booze apparent. World class for sure.

2012 Vintage. Tasted on tap at 2016 Wolpertinger Fest in glass German beer mug. It poured an opaque black colour, reddish at the edges when held to the light, tall sudsy brown foam. Great wood-aged Imperial stout traits, all around. Toasty, roasty, profoundly chocolatey, marshmallowy sweetness, caramel, tart almost to the point of acidic, red berry fruit, black currants, roasted nuts, charred wood, tannins, Fuggly hop balance persists even after lengthy aging. Full-bodied, chewy, alcoholic but not unpleasantly hot. Lingering complex aftertastes. Great stuff.
Pours jet black in color, has some nice creamy head retention and decent lacing. The smell reminds me of cherry and chocolate. Tastes bitter like coffee, excellent drink!

Bottle, 2009 vintage, enjoyed in 2010. Pours abyssal, bottomless black. Void-like, the darkness of this beer sucks in all light. A fizzy one-finger head the color of cardboard rises up from the inky depths slowly and dissipates after a short time. A sticky, foamy ring lingers at the edges, surrounding some oily residue. In the nose: lots of licorice, molasses, lactic dark chocolate, milk chocolate, peanuts, lightly toasted bread, caramel and malted chocolate. Very nice. This appears to be an uninfected bottle. HUZZAH! The barrel-aged characters are far more apparent here: oak, vanilla, a teeny bit of bourbon. The beer improves tremendously as it warms, as sweet plums emerge amidst light roast coffee, black licorice and toasty wheat bread. The deeper, acrid charred flavors march in slowly after the swallow and linger nicely between sips. There¬ís a great balance of complex sweet and roasty flavors here, and every sip reveals new dimensions. The body¬ís just a shade under medium, soft and smooth. It¬ís just a little thin for such a big stout. A medium, numbing carbonation caresses the tongue. The alcohol is pretty hefty at first, flaming the throat like heartburn on the way down, but this too improves as I work my way through the glass. I¬íve enjoyed the Abyss both fresh and aged now, and can say that it¬ís a beer that definitely improves with time. The heat has died down and the flavors, though not quite as bright, are nicely melded. Not mind-blowing, but definitely enjoyable.

2013 bottle. Pours black with a dark tan head. Aromas of chocolate, molasses, wood, vanilla, spice, slightly vinous, dark fruit character (blackcurrant/blackberry?), anise, dried fig, and raisin. Taste is roasted malt, char, chocolate, vinous, wood, dried fig and raisin, spice, slight molasses, vanilla, some dark berry, medium bitterness and slightly sweet. Medium-full body, smooth carb. You can tell this is high abv but it¬ís not too hot. Not too syrupy sweet either like some imp stouts are. Finishes with a nice char and slight dryness. Very complex, a great beer.

2014 bottle poured into a snifter..dark pour with a medium tan head..aroma
of chocolate,oak,coffee,licorice,,tastes of chocolate,oak,wine..medium body..
disappointing.

22oz bottle poured into a snifter. The aroma is initially a rich, dark cherry and chocolate blend with a mild molasses and coffee and a hint of licorice and leather, as well as and smokey char character (woody). The aroma turns towards a chocolate, biscuit, and toffee mix. The hue is black and opaque with a dense, soapy brown head that reduces to a mild wisp with bubbles, and leaves a light lace. The taste is highly sweet complimented by a medium high bitter. The texture is slick and smooth with a light, soft foam carbonation and a full body. The flavor profile is strong of figs and raisin up front with a chocolate and wood hint. The finish is sticky with mild alcohol warmth that cleans up with a wood resin feel and flavors of chocolate malt, tart, dark cherry, licorice and molasses with a hint of caramel and cookie. The aftertaste is light and mellow with a dry, charred character and a bit of a leathery molasses with light toffee and bitter floral, resin, and licorice.

Bomber to a goblet. Viscous black with mocha head and lacing. Amazing aroma, vanilla, cherry, chocolate, coffee, bourbon, toasted oak. Flavor is multilayered and complex. Smooth balanced, warming finish... Truly exceptional beer, one of the best.

Tap at stanleys at the blackout beer fest. 8oz pour. Black with small medium tan head. Strong Dark fruit and alcohol nose. Boozy, sweet, malty, with some chocolate notes. Alcohol dark fruit sweetness dominates though. A bit peaty. This is a powerful beer.

Vertical with 2009-2013 inclusive versions thanks to Frank, Ben & Catherine, Misty & Jason plus Mini & Bird. Some better than others with the 2011 the best.. Dark, pours like treacle with a tan head. Aromas of vanilla, liquorice and cocao. Taste is more complex with chocolate, coffee, vanilla. 
A definite treat to try them all together and great beer!

On tap at Harry¬ís Hofbrau in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is dark chocolate, fresh roasted coffee, bourbon (as it warms). Taste is tangy dark chocolate, licorice (sometimes medicinal), bourbon-y booze, cocoa, mild cherry liqueur. Some warming burn as it goes down. More bourbon and coffee as it warms. Very cozy and complex. Changes from sip to sip.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2016 From tap growler to wine glass
Appearance: very dark- almost pitch black but not when held against the light in a wine glass
Aroma: aroma of Chocolate
Taste : Excellent
Mouth feel : Creamy
Overall: excellent beer, one of the best
Drank: 1/9/2016	8:00 PM

How do you welcome a new year? When choosing a beer, it should be something bright and with an optimistic title to match the high hopes and promise of a new beginning. That¬ís, er, why we picked pitch black beer with the cheerful title of The Abyss. I¬ím not sure what that says about our coming year, but what a beer for the occasion. Pour is inky black. Oaky, roasty, boozy, syrupy aromas. Flavors of oak, licorice, molasses, burnt sugar, bittersweet dark chocolate, bourbon, and charred malt. This is a huge beer, but it¬íll seduce you with its smoothness. Sink into The Abyss.

Type: 22-oz. bottle
Glass: Clear plastic juice glass
From: Barons Market in Alpine, Calif.
Price: $16.99
Purchased: Jan. 7, 2015
Consumed: Dec. 31, 2015
Misc.: Best after Nov. 11, 2015; 2014 vintage

Poured a pitch black color with two fingers of rocky, tan head. Below average spotty lacing on the sides of the glass. Below average retention. (Sight - 4.00)

Smelled boozy chocolate, roasted toffee, dark caramel, oaky vanilla, dark fruits, mainly purple grape, plum and black raspberry, dark wet cocoa, molasses, wintry spices, light licorice and faint roasty malts. (Smell - 4.50) 

First taste reminded me of a slightly stronger Obsidian Stout or Black Butte Porter. Got roasted dark chocolate, toffee, caramel, dark fruits - black raspberry and purple grape - molasses, smoky fire, char wood, oaky vanilla and licorice. (Taste - 4.25)

Full body. Sticky texture. Average carbonation. Long, smooth finish. (Feel - 4.50)

This was a very good imperial stout, but not as good as I hoped. Can¬ít get over how close it is to Obsidian Stout and Black Butter Porter. Would have it again though, but not for $16.99. (Overall - 4.25)

4.32 96 A

Bottle.

A- Dark molasses, chocolate, subtle coffee, mild roastiness.

A- Black color, black liquid, brown head.

T- Subtle oak, subtle bourbon, molasses, chocolate.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, complex finish.

O- 2014 Vintage. What a beer for my first of 2016. No particular flavor stood out in this beer. In fact, it was hard to take notes because it was so well balanced. This was a great beer that most definitely lives up to the hype.
Really dark and bitter. Good but probably couldn¬ít drink more than one at a time. Good.
2014 Reserve Bottle. Pours Black with tan head. Aroma is Chocolate, Bourbon and Malt. Taste is sweet malt chocolate up front with a bourbon alcohol chocolate finish. Excellent beer.

Bouteille 650ml, gracieuset√© de Beervana lors du CanBIF Spring 2015, Thanks Cameron! Couleur noire opaque, mousse moka fonc√©e fugace. Ar√¥me de malt torr√©fi√©, cerise, Bourbon, anis√©, caf√©, cacao, cendr√©, m√©lasse. Go√ªt de caf√©, malt torr√©fi√©, l√©g√®re acidit√©, chocolat, bois√©. Carbonatation faible, corps moyen-dense.

2014 Vintage. Dark, syrupy black pour with a nice brown head. Aroma is vanilla, licorice, cocoa, oak. Taste is dark chocolate, espresso, vanilla, oak and whiskey. Complex. Full bodied, medium carb. Awesome.

Tap. Black with one finger head. First sip is a wtf moment, but in a good way. There is so much flavor complexity. Wood, dark fruit, berry, dark chocolate, light bourbon. Medium bitterness in the finish.

Bottled 11/11/2014 and enjoyed 12/1/2015 in a MadTree tulip/snifter. 

Look - Dark brown with a half finger of khaki head. It settled to a ring very quickly after slowly developing. Lacing is blotchy. 

Smell - Chocolate. Tobacco. Bourbon. Vanilla. Licorice. Chocolate. Fruit.

Taste - Drink it cold and it tastes almost like a barely wine. Let it warm and it is apparent it is a stout. Follows the nose. This is so complex. 

Feel - Finishes dry. No alcohol burn. Medium carbonation. Chewy feel.

Overall - There are good barley wines, good sweet stouts, and good dry stouts. This is all of those. It is complex and worth the wait. I hope I pick up a 2015 in late 2016 like I did the 2014.

Thanks to Bytemesis, the 2012 Reserve bottle poured jet black with a thick tan head and nice lacing. Aromas of fresh coffee, chocolate, molasses, and a slight booze warmth. Flavor is mildly coffee bitter that lingers.

A ton of wood flavor with some smoke. Some people will like this and some will not. I do like it but it's a bit in-your-face flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle (22oz $21): (2014) Dark Dark brown with brown head. Aromas are light roastyness. Taste was of roasted malts, almost Smokey. Then some licorice, but not too sweet. Very nice if you can get it.

650ml bottle (v2013) from trade with RobertDale. Thank you Bob!! Black color with beige brown head. Roasted malty aroma, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, licorice, dark dried fruits, raisins, wood, smoked notes. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Full silky oily to creamy body with soft carbonation.
Oak barrel aging doesn¬ít fit my taste but the black strap molasses is front and center here...it tones down the oak flavor and creates a more agreeable flavor for me.

Pours jet black from tap with cocoa brown head. Aroma dark chocolate, dark cherries. Taste is cocoa nibs, slight coffee, dark cherry, slightly roasted, slightly sweet. Nice mouthfeel. Very good beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Licorice, rasins, booze, dark chocolate, bread rolls and an incredible velvet mouthfeel. Don¬ít notice the pomegranate at all....Bombers the last two years. Both were excellent. Bought an extra to lay down for a vertical tasting in 2yrs. Will update if I can remember any thing after three glasses of this!

Black colour, tan head. Aroma of bourbon, caramel, malts, roasted malts. Sweet, light bitter flavour, roasted malts, liquorice and coffee. Finish roasted malts, liquorice, coffee and cacao.(from 66cL bottle @ ZZT XII, ¬íGetting Joes¬íd to it¬í Oirschot. 2012 Reserve. Thanks for sharing, Koen!)
Tar black pour with aroma of vanilla, molasses, oak, and roasted malt. Licorice, molasses, vanilla flavor with some oak, a touch of bourbon, and roasted malt.

Pours jet black with tan head and some lacing. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, licorice, molasses, and light soy sauce. Taste is the same with some vanilla oakiness. Very complex and vey smooth for the abv. Great brew!

2014 reserve. Pours black with brown head. Heavy body. Black licorice, little bit if vanilla, chocolate flavor, oak flavor, slight bourbon alcohol heat, caramel. Finishes pretty sweet like dark fruits and chocolate.
Draft pour at Snallygaster shared by solidfunk, thanks Josh! Black with tan head. Aromas of dark fruit, caramel, toffee, roast, chocolate. Tastes of similar. Full body with a dry finish.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2015 Very nice stuff. Huge roast and some dark chocolate. Some coffee and nut. Pours black with good head and lacing. Thick creamy consistency. Soft carbonation. Bittersweet finish. Tap.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2015 Vintage bottle from 2007, thanks Lieven of Velootje for sharing. Thickly lacing, stable, beige head over an ink black beer. Complex and interesting aroma of dry red wine, old madera wine, cigar ashes, liquorice (apparently added), chestnuts, coffee grounds, passion fruit, port, hint of soy sauce, vague banana. Somewhat candied onset (candied figs) but very subtly so, not even becoming sweet, blue plum or grape peel, cocoa, evolving quickly into a very dry, coffeeish, bitter chocolate roasted flavour, bit resiny, with the added liquorice all the way at the back, far less prominent than I had feared, but leaving a resiny bittersweet sensation on the root of the tongue; roasted coffee and charcoal bitterness remains along with peppery hop bitterness and a glow of warming, brown rhum-like alcohol; mouthfeel is thick and oily with very soft carb, but a little bit thinner than expected (possibly due to age). Not sure if this is the way this beer is supposed to taste, but after eight years, I get no signs of oxidation whatsoever; I do assume it was sweeter and more fragrant when young, but in this condition, this works perfectly. It has gained a tartness not unlike an ¬íoud bruin¬í (Flemish red) which does make it different from most other ¬íhyped¬í RIS beers I had. Interesting and memorable experience for sure, and glad I got a chance to taste this classic.

VINTAGE 2014 Pours black as tar with a rapidly dissipating chocolate brown head. Strong alcohol aroma and not much else, a hint of things to come.
Drinking it out of my favorite Duvel beer glass at about 50¬∞F. A bit thick or oily but not syrupy. I couldn¬ít find its o.g., but it is well attenuated given the 11% abv. The first taste you sense is the from the very dark roasted barley. Next comes in the alcohol mixed with delicate flavors of licorice, and a touch of vanilla and cherry. There is a nice, mildly bitter hop aftertaste. It is getting better as I write this, by time I hit the Enter button it might rank a 5.0 or that may be the alcohol getting to me. I should have let this one age longer. 
Luckily, I still have a bottle of the 2009 Vintage, which I am saving for a special event. Great beer. Do yourself a favor; buy a case and enjoy a bottle with a friend every six months.
Prost !!!!!!!!

Bottle 0.65l at The 8th Belgrade tasting Session One at the Beerville Beer Bar.17.07.2015.Thanks to Matt for bringing this vintage bottle to Serbia.Special from Matt¬ís cellar Vintage 2011 bottle.Pour it dark color woth thick black head.Aroma of sweet black fruits.Taste so complexed, wau, dark fruits, vanilla,licorice, american hops bitterness present, figs, really perfect complexed, aged very well.After taste dark chocolate.Perfection.
Bomber - coffee out the ass and dark chocolate. Little heata sipper. Complex bitterness.
2014 vintage. Dark black. Black licorice. Solid imperial stout. Vanilla. Oak. Barrel. Thick. Shared w carter. From brewtopia in NE. Pretty flawless.

Poured pure black with brown head that hung around for minutes. Aroma of cocoa chocolate and some fennel. Flavor of cocoa chocolate and some vanilla. Some alcohol heat which was very pleasing. Finishes a little roasty and delicious.
Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is malt, roasty, chocolate, coffee, caramel, oak and vanilla. Taste is medium to high sweet leading to a beautifully smooth finish. Brilliant!

Scored this bottle back in the summer and finally opened it up for Christmas Eve, 2012 version. Poured a deep inky black with a thin tan head. Aromas of alcohol, slight roast malt, faint hints of black coffee, some vinous wine, brown sugar, molasses and slight licorice. Very nice aroma. Deep, complex and strong. Taste begins with black coffee, rich roast malt, bittersweet cocoa and vanilla bean, with notes of oak, licorice, very faint hints of wine and hints of oak and bourbon in the background, especially as the beer warms. Finish and aftertaste are bitter, roasty and strong in black coffee. Very well done, balanced, yet assertive, aged, yet not dank. An excellent flavor. Mouthfeel is medium-thick bodied, sticky with a faint alcohol burn. Quite nice, very much a sipping beer. Overall this is another excellent, deep, complex Imperial Stout. It¬ís strong, assertive and bold, yet balanced. Well worth drinking.

At the 8th tasting (round 1), held at Vlada¬ís Beerville pub in Belgrade-Serbia. 2011 vintage bottle courtesy of Matt(eo) directly from his personal cellar (or bunker if you believe to the multiple assumptions about his real job) in Seattle-USA. GRAZIE! Hurrah for the USA! Pours oily black with a brownish head. Nose: dark chocolate, milled coffee beans, silky aroma. Very nice. Mouth: signs of oxidation, velvet taste on the tongue,bitter enough in the end, alcohol forward. Rich, bitter, dry!
Unfortunately I do not have time to write an appropriate review. But this is a great imperial.

2014 Reserve 650mL wax-seal (which is a pain in the ass, btw) bottle from Beer Cartel. Best after 11/11/15 - whoops!?
Looks the part - pitch black, small but firm orange-tan head persisting.
Nose not overly prominent, but there¬ís a lot going on - licorice obviously, charred wood, Bourbon, earthy spice, resiny citrus & leafy hops, dark chocolate, espresso, I could go on...
Oh so smooth, velvety texture, scarily drinkable, low carbonation keeps things restrained.
Kicks up another gear on the palate, just tremendous really - dark chocolate, rich dark roast espresso, molasses & licorice root, toasty oak vanilla, charred oak, Bourbon like good Bourbon not that Jim Beam tripe, vinous black fruits, resiny hops, piney hops, citrus hops, American hops - you get the idea - and a big American-style bitterness to boot. It lingers, it¬ís brutal, it doesn¬ít let go, feels like i need a glass of water to wash the last bits out of my mouth but i don¬ít think that would suffice. Booze is warming, welcoming, compliments my fireplace, but overall this is a really well balanced beer.
I had reservations at first, but this seriously delivers, worthy of its price...yeah, lets not go there...
Pretty good. A little creamy. Not my favorite stout but yeah. Somewhere between breakfast stout and something really good

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2017 2010 vintage. Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is licorice, chocolate, some barrel, booze, vanilla. Appearance is black, thick, a decent brown head. Taste is very roasty, licorice, chocolate, coffee, very nice. Mouthfeel is thick, luscious, great soft carbonation, awesome. Overall, I¬íve been waiting for this one and I¬ím happy to have finally experienced it.

650 mL bottle poured into a snifter. Best after 8/4/2012. Jet black pour. Nice mocha head with a variety of bubble sizes. Laces and clings all over. Licorice comes through a ton. Coffee malts, chocolate. Fudgy and oaky. I don¬ít get much bourbon on the nose, though. Taste is intensely fudgy. Strong oak presence. Licorice is more mild. The chocolate is really intense, especially in the finish. A slight astringency. Bitter chocolate finish that comes off as a black coffee. Nice and thick. Not quite chewy. Not a ton of booze. Warming, but not boozy. The flavors hang around forever. Complex stout. The flavors bend nicely. Very well crafted. I¬íd love more bourbon, but the stout shines through well.
Pool water smell. Taste is roasty stout, malt, dark chocolate, bitter black coffee, and way too much hops.
Really complex and delicous beer. Black pour, with low tan head. Coffee, chocolate, toffee, wood, coconut and vanilla.
2014 bottle. Strong oaky, bourbon, chocolate. Slight sourness in this beers aftertaste does not quite fit this beer in my opinion.

650ml bottle enjoyed @ home. Pours pitch black with a creamy brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, liquorice, chocolate, dark fruits, caramel, raisins and cherries. Flavour is medium sweet and toasted bitterness. Full bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation. Long and complex finish.

Bottle last night.. at dutch trading co.
Looks..big and black, med-lge tan head.
Smells.. Big malts, dark choc, liquorice, oak and berry, from the red wine barrel.
Tastes.. Big roasty malts, choc, liquorice, vanilla oak and red wine barrel.. Some tannins. Sensational.

Perfect imperial stout. Coffee but nit a harsh bitter coffee. Anise and fennel in nose with some walnuts and almonds. Flavor of smooth Starbucks French roast. Some alcohol warmth and finishes chocolate.

Initial reaction to this was it¬ís hideously overrated. The more I drank the more I appreciated though. A little polarising in that I think my expectations based on its reputation didn¬ít match up. But I did love the vanilla and liquorice bitterness. Just enjoy it for what it is
Bottle - Pours dark black. Nose is bourbon, oak, licorice. dark chocolate. Taste is licorice, dark fruit, sweetness, and dark chocolate. Honestly, the licorice is too much for me to enjoy this one.
Big licorice and French roast aroma with a little ouzo there. Flavor of rich coffe and dark malts with some of raisin. Flavor of light alcohol heat and a dark fruit finish.

2014 Bottle in Santa Fe. Pours deep black with dark tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, bourbon, licorice, oak, campfire, big sweet malt & booze. Flavor is sweet boozy malt, caramel, bitter espresso, chocolate cake, licorice. Major sweet, full body, big beer.. agg IS.
Definite bourbon and oak flavors with the wine barrel being an after taste. Nice lacing and coronation. Has a coffee and bourbon nose

Tasted from bottle. Aroma is peppery, licorice, coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is moderately bitter with moderate sweetness. Dark chocolate with spices in flavor. Some licorice and peppery taste with some coffee and caramel. A little dark fruit as well. Very solid imperial stout. Definitely top tier. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared by Bursprak the man. Thanks so much for bringing this! Been a big want for some time. Alright, let me explain how this went down: I thought Abyss was a regular bourbon barrelaged imperial stout, so when I smelled the open bottle I was quite surprised. Even more did the aroma surprise me, when it came from a glass. Lets dig in; pours pitch black with a medium dark brown head. Aromas of port wine, cherries, soy, dark fruits, dark chocolate, licorice, molasses, caramel, light tobacco. Taste is roasted, bitter, port wine, vanilla, licorice, salmiak, dark chocolate, molasses, caramel, cherries, dry woody notes, light smoke, burned wood, light heat. Even though I¬ím not usually much into this style of imperial stout, this was really nice.

Chosen as my rating #800. Bottle thanks to the almighty Bursprak! Pours a pitch black with a brown head. Aroma has soy sauce, cherry, oak, roasty malts, licorice. Taste is roasty bitter, and with some acidic cherry notes. Some licorice as well. Not very sweet, and very european in general. Didn¬ít quite live up to my expectations, but glad to try this! Slightly boring body and an average carbonation.

Bottle from Aaron, split a couple of ways. Blackish pour with a light head. Nose has loads of soy, light peat, fruity coffee and some light tartness. Taste has licorice, coffee, roast, a lingering tartness, some tar and ash, biter notes with some caramel.
Bottle split with Dave during GoT S5E7 5/17/2015. Pours a murky black. Aroma of light oak, bourbon. Lightly sweet, some licorocie. Tasty.

Black colour with a small beige lasting pillowy head. Aromas of chcoloate malt, bourbon vanilla liquorice, wood and hints of treacle and subtle roastyness develops. Very light carbonation with a velvety, slick texture and a full body. Harmonically balanced with sweeetness up front with a fine subtle bitterness. Complex and lasting finish. Pretty wonderful.

bottle pour. Black, viscous pour. Smell was amazing. However, the fun ended there. Not sure if it was a bad bottle or my taste buds werent all there that night, but the beer was extremely bitter and overall almost undrinkable. Have one more bottle and will try again at a later date.

12pz pour on tap into tulip. Minneapolis. 

On tap from 2011. 

Pours very dark, basically black. Small rim of mocha head. 

Aroma is heavy on dark chocolate, coffee, charred oak barrel, bourbon, subtle vanilla. 

Taste is mostly bitter, a little sweetness, but this is on the drier side for an imperial stout. 

Body is full. Smooth texture. A little frothy. Long bitter finish. 

Really nice stout. Bourbon is a little muted - not sure if that is related to the age. Very dry for the style, which I like.
Bottle. Very dark brown with no head. Malty and fruity tones. Malt, chocolate,, fruit and licorice. Full body with a long bitter sweet finish.

2011 bomber. I don¬ít remember where i got it. Pours inky black. Dark tan head. Scent is black cherries, alcohol and some dark chocolate. Taste some chocolate, coffee and alcohol. Very balanced. Aged well.

Visual: 2014 edition, black wax sealed. Pours coffee black with a very small head, petri dish lacing, SUPER-fine bubbles.

Nose: roasted dark malts, cherry wood, wet red wine barrels. (lvl-4)-pungency

Attack: very slick-oily mouthfeel, subdued alcohol

Mid-palate: light sourness, (MAIN) brown sugar, thick malts, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, woody, raspberry ->transition-> (lvl-7)-sweetness+malt

Finish: soy sauce, licorice, roasted-burnt bitter exhale, light burpy, cascading alcohol buzz, sweet-light bitter chocolate malt finish.

Summary: A beer with impact, both in taste and alcoholic bite. Layers upon layers of flavour, every year is exceptional. Notice the changes in flavours as the temperature decreases; less malt and more fruity characteristics emerge.
Aroma of tons of dark fruit, anise, barrel characters, taste is lots of dark fruit, maple taste, very dark red to brown appearance, alcohol finishes smooth- taste at DLD 2015. 2014 reserve.
Entering from my scorecard after having sampled at the Big Texas Craft Brew Fest.

Bomber (2014 Release). Look, I¬íve cellared this long enough. I have no patience to wait another 7 months until this hits it¬ís ¬íbest-after date¬í (and moreover, it¬ís also after 2:00am and it¬ís the only beer in the house)... so yeah. Okay, pours a nearly jet black, opaque stouty color, excellent chocolate-milk-colored foamy head with very nice retention and lacing. Nose is loads of cocoa, coffee, roastiness, dried fruit (raisins, dates and figs), candy sugar and a hint of smoked almonds. Mouth is oily and rich, nice balanced of bittersweet chocolate, coffee, roasted barley and barrel, getting some of that licorice, plums, and a pleasant underpinning bitterness throughout. Next year I¬íll try and be more patient as I¬ím now more curious to see what some age on this will do... because it¬ís pretty fucking impressive as is.

22 ounce bottle, 2014 vintage, label says best after 11/11/15. Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch frothy tan head that stayed around for a while. There¬ís also a bunch of lacing. Aroma is great, the brew smells like molasses, red wine, oak, coffee, chocolate, burnt/charred malt, and a bit of vanilla. The taste is pretty good too, there¬ís burnt/charred malt, coffee, chocolate, molasses, licorice, red wine, oak, bourbon, and vanilla flavors. Lots of bittersweet goodness! Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, it¬ís coating and creamy with moderate carbonation. I¬íve been waiting a while to try this, and I wasn¬ít disappointed! I liked this brew a lot, it¬ís going to be hard for me not to drink my other bottle before the "best after" date. I¬íll definitely buy this again the next time it¬ís released. $14.99 a bomber.
A hell of an Imperial Stout. This was is nice and rich, heavy, dark, strong. The perfect last beer of the night.

Bottle take home from Rustico-Ballston, into snifter. Black with moderate tan head. A: coffee, anise, oak, booze, nuts. T: coffee, molasses, licorice, chocolate malt, nuts. Smooth palate. Very very good, but was nonetheless expecting to like it even more. I think the licorice threw it a little off for me.
Looks black brown head. Smells of big chocolate sweet bitter bourbon. Dark roast. Tastes of big dark chocolate roast alc. Smoothish on the palate being so big.

2013 Bottle to pint glass
Chicolate, toasted malt, molasses, oil. Dark oily black with a 1 cm creamy bown head and nice lacing. Taste is molasses, chocolate, caramel, toasted malt. Great beer.
Bottle. This is a viscous roasted malt bomb with lots of dark stone fruits and burnt brown sugar.

Big...heavy. Lots of chocolate. This is a sipper for sure... but if you give it some time, and make sure it¬ís not too cold, there are some really amazing flavors going on in the beer. Very complex and delicious.

This wonderful beer pours an inky color with an espresso head that laces nicely. Aromas include coffe, bourbon, and molasses. Has tastes of burnt sugar, raisin, and bitter espresso with a boozy warm finish. Overall a great stout!
Dark obviously, lots of lacing etc on the glass. Sweet coffee aroma, barrels, char. Similar flavor plus chocolate. Quite bitter for a stout. Very nice.

Bomber of 2014. Dark roasty aroma with some licorice and coffee on the nose. Dark black pour with a finger nail of amber brown head. The roasty taste is bold and up front followed by the licorice, slight vanilla(which comes in more as it warms), and moderately bitter coffee finish. Conceals some of the booze but only some of it.

2013 reserve. Pours a jet black color with hints of murkiness and a nice sudsy tan head. Aromas of wood, bourbon, coffee, black licorice, chocolate, and nuts. Taste was incredible and complex. It was a nice mix of medium sweetness and bitterness. Full bodied with an oily texture to it. Lively carbonation and a nice long bitter finish with a hint of bourbon burn. Very happy I got to try this!

2010 bottle at the March Libertine Bottle Share. I¬íve had this numerous times but I guess I never rated it. Pours a deep black with slight tan head. Aroma is marshmallow, slight clove, some coffee. Taste is more on the bitter chocolate but muted, honey, oak and some vanilla.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
Pours a solid black with a short tan head and lacing. It has a rich aroma of toasty malt, some coffee, and bourbon. The flavor is dark malt and bourbon up front with a slightly spicy and malty backbone with a sweet and slightly bitter finish over a heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[Bottle] 2011 vintage opened last week. Pours an inky black with about an inch worth of darker brown foam on top. Licorice, deep roasted malts, oak and mild vanilla in the nose. Notes of anise and wooden barrel come through prominently in the flavor. Dark fruit, brown sugar, caramelized malts, bitter chocolate, port wine and some vanilla also make an appearance. Mild alcohol heat. Oily mouthfeel. Tasty stuff!

22 oz bottle, poured into a snifter at approximately 45 degrees F.

Appearance: Pours pitch black like its namesake, and forms a fairly thick head of brown froth. Lacing is quite present.

Smell: The aroma primarily reminds me of red wine and dark chocolate, mingled together. There is a tart red grape and cherry presence, and I¬íd say around 80% - 85% cocoa dark chocolate.

Taste: At the opening, this beer follows the nose, a blast of pure slightly sour red wine with cherries and baker¬ís chocolate. As it moves along, the flavors flow into a dark yeasty bread mingled with scorched toffee, with notes of vanilla along the edges. By the finish, the flavor profile is entirely black bread, earth, and oak. As the beer warms, the flavor transitions smooth out. The barrel notes, while present, do not overtake the entire beer, and the ABV lends just a pleasant touch of warmth. 

Mouthfeel: Full and fairly creamy, though a bit thinner than one would expect for a stout this black.

Overall: Quite a good stout, showcasing both complexity and intensity of flavor. I¬ím glad I happened upon a bottle of it sitting on the shelf at a local shop as I breezed in for some birthday shopping.
Certainly deep and dark, a black hole that sucks you in. Very bitter chocolate and dry wood. Very rich, notes of black licorice. Thanks Max!
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2015 I had a 2011 of this a few weeks ago and it was pretty awesome. I would highly recommend
2014 bottle. Dark pour duh tan brown head. Dark chocolate, vanilla cherries and bitter. Complex, boozy.
