Ugh, long descriptive passage was here, now gone. 2014 bomber. Aroma: tart red wine, roasty malt. Taste: coffee, cherrywood, dark chocolate, acidic red wine, later cherries and vanilla. At first seemed mellow and blah, later complex and dynamic. Great tan head, great lacing. Great beer. Took a few 10 minutes for me to get it.

Bottle: very dense. Not a great head or lace. The aroma on this is just concentrated. It intense, dense and black. Spice, coffee, chocolate, inky, fresh, cream and clean. Dry to off dry, not sour and moderate bitterness. The flavor is massive. This thing is just concentrated and brooding. Huge flavor but balanced. Chocolate ice cream, cocoa powder. Long and fine. 
Don¬ít fight this thing. It¬ís a beast. 
It¬ís not a palate wrecker like the DIPA¬ís but it will put you to sleep.

Pours black with a creamy tan head. Aroma is subtle and reminds of toffee and chocolate. Flavor is on the opposite end - full and varied - with chocolate, roasted coffee, and a distinct hint of bourbon. Finish is long lasting. With flavors this overwhelming, this is not a balanced brew but is very good nevertheless.

Bottle, $14.99 2014 edition. Intend to age some of this for a year or a few, but I picked up an extra to drink fresh since I haven¬ít had this before. Dark black pour; creamy brown head dissipates into a nearly nonexistent ring; light lacing. Flavor coffee, strong cacao bitterness, caramel, light vanilla; lingering, sharply bitter finish . Once this warms, the aroma is fantastic, with every inhale different: chocolate, bourbon, licorice, tobacco, caramel, roast, bubble gum, finishing oak and vanilla. A+ body: full, slick, oily; frothy in the mouth, yet not sugary sticky. I¬ím torn because there are beers this good for less money, but this is really good.

Very strong on the palate and an overpowering bourbon flavor. balance is a little off and seems very much up the alley of whiskey drinkers.
must be sipped and cannot be drank as a pint

Look: pours a dark black. Dark brown head. Very thick lacing. 
Smell: chocolate. Red wine. Molasses. Black licorice. 
Taste: chocolate. Cherries. Sweet fruit. Molasses. 
Feel: thick mouthfeel. Very creamy. Medium low carbonation. 
Overall: great beer. Great smoothness. Not overwhelming in any one flavor. Very balanced.
First drank: home 2/15/15
Vintage: 2014
22 oz bottle, pours black, brown head. Aroma of fruit, bourbon , molasses. Taste of roasted malts, licorice. Very boozy. I thought I would really enjoy this, but it just didn¬ít work for me.

If I didn¬ít know it was a drink I¬íd think I was pouring a glass of chocolate syrup. Deep black with a frothy dark brown head. Aroma of chocolate, cherry, coffee, vanilla. It struck me at first with an unexpected sharp tanginess and strong alcoholic flavor which is probably the bourbon. Other flavors include chocolate, coffee and licorice. Heavy bodied and syrupy mouthfeel.

Bottle at home. Pours blackish brown with deep coffee colored dense head. Nose of figs, earthy roots, licorice and oak. Molasses and coffee roasted acidity along with oak, raisins and more barrel notes on the palate. 2014 version so going to lay down another bottle but this has the makings of a complex beast to sip for years

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

draft that poured black as midnight with small dark head. deep roasted malts with the subtle sweetness of the sugars of the molasses and definite licorice root. all mild to the nose...the flavor was so much more of the same strong in some respects but very well blended together. I know this beer will age nicely. there is a mild alcohol burn on the back end but what happens before that is very very delicious.
On draft. Black with brown one finger head. Bourbon and roasted malt aroma. The taste is similar. Such a smooth beer that hides the alcohol well. One of my favorites.
Pretty good. A bit too much bourbon flavor for my taste. Other than that a very well brewed beer that is complex and hearty.

22oz bottle. 2013 vintage. Pours dark black. Aroma of molasses, wood, raisin, peat, earth, vanilla, cinnamon. Flavor of cocoa, molasses, licorice, wood, peat, leather. Very bold, but not overwhelming.

Deep brown/black pour. Great aroma of rye, brown sugar, oats, lots of smokey wood, dark sour fruit. Soft carbonation, fluffy carbonation in the mouth feel, carbony bitter dry finish. Taste has strong burnt mesquite wood flavor , molasses, strong smokey bourbon, oats, plum/raisin/bit of currant, chocolate and oak. Really great BBA stout with tons of scotch qualities.

2010 bomber shared. Black, small frothy tan head. Big molasses on nose, great oakiness - surprised so much barrel in there - chocolate and bourbon. Incredible taste, deep roastiness, big chocolate, bourbon and big oak. Rich stuff here, maxed out by more molasses. Medium/full body. Well rounded. Fabulous stuff.
Nice Dark color with a great aroma. Very drinkable and smooth on the palate.

Bottle shared by Damian and Lona. Pours an opaque dark black with a thin layer of toffee colored head. Taste of roasted malts, lingering vanilla, and wood. Aroma of booze, roasted malts, and licorice.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2015 Black pour from draft at JP Burkes - tan fluffy head. Nutty and maybe cherry aroma to it. Big bold cocoa and fruit taste. Can¬ít tell what all is going on here but it is delicious
Bomber shared with pals at brian tasting in chicago. ..pitch black surpy.goodness...great!

2014 edition. 
11.10.15 best after date.
Poured from a bomber into a tulip on 11.25.14.

A: I can smell it after popping the waxed cap. Licorice, deep milk chocolate, truffle, strong molasses, vanilla, and cocoa. Wow. This is so complex and unlike anything. It¬ís all blended so perfectly. The aromas aren¬ít muted either as they mix.

A: 1 finger light brown head that is retained fluffy and beautiful. Midnight black body with no red.

T: Oak, cherry, and molasses dominate. Vanilla, truffle, and milk chocolate are more subtle but still strong.

P: Creamy smooth. This isn¬ít as bubbly as other BBA stouts, which I like. It has perfect carbonation.

O: Oak is first, then molasses, slight vanilla, truffle, and chocolate in the middle. The tart finish comes out as cherry (from the cherry bark) and balances the sweetness along with the oak at the start. It does have amazing depth. I expected to get a lot of vanilla but this goes a different way. Oak wasn¬ít there in the smell but it comes out from the depths and asserts itself in the taste. Every sip seems different. Oak eventually fades to vanilla after dominating for awhile, but the middle and back end remain the same. As big as the flavors are, they¬íre not overdone. The balance is incredible. What an experience.
Bomber thanks to respertFTW. Cloudy brown with a dark head. Grapes, wood and alcohol. Chocolatey and plums with a smokey malt.

Bottle 2013 vintage. The pour is black with nice lacing. The aroma is heavy malt and molasses. The taste is bold and roasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Malty aroma: Raisin, sweet, toffee, chocolate roast. Sweet, dark fruit, apple-ish flavor. Some molasses. Spicy, and subtle alcohol. Nice dry coffee-like roasted aftertaste. (2013 reserve; drank 1/4/15)

Stumbled upon this one on tap at a place in Santa Rosa. Overall a well balanced and very drinkable 11% imperial stout. I think the molasses stands out a little more than in other imperial stouts that I have had. The best beer I¬íve had in a while.

bottle 2013---very roasted malty, licorice, molassessoy, bourbon, wood, chocolate, and a dash of dark fruit and vanilla leading to a very dry long lasting coffee and hoppy finish. Very smooth...very nice.

Bomber bottle, 2013 release. Aroma is dark malt and some booze. Hint of bourbon and sweetness. Appearance is black with a little tan lacing. Taste is dark malt up from that has a bourbon booze hint of sweetness that then finishes with a very raw chocolate malt flavor that borders burnt popcorn, but not quite. Palate is dark malt bitter. Overall, an excellent beer. Plays the line between far enough and too far excellently.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2014 bottle. black with small brown head. big, robust and roasty with a fruity red wine note. flavor has more of the vanilla sweetness and oak character over the wine. full body and silky. toast, mild caramel sweetness and charred wood.

Bomber, 2007 vintage. Wonderful aroma of chocolate, some toast, licorice, molasses and bourbon. Pours inky black with a thin mocha brown head and excellent lacing. Starts with a silky smooth body with licorice and molasses flavors. Finishes extremely smooth with chocolate, vanilla, oak and bourbon. Absolutely delightful.

Bottle, courtesy of a kind soul... shared in a location remote of my dining room.
Pours basically black with a good head and nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is licorice, chocolate, vanilla and lots of roast. It¬ís decently sweet smelling but balanced. 

The flavor is very roasty with plenty of espresso, some licorice and a good bitterness. the sweetness is fairly well controlled albeit a big part of the beer. 

I¬íve wanted to try this for ages, cool.
2013 bomber from ck1, Cellar aged 13 months. Shared by all in Austin¬ís honor. Yum! Choco-caramel and smooooooth. Best of the night, or many nights. 17

First off let me say that this beer needs to be held onto for at least a year before you open it. I am more than certain that this beer would have been perfect a year from now, not that it wasn¬ít darn near perfection. The aroma was absolute heaven, roasted malts, coffee, oak and vanilla. The taste was very complex, with notes of caramel, chocolate, hints of bourbon, spices, vanilla, oak and cinnamon. The finish was surprisingly sweet and I wanted more. It did need to mature a bit.

Bottle at a tasting at Butler's place. Ben brought this one. Pours dark brown to black with a thin tan head. Aroma is slight dark fruit vanilla lots of dark chocolate. Flavor follows. Dark sweet chocolate. Some smoke. Fairly sweet. Really nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Market of Choice, Eugene. 2013 Vintage. Pours a deep, dark brown/black, not much head. Aroma sweet, candi sugar, molasses, vanilla. Body punchy and oaky, very complex, can really taste oak, wine, Bourbon, before a generally tannic licorice note winds things up. Even though I¬íve lived in Oregon for years and had plenty of Abyss, I have really appreciated drinking this critically, a great beer.

Bottle from 2009. Pours dark, completely black in the glass, with a thin khaki head, very fine lacing, decent retention. Aromas of oak, molasses, leather, tart cherry, chocolate, and hay. Full body, moderate carbonation, lightly dry. Mildly sweet, just a hint of citrus, with a lasting medium-strong bitter finish and just a little alcohol heat.

Rating from September 2010....Dark as night without moon....rich roasted malt with chocolate baking cocoa....wow...dark ass malt...coffee for certain...bakers cocoa/dark chocolate....shines strongly and lingers on the palate....the licorice is subtle to my taste...but I do get it....not a licorice fan, but presented in this beer, its ok by me--bitter finish--goes down easy for 11%....just good!...well crafted and quite an experience for my senses
Bottle @ Home. 2013 Vintage. Great smooth mouth. A nice oakiness, vanilla, bourbon, molasses, and brown sugar. Does a great job hiding it¬ís ABV. Finishes on the sweet size.
Wow, my first time for an aged beer - 2011. Strong, thick, dark, flavorful. Very high alcohol. Smooth, and definitely better as it warms

UPDATED: APR 7, 2017 Alright, it¬ís about time I finally sit down and rate this. I wanted to find this on draft for a while, and had the worst of luck, until now. Poured into a growler. Pours a thick black with a dark brown head. Toasty, slightly boozy oak front aroma. Rich flavor with a huge roasted finish. Picking up some of the sweet licorice flavor as well. Decently smooth oak and chocolate finish. I don¬ít know. This beer is great, I enjoy it as a sipper. Not quite the beer I run out of my way to track it down, but if it falls to me again, I will gladly give this beer another go. Sum this beer up in one word? I¬íd say solid.  UPDATE:  2007 bottle opened during a blind tasting.  Thanks to Jansen for bringing this one.  Had to add additional notes due to the amount of smokiness this had.  So smokey, it left everything I thought I knew about Abyss long behind.  Roasted malt heavy, smooth chocolate.  I think I like this smokey Abyss even better, if that¬ís what it¬ís going to be.  Fun beer here, and though not my favorite beer of it¬ís type, I¬íll never tire of trying the different vintages, and comparing them in my head.  Still solid, after all these days.

Great beer. Love the favors involved in this beer. 

Jskxkxkdkdjdjdjdjdjsbsbbsbsbsbsbsbbsbsbsbbsbsbsb via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with khaki head. Chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, vanilla, wood and soy sauce aroma. Chocolate, roasted malt, soy sauce, licorice, coffee, vanilla and molasses flavors. Full body and moderate carbonation. Chocolate, roasted malt and molasses finish. 13, 14
Draft at Bricks. Pours dark brown with chocolate milk head and rings of lacing. Nose is chocolate and tobacco. Taste is chocolate, liquorice, tart vineous taste. Lasting bitterness in the aftertaste.

A nice, smooth, medium-full bodied Imperial Stout. Nice sweet oakiness, bitter chocolate, faint leafy hops, molasses and some Sambuca anise round it out. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Molasses, prunes, cocoa, roastiness. Black with a dark tan head. Dark fruity sweet. Cocoa. Vanilla. Molasses. Bitter roasty finish. Boozey warmth.

One of the smoothest bourbon battered beers I have ever had. Not overly sweet and heavy. Slightly chocolatey and coffe. Pours black with a tan head. Incredible beer 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2014 Bottle. Pours dark opaque black with large, fluffy, medium brown colored head that sits there like chocolate mouse before it diminishes to a small covering. Aroma has sharp vinous, bourbon notes at first with smooth caramel mocha behind it. Flavor has huge cocoa, coffee malts, balanced with a light bitter bite. Subtle bourbon is evident in the finish & aftertaste, but just enough to round it out and not too intense. Slightly oily mouthfeel, bubbly. Pretty pricey at $15/22oz though.

Purchases 2 bottles of the 2014. Opened the one and saving the other for next year. 

Pours black with tan head. Smell is roasted malt, chocolate, anise. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, licorice, tobacco, molasses and smoked wood. Heavy body, light carbonation.

Draft at Good Dog. Pitch black pour with a tight creamy brown head. Good amount of lace. Thick, rich and dark. Big cocoa, coffee and liquorice flavors. Additional notes of tobacco, molasses, peppercorns, black leather and charcoal grill. Feels a bit boozy up front but has such an abundance of wood tannins such that it finishes smooth and dry. Gigantic and fantastic!
2011 bottle, huge thanks to northropfrye. Aroma is roasty, chocolate covered cherries. Flavour is chocolate, cocoa, cherries, slightly boozy, a touch of coffee. Wow, this is a treat.
Jet black. Dark frothy head. Burnt coffee beans, anise, vanilla, marshmallows. Earthy hops, oak. Mild bourbon notes. Extremely balanced for being such a big, full bodied brew. Epic !
On tap at the Heimat House. 2014 variety was black as night with a sweet liquorice and molasses finish. At 11% ABV you barley notice it. Incredible beer.

2011 on draft at Aces and Ales in Las Vegas. Small 3oz flight pour. Pours an opaque nearly black thickness with a very lasting mocha head. Aroma is a combination of anise, coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts, and Brazil nuts. The taste is incredible with dark chocolate, anise, roasted nuts, coffee, and wood barrels. Somewhat booze finish, but not overdone. Medium full body, well carbed. Very good.
Black thick pour with a small thick head. Wood smoke aroma. Very bitter taste. Hints of molasses and burnt marshmellows. It¬ís ok.

Tap at Busters. The 2011 variety. Snifter glass. Deep black color with frothy head. Intimidating appearance. Aroma has chocolate elements and a freshness not expected. Some roasted malt notes too. Reminds me of the really good chocolate influenced stouts. The bitterness is well hidden...sweetness takes center stage. Incredibly smooth and rich. Nice finish...with warming alcohol presence. Stronger alcohol due to the aging...definitely appreciated. Enjoyable option.

Pours a deep dark chocolate head. Loads of chocolate, licorice, star anise, and a good amount of molasses. The barrels it was aged in are noticeable but not so apparently and is really well hidden. Love it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013 bottle. Jet black pour with a tan head. Wow there is so much going on here it¬ís unbelievable. Bourbon, molasses, wine, and notes of
Licorice. Flavor is a wonderful blend of everything that is going on in the aroma. No one Flavor dominates the others, it¬ís perfectly balanced. A true work of art. Thanks Lectvay for the bottle!

Big frothy bubbly tan head dark pour near medium carbonation aromas chocolate molasses vanilla rich fruit woody notes the flavours wow! the sweetness really hits you just a mix of goodness alcohol liquorice molasses caramel dark chocolate vanilla creamy note plum raisins the oak wine really good on the palate and the cherry bark giving a bitter taste nutty as well good balance the oak barrelling smoothly done really good note a simply superb bit of brewing by the people at Deschutes the cherry bark fits in so well with the sweet tastes flavours outdo the alcohol volume easily the finish this is a beautiful imperial best notes cherry bark sweet malts oak wine barrelling influence body and balance superb sweetness magical imperial all round
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee and chocolate. Taste is strong coffee, very bitter. Way too much, needs pulling back. Not that good.

Bottle, 2011 vintage, thnx to Duffman for sending me this. Pours a pitch black beer with a big, tanned head on top consisting out of small bubbles. Aroma is incredibly full, loads of molasses, vanilla, caramel, chocolate, coffee. Flavor has loads of wood, loads of sweet stuff, licorice and coffee with chocolate in the finish. Very much complexity going on here, very full bodied with low carbonation. This is amazing stuff, definitely worth it¬ís top 50 status.

Pours black, thick, with a dark tan head.
Nose shows soft woody oak, faint red wine notes, heacy roast, some sweet rich molassess, chocolate and toasty/bready malt.
Bittersweet flavours with lots of roast countered by molasses sweetness. Some booze along with a little vanilla oak notes and a hint of bourbon. More red wine too. Very well-balanced.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2016 2009 Bottle shared at Darkness day. Infected bottle. Some barrel smokey smell. Taste smokey and sour (unintentionally I?m sure). Okay...would like to try again.
2010 bottle shared at tasting. Re-rating. Dark brown pour. Nice barrel and boozy aroma. So much better than previous. Very dense and rich. Really good.

September 25, 2014. Bottle at SBWF, 2013 vintage. Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma is sweet licorice, chocolate, coffee, wood. Taste is medium sweet chocolate and licorice, light dry roasted and woody bitterness. Finish is dry woody,roasted bitterness and sweet licorice. Medium bodied, soft carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2014 600ml bottle served in a snifter glass.
2009 Reserve edition. Best after: 11/1/2010 printed in the left side of the label.
A: Pours a deep brown to black color forming a absolutely beautiful creamy and thin bubbled beige to brow head. Multi tonalities of brown lacings are formed on the top. Excellent retention and only small spotty lacings left in the glass. A thin layer remains forever on the top
S: Very sweet and malty upfront. Strong notes of wood, dark chocolate and coffee. Strong notes of dark fruits, mix of grapes, raisins and figs, mainly. Licorice and caramel. Roasted malts and a some notes of alcohol in the end
T: Perfect taste. Sweet upfront with strong notes of coffee, dark chocolate, licorice, roasted malts, caramel, caramel malts, oak, grapes, raisins, figs, smoked malts... End is bitter but not extremely. Bitterness is mainly made of roasted malts than hops
M: Heavy body. Creamy and molasses. Medium to low carbonation. Roasted malts bitter aftertaste
O: Excellent drinkability. A perfect beer is hard to judge
[ BA Review @ 2/17/2013 ]

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2014 2012 bottling.
Pours black with a espresso coloured head.
Aroma has lots of bourbon, chocolate pudding, liquorice and sweetness.
Taste has chocolate, bourbon, liquorice, soy, sweetness and a nice bitterness at the end.
Almost full bodied, low carbonation, soft and round mouth feel.
Very easy to drink, perhaps a wee bit to heavy on the bourbon. Still, very good.

Pretty nice coffee stout Julie says cream guey oiliness. Julie gives 4.5.

650 ml bottle. I¬íve been waiting this for so long. Pours a black colour with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, biscuit and coffee. Flavour of rich roasted malts, coffee, biscuit, dark chocolate, some mild spiciness, wood, smooth bourbon notes, salty licorice and complex earthiness.Full bodied and oily mouthfeel. Barrel accompanies the flavour very nicely. Brilliant balance. It seems that this ages very well and it gets very smooth. It¬í salty, it¬ís sweet, it¬ís roasty, it¬ís full of chocolate. Excellent balance. I¬íd love to taste this when it¬ís fresh as it¬ís probably very different. Brilliant stuff, I must say.

@ SBWF 2014: fantastisk br√§nda toner. Trevlig smak av kaffe, choklad och chili. Mycket gott.

Sample at SBWF 2014. Malty smell with dark chocolate and coffee. Similar taste with roasted malts. Very nice. Complex. Allot of flavour.

Pours jet black with a beige head. Thick, rich and creamy texture. Liquorice, roasted malt, chocolate and coffee aromas and taste. Perfectly balanced with a slight, warming alcohol finish. Just excellent.

Very nice indeed. Pours black with a tan head. The aroma is lovely with chocolate, sweet malt, a hint of licorice and caramel. The flavor is similar with everything coming together quite well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle cheers to Andrew and Beau. The nose on this is super complex. I was expecting bourbon over load but the cherry and wine tart focus in this is superb. Tarty dark chocolate and very woody stuff. The bourbon adds a vanilla element but that¬ís overshadowed by the dark cherries and mild tart throughout. Kind of tannin like. Liquorice is definitely in your face. Complexity is there but not quite the finesse of everything coming together. Still very good
This is simply the best Imperial Stout I ever tasted. On tap at Deschutes tasting room after skiing or from bottle in BrewHouse. Also growler fill at GrowlerGuys, Bend, OR

Pours an opaque black with a big tan head that leaves a lot of lacing. Wonderful aromas and flavors of licorice, cherry, chocolate, smoked nuts and just a hint of bourbon/alcohol. Full bodied and silky smooth. Awesome beer.

2013 bottle. Black with a tan head that fades but laces very well. Intense roasted malt aroma with mocha, licorice, dark berries, molasses, oak. Oily, lowish carbonation, quite silky. Lots of bittersweet chocolate, roast is fairly heavy but not as full on as suggested by the smell. Berries have a touch of sourness about them. Bourbon notes peek out but beer is _just_ about driving the show, although the fruit and barrel treatments gain prominence after a while. Bitter and quite oaky at the end. A slow drinker but not overly boozy. Excellent - just lacks a bit of inviting softness and seems slightly contrived. But excellent. Best after today apparently, so mayhap there¬ís a timezone issue.

Pours completely opaque black with a dark tan head good lacing. Aroma of cherry, dark chocolate, licorice, umami, nuts and an ashy roastiness. Taste of molasses, dark chocolate, cherry, leather, a nuttiness, oak, vanilla and an ashy char. Finishes dry with a roasty bitterness. Mouthfeel is oily with a light/ medium body and low carbonation. An excellent stout with so much flavor.

2014 bottle. Jet black with a cinnamon brown head. Aroma is cherry, vanilla, tobacco, licorice. Taste has the same with molasses, oak, leather, ash. and roast. A light, slick mouthfeel.

this one was a little thinner on the palate than i thought it was going to be. nice but not seeing what the fuss is for.
Had this at a fantastic tasting and had such a great time with great people and great beers!

bottle, shared at Blue Monk. Fuller bodied black pour. dark chocolate, heavy roast, oak, bourbon notes. Black licorice. complex, delicious

Bottle at Beechner Blind Beer Bash. This one seemed to be a little more fruit forward than I was imagining it would be. Notes of cherry dominated the nose with a subtle chocolate background with some vanilla. Taste was just as fruity with a light stickiness and sweetness, but never evolved into much chocolate. Overall enjoyable, but something just seemed a bit too fruity.

A smooth, dark khaki head falls to a resilient cap with several mounds of large bubbles over a black body with minuscule fiery amber highlights

Aromas bring to mind some of the negative components of aged american imperial stout with all the burly, sour dark notes I¬íve grown to recognize from the style at this age. The molasses and cherry bark are holding the back end together to offer a sweet cream and chocolate finish, but this is generally bad. Citrus rind and charred solvents balanced by oak barrels on a creamy, silky smooth, coating medium plus body.

I held onto about 4oz of 2013 Boulevard Imperial Stout to compare the more blended versions of this barrel aged imperial stout tasting. Good lord, the Boulevard tastes like chocolate cherry whiskey compared to this $15 bomber of let down. One of the most overrated beers I¬íve ever had. 

The problem I have with all aged hoppy stouts is the intensely harsh, overly abrasive citrus bitterness moving directly into coffee and dark chocolate with almost no blending agent. This dynamic makes for poor flavor, bringing aromas of cow shit to mind (having grown up around a cow farm).

22oz bottle of 2012 reserve served at 58¬∫ and warming into an Orrefors Difference Porter snifter
2010 bottle. Oily pitch black colour, dark brown foam. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts with sweet notes from chocolate and molasses. Very good but I was expecting more, maybe too old?

Bottle at RBSG 2014. Thx to everyone for sharing today¬ís bottles!
APPEARANCE: clear brown beer, smal unstable beige head.
NOSE: hoppy, light sour, fruity, chocolate.
TASTE: hoppy, chocolate, coffee, sweet, little sour.

Part of a four year vertical. Big thanks to phatdog1 for putting this together!! For the sake of this review I am only reviewing the 2013. With a best after date of 08/16/14. Pitch black color with lasting mocha colored head. Aroma of licorice, coffee, and ash.  
Flavor is really damn nice. Well hidden all goal under coffee, molasses, tobacco leaves and having a lingering licorice finish. After 3 oz. I also picked out a berry hint with oak. Oak is a light note as well as a light red wine hint. Body is creamy and full and what I look for in an imperial stout. Unreal stout that¬ís gets better with age, exceptional with a little bit of age. A year and half age is about peak. Fantastic

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2016 shared a 2012 bomber with 2 friends. poured dark black with a nice small mocha coloured head. a lot of dark roasted malts, dark bitter chocolate, vanilla, fruits, hints of bourbon, licorice notice. 

wow this is not your every day stout. very unique! what a complex taste, ton of roasted malts combined with dark chocolate, bitter espresso beans, vanilla, dark fruits, bourbon tones, ash, tobacco, caramel, after the first powerfull layer you can taste the wine barrels at the aftertaste. full bodied creamy mouthfeel. with some warm hints of the alcohol. 

very unique beer! loved it!

22oz bottle (2013 reserve) with a best after date of 8/16/2014.


Appearance: Black and opaque with a tan head. Pours thick out of the bottle.


Aroma: Chocolate, coffee, vanilla, roasted malt, molasses, licorice, oak, figs, raisins, tobacco and a little wine character.


Taste: Dark chocolate, silky vanilla, black coffee, sweet molasses, figs, some bourbon, licorice and a little smokiness.


Palate: Medium-full bodied, very smooth, light carbonation and finishes with dark chocolate.


Overall: Great imperial stout. The licorice and wine comes out as the beer warms and provides a character rare in other stouts. Fantastic beer all around.

On tap. Pours jet black with some good lacing. Aroma is bourbon, roast, chocolate, licorice. Taste is sweet bitterness with chocolate, molasses, coffee, bourbon and oak flavor. Really enjoying 2013 abyss.
Very dark brown pour, brown head. Wonderful aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and smoked meat. Amazing huge flavor: chocolate, quite roasty with a hint of smoke. Super smooth. Absolutely fantastic.
Many thanks for this bottle to kappldav123. Black pour with tan head. Vanilla, chocolate, an array of barrel tones, sweet and smooth.

2011 version, sampled at Brau 2012.
Dark and milk chocolate, fig, light orangepeel aroma. 
Black hole, low brown head 
Smoky dark roast, choc, orangepeel, demera sweetness 
Full and sticky. 
Nourishing

22oz bottle = 2012 vintage - pours black with dark mocha head. Strong aromas of vanilla , bourbon, licorice , molasses, figs, raisins, just a lot going on here. The taste gets even more complex, all of the above with some added sweetness , exactly as advertised ... molasses and licorice. Very complex brew... I will enjoy every ounce of it .

Small sample from bottle @ Zeebra II. Pours pitch black with a small tan head. Aroma has quite some dark chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Taste has chocolate, quite some coffee, roasted malts, bourbon, some licorice and a medium bitter finish. Over medium body and medium carbo. Nice stuff.

2010 vintage. Pours a dark black, minimal mocha colored head, minimal lacing. Aromas of rich malted cocoa, black licorice, dry oak and a slight amount of bourbon. Taste was very rich, but very balanced. Distinct flavors of licorice/anise, tobacco and leather that counterbalance a rather sticky body, loaded with molasses. Finishes nicely with a harmony of the barrels providing one final kick of oak and bourbon.

22 oz bottle. 2011 variety. The pour is jet black with a thin film of dark mocha head that fades to a small ring and no lacing. The aroma is mostly roasted malt licorice with a light bourbon presence and minimal vanilla tendencies. The flavor is a touch boozy with a solid licorice and roasted malt base. There is again a little bit of vanilla and a light cocoa presence which helps. The mouth feel is a little light, but the carbonation helps a velvety complexion and lingeringly dry mouthfeel that is definitely a little bitter like a good stout should be. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark black with a little light head. Big fig leather and tobacco smells. Bitter woody big with some viscosity to it. Rich layered. Sip it slow, let it linger, Start cool but let it warm up Flavors grow and change. Amazing.

I bought three bottles back in December of 2013. I cracked one open in February but forgot to mention anything about this back then.
Today, I¬ím having my second bottle that has a date of "best after 08/16/14."
I poured this into a snifter, here we go.
The appearance, well, it poured like motor oil and I even heard the "glub glub" sound as it strolls out of the bottle, (did I pour too fast, hmmm...most likely not?). The head is about a finger¬ís worth of off-white to a nice tan color that lasts for a good minute before dieing and leaving a super nice coating of tan lacing clinging very nicely to the glass.
The smell is an almost perfect aroma to any imperial stout anyone could ever want. It goes a little something like this: super nice oaky/woody vanilla, cherry, chocolate, molassess and licorice. There is a slight aftertaste and its kinda woody with a nice dose of lingering molasses and vanilla. The finish is quick, dry and sweet.
On the palate, it sat about a medium to heavy. I sure did sip this. This is one not to gulp. Sessionability - ha, no way, man, one and done. ABV is felt. The carbonation is smooth and good for the style and for me.
Overall, American Double/Imperial Stout, wow, this practically defines it. Don¬ít ever pass up on this if you ever see it. I will be sure to look out for this next December when it comes out.

A tremendous opaque black pour w/ a stunning mocha head that leaves 3 beautiful rings of lacing. The aroma is as advertised with a concoction of licorice, molasses, some of the bourbon flavors, & slightly boozy. The taste while complex & certainly rich, is just a tad bitter & harsh at the finish to be perfect. Don¬ít get me wrong, this is one hell of a beer. It¬ís an imperial to umteenth degree & w/ so much going on, it all comes together nicely. It¬ís a must try even at $15 a pop!

Bottle is vintage 2009.  Pours a pitch black color with lasting coffee head and lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, sweet toffee, bitter chocolate, and bourbon notes.  Flavor is massive: bourbon, licorice, char and a dry finish.  Wow.  From notes 2/15/10.
Backnote, had this beer at the zeebra extreem beer festival 2014. superb beer, but rather thin for an imp stout
22 oz bottle. Pours a pitch black colour with small brown head. Aroma is sweet, licorice, chocolate and alcohol. Flavor is licorice, coffee, chocolate, with a bitter warming alcohol finish.
Solid imperial stout. Has al the traits of the style, but doesn¬ít trascend above the rest in my opinion.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2015 Sampled @ Zeebra 2014. Coffee. Vanilla-like taste comparable to Hunapuh (Cigar City) but then more bitter, toffee-like, coffee as well. Sweet vanilla, fudge, noga smell.

Edit: rated slightly higher after drinking a 2013 bottle at Thijs¬í place 20-12-15
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2015 Mooie zwarte kleur met een goede bruine kraag. Ruikt koffie, vanille en chocolade. Iets gebrand. Smaakt vanille, gebrand, koffie. Goede bittere nasmaak.
UPDATED: FEB 14, 2016 Pours a pitch black beer with a good tan brown head. Smells rye, coffee, chocolate. Tastes lots of coffee, coffee bitter, roasted. Low carbo, medium body and a sticky texture.

2013 bottle. Pours a nice black color with off-white head. Roasted malt, cocoa, oak, and bourbon on the nose; follows onto the palate, very complex. The alcohol is a little hot fresh. Finishes with a molasses sweetness, and just a bit of anise. Should age very well.

2010 version. Perfect looking, pitch oil black with dark brown head. Loads of coffee, roast and molasses in the aroma, tiny oak and bourbon hints. This is a beer that goes on for layers and layers of velvet. Extremely balanced and subtle for the style. Bourbon is tingling as is the heat. This is excellent stuff! Thanks Duffman!
2013 version on tap at the Red Cow. Black with a big foamy light brown head. Chocolate, raisins, molasses and smoke. Taste is raising sweet with a chapters finish. Body was full with a foamy feel.

Pours very dark deep. Clearly given the name. A big bourbon and dark fruit color that rolls right into the aroma. Flavors match the nose. Caramel and syrup spice mix in with the bourbon flavors. I really would like to try it again. Good stuff.

2010 vintage. Shared with EricTeusink. This bottle is from my very first RB trade. Been holding onto this bad boy, getting advice on when to pop. The result was an extremely mellowed out brew, that did show a hint of age, but it was not a detractor. Thick black pour with ample dark mocha head. The taste showed mellow bourbon that was nicely intergrated with the molasses, and the licorice was just barely a character. Dark fruits swirled with a heavy dose of dark chocolate. Decadent. I would advice on drinking now.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2015 2013 vintage bottle at Northern Taproom, Chicago. Black black oily with big foam head. Aroma is licorice and booze. Taste is very complex and chaotic - vanilla, aniseed, heavy body (oak?), tobacco, leather. Lots of dark flavours with a strong abv in the mix. Bitter finish, tannins and syrupy. Overall, this one is too much for me. Astringently serious. Not so much fun to drink. Functions like a lecture on beer.
New bottle 2013 vintage new years 2014: aroma 8 dark cherries and red wine, taste 8 dark chocolate cherries rise out as it warms, overall 15 still needs more age but better now than 6 months ago.
Bottle pours black with big tan head. Aroma is roast with licorice. Taste is big thick roast with a slight sweet alcohol finish.
Great brew with strong oak on the nose and in the taste. I recommend aging this beer to soften it. It is complex and lovely. Drink it.

22oz bottle (2012 vintage) pours dark black brown with 2 finger tan head. Nose is rich earthy dark fruits, roasty coffee, dark chocolate, oak, subtle wine. Taste is creamy rich bitter chocolate, bourbon, licorice, plum, faint berries, wood, cream. Finish is bitter roasty malt, hershey bar, dark fruits, bourbon. Decadent and delicious.
Aromas of vanilla, licorice and booze. Taste follows nose with a hint of molasses. Slick mouthfeel with good carbonation. Very good.

2010 reserve.
Oil black body, light brown head that is gone fast.
Aroma has lots of going on: wine, bourbon, chocolate, liqourice, plum, more sweet bourbon and some tobacco. There is very light almost no taste at all in the beginning, but it grows fast. The tobacco, bourbon and some roasted grainy malts come aftewards. Very velvety and smooth. Rich ashy and alcohol is felt, not tasted. Flavour has less fruity and winey charasteristics than aroma. Very complex and quite extraordinary.

22 oz bottle. 2010 Reserve. Best after 11/15/11.
From a trade with Rosebud butternuts. Huge thanks to Eric! My rating #6000.
Pitch black colour with a tiny tan head. 
Roasted malt, lots of malty sweetness, molasses, mild alcohol, whiskey and red wine notes and mild chocolate in the aroma. 
The flavour is... quite incredible. Roasted malt, dryness, sweetness, molasses, alcohol, mild smoke, whiskey, bitterness and sugary sweetness to name a few flavours. 
Amazing richness and smoothness. Warms nicely. 11% is present in a very positive way. Pleasant.

2011 version on tap at Urge. Pours a pitch black with a one finger khaki head with nice lacing. Aroma is of roasted malts, licorice, molasses, coffee, bakers coco, dark fruits, some oaked whiskey, and some faint booze. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma but is even smoother and has almost no noticeable booze. Has a full body with a oily, creamy mouthfeel, and a moderately bitter, long, lingering finish. Overall, a fantastic world class stout that is very complex and amazingly smooth after three years of being aged.
Tap, pours black with a tan head. Sweet tasting with chocolate, vanilla, and molasses. The Bourbon is noticeable but not overpowering. Nicely balanced and very tasty.

2012 vintage on draft. Amazing bourbon and oak taste up front with a tobacco dry earthy and spicy aftertaste. Amazingly smooth and drinkable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2014 The aroma blends roasted, chocolate, and caramel malts with molasses and a hint of bourbon, and the appearance has an opaque black color with a large tan head. The taste is a phenomenal blend of a heavy umami, slight bitterness, and a touch of sweetness, and the palate fuses a slick and thick texture, full body, robust and roasty finish, and a soft carbonation.

Chocolately nutty aromas with a hint of licorice come from this very dark brown thick beer with a nice tan head. Taste the alcohol and chocolate with hint of bitterness at first. The charred flavor comes in with a hint of cherries. Then a bitter aftertaste. Its a very fullbodied beer with good carb.

Dark thick pour with a smattering of khaki head. Smells of cherry, chocolate, malty. Tastes of dark chocolate, very malty, vanilla, a good amount of bitter maltiness, cherry, smooth sweet coffee at the end, cigarette ash, char, bready. A slick mouthfeel with a semi hot alcohol. A very good stout, lot of malty bitterness, chocolate covered cherry. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The absolute best Imperial Stout that I have tried. Even better when put in the cellar for a year.  Deschutes and Stone are the top breweries that I have tried.

This is a review of the Abyss 2008 vintage that I was lucky enough to get a couple bottles of after a brewmasters dinner I did with Cam O'Connor the brewmaster of Deschutes. The 5 years of aging have done wonders for this beer. It is incredibly smooth and unbelievably delicious. I highly recommend aging any more recent incarnations(if you can wait!) to see how it develops. Amazingly chocolately, roasty, smooth, the alcohol has been completely mellowed out, you would never know it was 11%.

Black pour with an espresso head. Very bitter at first, like sucking on an ashy piece of barley. There is some sweetness in here too that tones down the roast. This just bashes you in the face with roasted barley. Aroma has some raisin along with the taste. Hints of sugar, nuts, chocolate & caramel.

22oz bomber (2013) shared by Phil @ Crossroads Spirits. Big thanks Phil!! Pours a deep black color with absolutely no head. Aromas of licorice, bourbon, oak, roasted malt, and some smoke. Taste of bourbon, oak, caramel, roasted malt, and smoke. Some warming alcohol burn in the finish. Carbonation seemed to be lacking in this beer, but overall delicious.

2012 Bottle. Molasses, sweet chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit and alcohol aroma. Black brown with a moderate tan head. Burnt coffee, chocolate, vanilla flavor with a long roasty bitter finish. Body on the lighter side of full, soft carbonation, dry finish. Seems rather thin for the style.

2013 bottle. Pours straight black with minimal head. Aroma is molasses, raisin, dark chocolate, oak. Cherry flavor kicks in immediately with the blackstrap molasses adding sweet/sour notes. The barrel aging and blending adds a nice amount of alcohol heat but not overbearing. This one will sit nicely in the cellar.
2/13/2014. On tap. Pours black with a beige head. Thick, rich and creamy. Licorice, roasted malt, chocolate and coffee aromas. Very nice balance and complexity. Bitter finish... very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2015 On tap at Hay Merchant. 2012 edition. Pours very dark brown, dark tan head that slowly dissipates. Aroma is intensely complex: cocoa, dark chocolate, coffee, molasses, a slight bitter note. Taste is sweet up front, roasty, burnt in the middle, and mildly bitter at the back. There is the slightest of bourbon taste, and I like it that way. It doesn?t dominate the taste. It is slightly warm going down, though. Kind of a thick mouthfeel. Very smooth. Probably the best beer I?ve ever tasted.

2013 bottle generously shared at the RBWG grand tasting. Dark brown pour. Nose of dark chocolate and sambucca, a bit hot. Flavor is oak heavy with dark chocolate and sweet, sticky molasses in the finish. Not what I was hoping it was.

Wow did I want to start making love to this beer right when I was in the bar... Draught. Pours a gorgeous thick black color with a moderate darker tan head on it, and with nice lacing. Nose had just a little bit of bourbon that hits you up front. The strong roasting with just a hint of chocolate comes through the aroma afterwards. The taste is majestic - extremely smooth on the palate, and has a beautiful silky mix of roasting and chocolate, with just a hint of wood coming through.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2014 Pours opaque black. 
Both the aroma and flavor are amazingly complex yet balanced.. The complexity leads to different aspects of the brew coming forward in successive sniffs, with some featuring the wine barrel effects, another the BBL and yet another the dark roasted grains. Excellent sweet/bitter balance. 

Update: 2014 bottle shared in Dec. 2014: very, very rich - 4.1

Pour - black. No head

Aroma - hint of whiskey

Mouth - mild carb. Not as velvety or creamy as some. 

Taste - sweet wine like finish. Slight whiskey. Long finish. Little boozy. Would be better with age. 

Overall - excellent. One of my favorites.

Great. Roasted malt, some hops and molasses aromas. Maybe a little oak and bourbon as well. It had a lot going on. Very dark black color with a minimal tan head. This 2011 offering has blended well over the years with good carbonation and a smooth mouthfeel. Flavors were rich with a strong roasted bitterness that mixed with the hops. The lingering flavors were slightly sweet from bourbon and woody from the oak. This also had quite a kick.

Pours deep black, with a two-finger mahogany head. Licorice and oak on the nose. Bit of bourbon, smoke. Taste is coffee, a little wine, bourbon, vanilla, wood, smoke, burnt caramel. Lacing like rings on a prehistoric tree. Very nuanced beer. Mouthfeel is thick, viscous. Some hop bitterness, slightly sweet. Alcohol is well hidden, but creeps up quickly. This will end your night. And you¬íll like it.

Vertical of 07 08 10 11 12 at Sloshfest, thanks to Jeffo & Erik!
In general: all intensely coloured and full of the good stuff in terms of aroma and flavour; full roast, deep sugars and malt, nice oak components - not too much bourbon - thank you lord!
Liked the 2010 the most, followed by 2007, 2012 (still very fresh on the hops), 2011, 2008

2006 22oz bottle, batch 1 drunk Summer of ¬í09, at my Farewell to the beer scene tasting.Compact, creamy, charred-beige head is very persistently retained, and tops an opaque, deep ebony body with dark brown edges. Moderate sediment in the bottle after 3 years rest.A somewhat more subtle aroma for the style, not to be confused with a weak aroma, it¬ís just not pouring forth with either heavy amounts of vinousness, nor sweet chocolate/malts. Rather, it¬ís lightly smokey, with soft vanilla creaminess and some ashy roast notes. With warming, some barrel tannins emerge and mix with the light alcohol and roast, producing a liquorous-like warmth and complexity and rendering the nose quite dry. Long, dry black pepper and sweet bourbon lasts quite well.Somewhat alcoholic and a bit sharp on the initial sip, with chocolatey malts and sweet vanilla notes softening it some. Not as tight a carbonation as I was imagining, leaving it a little bit watery on the end and providing for only a medium body relative to style. What it does do right is provide an ashen, chocolatey and bourbon-like flavor that is quite interesting, very unique. Hints of pruney vinousness on the finish, with touches of raw, grainy wood (alcohol and barrel tannins). As it warms, the flavors come together a bit better, though the sweet malts never integrate fully, leaving the beer a bit disjointed, especially due to the somewhat light mouthfeel.

2010 vintage. A bottle from ¬íthe accident¬í. Time in the closet has given this an amazing smoothness. So complex. Licorice and roasted malts and coffee bitterness. A surreal experience. Very hard to open the bottle. Thanks C.

On tap. Deep deep beer. So many levels in this glass it's beyond a single review. I would have to spend a weekend deconstructing it and a thesis would follow. Well worth the price is about all I can say. Treat it like a fine scotch.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle shared during #bottlecherwednesday at Beachwood BBQ in Seal Beach. Poured into a tulip. This beer is black, black, black - opaque and unyielding. A two-finger brown head forms before collapsing to a film and leaves patches of lace in the process. More lace rings are deposited on the glass during the session. The aroma is as advertised, but deliciously so - roasted malt, unsweetened chocolate, molasses, oak, anise, coffee, and barrel notes of vanilla and bourbon. Taste opens up with roasted malt sweetness, molasses, coffee, anise, and vanilla. Some bitterness creeps through on the finish featuring oak, coffee grounds, a little citrus hop bite, keeping the surge of sweetness from washing out everything else. Only trace alcohol flavors come through, surprisingly. Quite full bodied, thick, creamy, silky slick texture, soft carbonation, drying and warming on the finish. Delicious.

On draft at independent ale house in rapid city it is a dark brown color with a slight head. The aroma is roasted coffee the taste is of licorice with an amazing roasted coffee flavor that resonated on the palate

I was fortunate enough to have a 2012 bottle and a 2013 draft within a week of each other. The bottle I got to share with some friends who were celebrating the closing of his liquor store, and the draft I got from my local bar. The 2012 was modestly superior. While I have noticed I enjoy bottled beer more than the draft version, the aging is what I feel made it taste better. If you find this gem, pick up at least two: one for now, and one for next year.

Draft - Vintage 2012 - Dark roast coffee, anise and dear fruit. Jet black with a persistent but small brown head. Rich bittersweet chocolate, some dark fruit and coffee. What makes this beer shine is the rich oily body.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2014 [Bottle / 2012 / 1 year old] Thanks, Kevin! Pours like an abyss (go figure)... Black, oily, & inky as hell with a super-deep tan head that froths up like a latte crema; long lasting, slowly receding. Aroma is full of creamy & roasty coffee beans - "nice" coffee... Some mild cream & sugar reminders with faint, back-end smoke. Lightly roasted malts, cocoa, & a small helping of black licorice. Flavor has lots of oily, roasted coffee beans, too, with a slight bitterness that¬ís balanced by a creamy sweetness. Bittersweet chocolate pounds hard with some roasted malts, molasses, & faint licorice in the finish. I had no idea this was "partially" barrel aged - there are NO barrel flavors or aromas in it. Good beer, but overrated? Didn¬ít blow me away like I expected. [Original Rating: 7-5-7-4-13; 3.6]
[Bottle / 2011 / 2+ years old] Thanks, Tim! Not sure if it¬ís the vintage or the age (or possibly a combination of both), but this bottle of Abyss was much more enjoyable for me. Looks as good as ever with heavier cocoa in the aroma & flavor, still with plenty of coffee. Light prunes & an underlying milky sweetness leading to a finish of creamy, lightly bitter coffee, roast, & milk chocolate. Again - just about no barrel, but the flavors were a lot more refined to me this time around. Still possibly overrated a touch, but still a very good beer... Much better than I remember.

On tap. Pours a dark brown with khaki head. Aroma is sweet and roasty with a decent amount of bourbon coming through. Taste is bitter and roasty, with some sweetness and chocolate. This was a very good beer.
Tap. Pour black with tan head. Has a chocolatey aroma. Rich, extremely bitter, lots of chocolate, burnt coffee. Alright....maybe needs a bit more age on it to mellow out all the bitterness.

Just when I thought nothing could compare to KBS, this showed up in a glass in front of me! What great news for me and my tastes buds. A wonderfully blended batch of beers that are so tasty. Beautiful aromas and tastes of molasses and bourbon. What a delicious brew!
Pitch Black with a thin filmy head and decent lacing. Aroma of chocolate, oak, vanilla, bourbon, molasses and licorice. Same goes for the flavor. Heavy body and mild carbonation; Very Creamy!

2013 bomber to Tulip. Pours black with faint brown head.Smell of roasted barley, wood, chocolate and cherry. Taste the same as smell. Different but very well.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pitch Black with a thin filmy head and decent lacing. Aroma of chocolate, oak, vanilla, bourbon, molasses and licorice. Same goes for the flavor. Heavy body and mild carbonation; Very Creamy! Pretty good overall.

2011 vintage. Pours pitch black with a nice creamy mocha head. Aroma of black licorice, molasses, some chocolate, slight coffee scents, alcohol undertones and oaky bourbon notes. Taste is mildly sweet throughout and not overly bitter, but incredibly dry and quite rich. Creamy thick mouth feel, full bodied with good carbonation. Overall it is, without question, one of the best and strongest imperial stouts I¬íve ever had.

Nose of roast barley and booze, with raisin and sweet coffee. Dark and black about anything you can find with some reddish reflection in bright lights but not much else. Rolls on the palate with the nose and is lighter in body than one might expect, layer upon buttery layer of the deepest, darkest date, raisin, coffee, bitter chocolate, some residual bittering as well but hsrd to say malt or hop. No explicit hop. Mid taste alcohol but resolves itself back to smooth heavy roast. Very good, perhaps a bit too much booze for my palate.

Bouteille 22 oz. Vintage 2010. Noire opaque, mousse brune. Nez de m√©lasse. Bouche visqueuse commen√ßant par de la m√©lasse mais allant rapidement vers la torr√©faction et la barrique de ch√™ne. Pas mal.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2014 From my first trade ever (with ygtbsm94), thanks Brad! 2009 vintage. Bomber. Pours dark brown with a fine medium brown head. Scent is bourbon, molasses, vanilla. Full mouth with dark malt, molasses, licorice, coffee, ash, and a touch of vanilla sweetness in the finish.
2010 vintage at Strong Beer Fest. Aroma is more chocolaty, less bourbon. Flavor too. Very enjoyable. Left numerical rating unchanged.

2013 poured from tap to glass. Jet black with thick creamy brown head. Aroma of strong roasted malt, molasses, plums, caramel, coffee, sugars, vanilla, rich tobacco. Mouthfeel is beautiful with a full body and nice carbonation. Taste is sweet initially with a really nice astringent bitterness to round out the finish. Smooth bitterness lingers which is reminiscent of cold brewed coffee. Overall, this is an absolutely fantastic brew and I really look forward to seeing how this year¬ís vintage is with some age.

A dark, semi-sweet black licorice-forward imperial stout with which was soothingly herbal, heavy, and chocolatey; tiniest hints of oak, topsoil, and burnt fudge peaking through. Delicately warming. Molasses cookies and espresso beans experienced by swallow. Fun.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2015 22 oz bottle shared with a friend. Black appearance with a big, lasting brown head and thick lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, anise, licorice, molasses, coffee, dark chocolate and earthy, bitter hops. Similar flavor, rich, malty, robust and complex with notes of bourbon, oak, vanilla and a touch of vinous fruit. Full body with a thick mouth feel and a lingering finish. Fuckin awesome beer.  Update:  2014 vintage, not as impressed more like 3.8 territory.

Bomber at Dad¬ís. Pours solid black with rich chocolate head. Aroma of chocolate, molasses, and roast, with little barrel. Rich chocolate, smoky malts, coffee, some bourbon and too much licorice for my taste. Mouthfeel is thick. Looking forward to tasting it again in a year.

My beer store finally has this legendary impy! Clerk recommended I buy one for now and age the other, so I did. My one-for-now: aroma of deep roasted choc with bourbon and hints of fruit, molasses, and licorice. Taste follows suit. Explosion of flavors in the mouth. Dark chocolate with super bitterness and booze and fruit and goodness knows what else. Reminds me a little of Expedition, but I think this might be even better. Would be neat to blind taste test someday.
On tap great fresh. In the bottle best aged at least one year, two or more years better. A top notch offering.

Bottle to glass. 2011 vintage. Pours a thick deep black color with a fizzy and quickly disappearing brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate. Flavor is an intense burnt roasted malt bitterness, with light chocolate sweetness hiding in the background. Thick creamy body with a burnt bitter finish. Perfect for a nice holiday eve.

Good beer, really nice taste 
Hops but chilled by aging. I like it, nice stout 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 vintage. On tap at the Olympics "there will be darkness" event. Loads of coffee, chocolate black licorice and toffee. Hot and boozy, but not as hot and boozy as the 2013. A year in their keg cooler has been good to this brew.

Pours dark and thick. The carbonation seems to slowly bubble like it¬ís caught in a bog. Smells of oak and dark fruits.. Tastes similarly. The alcohol burns nicely when drank, the carbonation is much lighter than it would look. Wow, so much rich chocolate flavor, has a woody and sweet balance that works really well. Would have on any winter night. Two for a real relaxing time.

Rated December 2013. -     
2010 vintage - 3 years old   
Black. Small brown ring of head. Aroma and flavor are complex and packed with character and seamlessly balanced. Tastefully sweet. Roasty. Kiss of sweet bourbon. Lots of chocolate. Coffee, licorice, molasses, touch of dark fruit. Very pleasant alcohol warmth. Clean toasty, just so smooth. Full body. A little sticky. Awesome. Everything comes together so well. A fantastically aged beer.

Rated December 2013 -   
2011 vintage.   This is a different recipe as far as the barrel aging and makes for a noticeably different beer. 
Compared to above. Sweeter. Some red wine. Dark cherry. Red fruit. Plus all the other malty goodness. Lots of chocolate. Caramel, molasses, etc.as stated above. Slick, creamy, and velvety smooth. Multilayered. Beautiful development. Truly world class.

The fragrance is rather subdued - roasted malts and vanilla. Pours as black as the bottom of an deep abyss with a rapidly disapearing khaki head and moderate lacing. The taste is slightly sweet yet roasty. Licorice, wood, malts, with hints of fruit. Full body and moderate carbonation. Velvety smooth mouthfeel. Overall, this is beer lives up to all the hype. Rich and rewarding.

On tap 5 oz. pour at the 2013 Strong Ale Festival at Pizza Port in Carlsbad (village), CA. 

Opaque, near black with a tan head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of cocoa, bourbon, roasted malt, roasted coffee, vanilla, cherry, dark fruit and Merlot. 

Taste of Merlot, dark chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, oak, roasted coffee, dark toast, cherry and dark fruit. 

Medium body and medium/high carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
2012 aged for one year. It burns so good. Super complex brew with numerous flavors on the palate. Chocolate, liquorice, coffee and tobacco. The mouth feel is amazing. Glad I waited.

Can¬ít wait even though it¬ís fresh off the line. Welcome to Philly! Bomber from Wegmans. Pours thick, inky black with a medium sized brown head with excellent retention, tons of lacing on the glass, a gorgeous stout. The aroma has a dense milk chocolate burst followed by cacao, vanilla, some of a coffee, and a little bit roasty. The taste has a bit roasted malt flavor that is followed by rich chocolate, some of the bourbon barrel comes through in the middle of the drinking experience with a vanilla and toasted oak.. maybe a faint coconut. The finish has just an unreal complex chocolate, vanilla, sweet, yet dry experience. #1 on my list.

Bottle. Split with the Shin Tommy. Pours cola black with a tan, creamy head. Aroma of Sharpie, cookie dough, oak, and dark chocolate. Taste is velvety chocolate, tobacco, roast, and subtle hints of coffee and licorice. Rich, silken, and refined. Very good.
Tap (nitro) at Deschutes, Portland. Colour is black with medium brownish head. Aromas and flavours: Coffee, sweetness, hints of chocolate and roasted malts. Supersoft and enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2014 2013 bottle. Big chunky pecan colored head, body utterly black and opaque. Heavy lacing. Aroma bread, dark fruit, dried plum, bourbon. Taste of citrus, caramel, plums, coffee, licorice, bourbon, grapefruit. Finish is bitter. Body thick, very viscose, little carbonation.

Just wanted to add a note; drinking abyss from a growler! Still great. Definite hints of anise. It would be great to cellar this too.

Cerveza compleja e interesante.
Aromas a malta tostada, caf√© y chocolate.
Color obscuro intenso, cuerpo de medio a redondo.
En boca es suave y sedosa, intensas notas a cafe y un final largo.
Al paladar es una cerveza compleja, intensa e interesante. Las maltas tostadas se perciben y combinan de gran forma con los sabores a chocolate!
Genial!

That smell is incredible coffee, chocolate, sweet, almost like a hint of mint, the look and pour is 10-40 motor oil, not a watery stout it¬ís milky in feel, you taste a note of sweet, coffee, chocolate, then a bitter kick after the swallow that lingers on the palate....the ABV is almost un-noticeable. One of the best beers I¬íve had all year!

650ml/22floz bottle into a tulip glass; served cool.

Aroma: SUPER chocolate-y. Reminds me of brownies. Some mocha/espresso notes. Choco bomb!

Appearance: Pitch black, opaque body. Dark brown, foamy head that dissipates to a thin cap.

Taste: Bittersweet chocolate. Molasses too. Not a lot of flavor you¬íd expect from the aging. Maybe a little bit of oak and vanilla. Great stuff though!

Palate: Very full body. Slick. Some light effervescence. Moderate-long warm, bittersweet finish.

Overall: Pretty great stout! Not what I was expecting, with all the flavors listed. It¬ís like a hardcore version of Black Butte kind of. Really nice though!

Vintage 2012, Best after 01NOV13

From the bottle: "brewed with black strap molasses, licorice, with cherry bark and vanilla added with 6% aged in oak bourbon barrels, 11% aged in oak barrels, and 11% aged in oak wine barrels"

Near black ale with a sheet of tan foam that creeps up the sides. Smells of oak, too much oak, smoke, some licorice, some molasses and a bit of hops (never had this experience in this beer previously). A resiny, bitter character on the nose. Flavor is alcohol, oak, bitter, licorice, toasted malts. I really, really want this to be better, but this is simply the worst iteration I¬íve had. Full bodied with moderate carb and a semi dry finish. I am concerned the prestigious heritage of this beer is faltering. While this is far from the best vintage, this is still a nice beer, and I¬ím happy to have a couple cases in the cellar, I probably wouldn¬ít have done that had I known about the deviation. 

Vintage 2011, Best by 04AUG12
4/4/4.5/4.5/4- 4.28 on 29NOV11
A: pours a dark, dark ale with nearly two fingers of really dark chocolate foam. This falls to a thick sheet of the same only dissipating once the beer sits for nearly an hour. Cobweb lace when foam present.
S: The bourbon barrel is present (surprising given the low percentage aged), some more oak, molasses, vanilla (subtle). The wood is quite strong when cold, as it warms the cocoa, coffee, molasses and bourbon come through much better.
T: The beer is roasted! Lots of toasty oats, oak, cocoa, bourbon, vanilla. Super refined tannins. Good bitterness to it. The vanilla is there alongside american oak. Black coffee and bittersweet chocolate. 
M: Burly body with lower carb. Nice, long, sticky finish with semi dry resonance.
O: This beer is good, but I don¬ít know how many I will be picking up this year for the cellar. I¬íve found through some recent tastings, that I may prefer this beer fresh. All the better! Makes me long for it in the off-season!

Serving type: bottle

12-01-2012

Dark chocolate, vanilla, burnt caramel, deep roasted malt and licorice. Slightly boozy and then the molasses. Perfection in brewing, beats the cr*p out of any BCBS this year.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft pour at Whip In. Pours pitch black with a thin, dark khaki head. The lacing is large and soapy, covering the entirety of the inner glass. Mild carbonation. Aromas of malt, coffee, licorice, molasses, faint oak. Full bodied with a great palate. Licorice and a mild bourbon sweetness before a long, bitter malty finish. Creamy mouthfeel that offers a sweeter flavor after several swigs, more licorice and malt as the bitterness fades. The bourbon is present but reserved. Awesome beer.

Bouteille de 2012. Noir sombre avec une petite mousse marron fonc√© qui reste jusqu¬íau fin. Au d√©but, l¬íar√¥me est comme les cerise enrob√© en chocolat noir avec un peu de r√©glisse. Je peu aussi d√©tect√© un peu de molasse et chocolat. Quand il se r√©chauffe l¬íar√¥me originale reste, mais il devient un peu plus terreux, un peu du bois. Pas fum√©, mais tr√®s terreux. Le go√ªt est d¬íabord du chocolat, cerise, molasse et r√©glisse. La finale est une amertume tr√®s bien √©quilibr√© avec un apr√®s go√ªt de r√©glisse et chocolat noir/cerise. Tr√®s, tr√®s bonne.

One of the best beer ever.
This is the god of imperial stout.
If you see this beer in your market you have to buy, everything is perfect on it.
When you drink, first you feel the dark malt and later you feel a flavor of licor, that is incredible

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2015 2013 was on tap from the Deschutes Brewpub in Portland. On nitro. Another on CO2. Ahhh. This is one interesting beer. It came black as night with a slight head, but the lacing on the glass was huge and adhered to the glass until finished. Aroma of chocolate and molasses and licorice. Flavors similar, but this is where it was more interesting. At first, the roasted and dark chocolate flavors dominated, followed by a significant bitterness at the back of the tongue - not overpowering, just very nice but definitely there. Full flavors. Toward the end of the glass, the flavor profile seemed to be more sweet than at first, but still with the constant bitterness not quite in the background. Very very nice. Bourbon flavors were present but not overpowering. A well-balanced masterpiece of a beer. I?d sure like to find a bottle and bring it home to age for another year, but am happy to settle for a glass or two with a friend at the pub, seated in front of the fireplace. This was worth the drive, and I?ll do it again not too far in the future.Today (end of 2014), I enjoyed a glass of the 2011 Abyss. This was smooth as silk, and without the sharp bitterness that initiated the new batch above. Smooth and easy to drink. A little boozy. Dark and complex and even more lovely. Today, mid 2015, I¬ím enjoying the 2014 vintage. Already, the sharp edge has come off and it is smooth with a lovely one-finger head. Still a masterpiece. So good.

Black with medium brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and liquorice. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, liquorice, medium sweet, caramel, notes of alcohol, wood, oak, hops and quite bitter.

On tap at naked city. At first a bit overwhelming. Smoke, coffee, bitterness, alcohol, soy sauce. Once you adjust this is delicious. Super rich coffee notes and dark chocolate. Reminds me of Expedition stout.

Poured a 2010 vintage into my snifter. Pours a jet black with a thin tan head that fades into a wisp.

Smells of chocolate and roasted malts. My cold is preventing me from picking up more subtle smells, but from what I can tell it¬ís great.

Some great roasted tones hit the palate immediately and I can tell the journey to the bottom of this glass is going to be sublime. Just a touch of booze near the end along with a very smooth incredible chocolate flavor. Finishes with a little roasted bitterness. This may be one of the best stouts I¬íve ever had.

Viscous without approaching cloying at all. Low carbonation levels, but enough not to be flat. Like drinking chocolate milk.

Amazing beer. I¬íve been waiting a while to open it and I¬ím glad I still have several more left.

I poured a 22oz bottle into a tulip glass. It had a "best after" date of 11/15/2011 (one year from the bottling date?). It cost $15.99 ($0.73 per ounce).

Appearance: Absolutely pitch black body with a small dark brown, foamy/frothy head. It laces and retains well considering how heavy and old the beer is.

Smell: Sweet aroma of black licorice, vanilla, and cherry. 

Taste: I got this bottle of Deschutes The Abyss (2010 Reserve) in a trade with my friend Ryan in San Diego back in January of 2011. I cellared it immediately and planned on drinking it later that year, but for whatever reason I kept putting it off. Now, nearly three years after this beer was born, I finally decided to drink it and I¬ím kicking myself for having waited so long. It¬ís everything I look for in a barrel-aged imperial stout, but without any of the weightiness or edginess of a fresher vintage. 

There¬ís a lot going on in this beer, though that¬ís not surprising considering it¬ís brewed with licorice and molasses with 1/3rd of it aged in oak and bourbon barrels. Imperial stouts of this caliber tend to be rare and expensive but this one definitely deserves all the merit it receives. It begins with a luscious, sweet flavor of dark cherry. It¬ís almost tart in a way, like raspberry, but without any tartness. Some chocolate syrup flavors come through towards the middle, then changing to something more bitter on the backend. Big imperial stouts like this tend to be highly hopped for balance, but The Abyss is only 65 IBUs, giving it balance, but keeping the hops in check. There¬ís a delicious woody/vanilla flavor on the finish, which I like to let linger on the tongue to savor. The alcohol has mellowed nicely and has faded into the background and probably accounts for the vanilla and woody character. 

This beer is basically everything an imperial barrel-aged stout should be, and is one of, if not the best example of the style. 

Drinkability: While Deschutes The Abyss is a big beer at 11% ABV, with three years under its belt it¬ís aged remarkably. The alcohol has mellowed to the point that it¬ís just a subtle warming sensation in the background. The body itself is pretty full, though the mouthfeel is a little thinner and cleaner than I was expecting. It¬ís calm and soft and goes down smooth with no burning or warming sensation. It leave a lovely aftertaste of licorice and roasted malt, yet it¬ís not drying or cloying. I probably should¬íve saved this for a more special occasion than an ordinary Tuesday night.
Wooooow been wanting n waiting to try this classic brew. Got my hands on a 2011 n man it didn¬ít disappoint at all. Not talked about enough

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2013 Rating # 250! 2011 version on tap 12 oz pour into a snifter at Brouwer¬ís cafe Back in black stout fest. Pours a pitch black color with a thick khaki head that leaves great lacing. Smells of oak roasted malt dark chocolate, black licorice, vanilla, and dark fruit. Tastes of all the same thing¬ís in the smell with a slight bourbon flavor mixed in. As it warms it tastes better and better Mouthfeel is thick and creamy but pretty smooth and chewy with good carbonation and a dry finish. This is one of the best imperial stouts around period. Has a plethora of different flavors and is very balanced. Glad to have finally tried the 2011 version. Only had the 2010 version before and I think I like the 2011 version slightly better.  Just had the 2013 version  from a grower and it was great. I think it will taste better with age. still prefer the 2011 version.

text: This is a 2008 reserve. I have been sitting on this and waiting. I have never has the Abyss before. Pours black with dark black and tan head which fades quickly. smells of burnt oak, bourbon, malt and molasses. taste of smoke wood oak chocolate molasses. also some sips getting a creamy vanilla taste and a little licorice, pretty light in body at first then heavier as it warms, I think this bottle aged well and is still very complex.
What a great beer for my 100th rating... The Abyss is just that. Endlessly deep with so many great flavor components. Chocolate, coffee, booze, malt, and the licorice is a nice surprise. Loved it.

1400th review!  22 ounce bottle into snifter; 2011 vintage, best after 8/4/2012.  Pours dense pitch black color with a 1 finger dense dark tan head with great retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lasts.  Nice dense soapy lacing clings on the glass; looks awesome.  Aromas of big dark chocolate, roasted malt, cherry, oak, light char, coffee, cocoa, molasses, caramel, toffee, vanilla, licorice, toast, and roasted earthiness.  Incredible aromas with big complexity of dark malt, oak, and barrel character; and extremely balanced.  Taste of big dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, molasses, light char, cherry, oak, toast, toffee, vanilla, cocoa, licorice, light smoke, and roasted earthiness.  Lingering notes of dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, molasses, light char, cocoa, oak, licorice, light smoke, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while.  Fantastic depth and complexity of dark malt flavors with the barrel character and flavor additions; with a fantastic overall balance of all flavors; and zero cloying sweetness after the finish.  Medium carbonation and very full bodied; with a very creamy, slick, and lightly chalky mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic blended imperial stout!  Huge depth and complexity of flavors with incredible balance; and very smooth to sip on.  An extremely enjoyable offering to sip on slowly.

Bottle to finish off The Stouts Tasting Pt II. Cheers to Bruce for supplying this. Vintage 2011. The pour¬ís deep brown with a tiny off-white head. The aroma¬ís of rich caramel candy. Werther¬ís Original . Some chocolate. Raisin nut cake. The taste is more of the same. Chocolate, roasted malts. Some accents of vanilla. Moderate bourbon barrel presence. Slightly hot on the finish. Medium body. Smooth. Overall, a really good beer.

One if my favorite stouts. Dry mocha with licorice and oak with some bourbon.

The palate follows with a thick sticky blackstrap molasses base that adds a touch of rustic graininess caramelized deep dark fruit, spent coffee grounds and some roasted malt. As it opens up there is some more chocolate presence and a sweet vanilla roundness that smooths everything out and balances some of the intense flavors out.

Clear dark brown beer, small creamy brown head, unstable, non adhesive. aroma: lots of caramel, dark chocolate, bit sugary, dusty, cocoa powder, vanilla. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body, smooth texture. Taste: very nice caramel flavours, fudge, bit sugary, lots of chocolate, sour touch, vanilla. Personal contribution @ ¬ëThe Adam Jackson Tasting¬í. Obtained in a trade with Adam. Brewed with molasses and licorice, that just sounds like a joke, apparently also 33 % was BA in oak and bourbon barrels. 2011 Vintage I believe? Best after 08/04/2012. 65 cl bottle sampled. Pours black with a reasonable mocha head. Nose is sweet and licorice heavy, smooth and well integrated, touch molasses, roasted malt, underlying sweetness and coffee, anise. Bitter black licorice taste, bitter molasses, burned coffee, chocolate, pure chocolate, bitter coffee grounds, cacao. Full, very slick, everything is well integrated. Well done and I appreciate it even with the licorice focus. Another top 50 beer explored ¬ñ whaling with Ahab.

22oz bottle split 2 ways. 2010 vintage properly cellared. 

A: Thick pour into a tulip yields a mocha head which recedes rather too fast. Color is true to the maw, but it¬ís the legs which impress. They leave a brown stain on the glass.

N: Peppercorn, molasses, anise, chocolate, roasted malt, coffee. Laden with an earthy bitterness still. Fudge goes deep as does the licorice. Has a slight raspberry and cherry edge. 

T: Lots of blackstrap molasses and black licorice. Substantial earthy hoppiness. Roasted coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Lots of black peppercorns. Raisins and prunes compose the back of the flavors. Oaks, as always is quite strong, though bourbon is not. Every sip is a bitter, sweet, and spicy assault on the tongue, but it¬ís never cloying or overpowering.

M: Heavy on the palate, but it does lack some of the heft of its competitors. Lots of alcohol still. This might have another couple of years until it peaks.

O: A fantastic RIS. Never goes too big in any one direction, which is a big positive in my book, because it¬ís easier to find the spectrum of flavors. You¬íll enjoy it, it¬ís a given. Pity this is the last year of the non-futzed version.

Amazing comes to mind. 9oz pour goes a long ways. It is just like having some heaven in your hand
