One of the best stouts i have had. this one would have definately benefitted from at least 6 months in the cellar to let all the complex flavors meld. 
Great Stout.
One of the best stouts, ever. Everything I want from a big RIS: bitter chocolate, licorice, coffee, roast, minimal carbonation, oily mouthfeel. Just great.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2015 re-rate 12/15 from growler (first growler!)  Saw this at a local growler station and had been wanting to try again, so this was fresh.  aroma and taste different at different temps - nose when warm had smoke and wood - really niiiiice!.  Taste was best in between cold and room temp - roasted malt, stout stuff - the alcohol/hop combo was a little too much for me (why I normally prefer an aged stout).  complex beer.......kept rate at 3.8 very good stout but plenty others I prefer over this one... ....... 2010 bottle; not sure how/where I got this one - disappointed by nose - wine very strong at first followed by alcohol; as bottle warmed I got some chocolate but nothing else??  beautiful oil black pour.  mouthfell full and thick.  Taste was a little all over the place - strong carbonation, some alcohol; chocolate and slight bitterness - not sure that this pulled together a little dissapointed considering the hype.

2012. Black pour with a dense lasting brown head. Aroma is chocolate, wood, and licorice. Taste is cocoa, coffee, dark fruits, licorice, molasses, and alcohol. Very warm on the way down. Carbonation is a little more prickly than expected. Viscous and sticky on the palate. Nice burly stout.

2011 bottle was an extra from a trade from a chap from Missouri that resides on the other site. Pours motor oil black with same viscosity. Quaker State is jealous. I get wine immediately in the nose, with bourbon and oak in the background. Bourbon is more defined in the mouth with a solid chocolate and roast backbone. Somewhat chewy at times. Booze factor hits strong... Good thing I am sitting down.

21st November 2011Opaque black beer, big tan head. Palate is surprisingly light. Nice dark malt - smooth with a trace of coffee. Mild lactose cream. Just a trace of oak and even less of bourbon. A whisper of fruit. Semi dry smooth finish that is almost minty fresh. Pinch of spice. Not a shouty RIS but pretty elegant and balanced. Very drinkable.

Almost smoky aroma, black pour, balanced taste and mild mouthfeel.  Easy drinking beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Refrigerated bomber with black wax 2010 obtained through trade poured into snifter.  Pours black with small light brown head that dissapates quickly.  Little ring of lacing, medium body, low carbonation, and coffee aroma.  Taste is bourbon, black coffee, dry oak, some molasses, some salt,  and some anise.  The flavor don¬ít meld for me.

2012 Vintage. 
Aroma is dark fruit, molasses and licorice balanced by with some roast and chocolate. A light hop aroma is present as well as a bit of an oak aroma. 
Pours a dark black with a thin mocha head that recedes fairly quickly to the edges. Moderate lacing and small legs. 
Flavor has some nice sweet chocolate and roast character. Some sweet cherry notes and light licorice character. Moderate bitterness, light oak and low hop flavor. A touch of molasses and alcohol in the finish. 
Medium full bodied with medium carbonation. Low to medium low astringency and medium alcohol warmth. 
Overall this is a nice imperial stout but I think I like it more with a bit of age. This one is a bit hot and should age nicely. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma of licorice, coffee, and dark fruits.  Pours thick black with light tan filmy head.  Taste is all roast coffee and sweet dark chocolate.  The coffee roast lingers in the mouth.  No sign of the alcohol.  Aaaamazing.

Bottle courtesy of Uncle Craig. Thanks! 2012 vintage. Poured at a tasting w three other folks. Extremely dark pour. Dark brownish head. Very thick but not oily. Fantastic woody and bourbon aroma. Melds together perfectly. Mouthfeel is actually lighter and smoother than I would have guessed. Flavors are the same way, they all blend together perfectly without one dominating. The flavors I could discern were wood, oak, mild bourbon, semi-sweet chocolate, leather and berries. This beer is fantastic! The hit of the tasting.  Too bad it's so hard to get and impossible in PA!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at St. Augustine's. blackest that black can be, with a thick dark tan cap that sticks around for a while. Aroma is licorice, chocolate, ah fuck it. I'm annoyed with reviewing a universally great beer, like this. Some people will get a chub picking out subtle differences, but mostly, they're probably finding different paths to the same characters that others have mentioned. This beer is good. I can drink it more than other licorice-forward stouts because its better and it's balanced. It makes my sweat pants tent.

2010 bottle, shared between 2 people. smell instantly reminds me of Darklord, the molasses is so recognizable and it dominates, no licorice in the nose at all. it pours jet black with a strong dark chocolate milk head. no light penetration which is always a plus in a stout. the taste is of molasses, burnt, roast, hints of vanilla, theres a little barrel in there. the body is not as heavy as i was expecting at 11% and a bit watery on the finish. carbonation was a bit higher than most imp stouts like it. overall not bad but if its like this with some age on it then idk if i want to see it fresh.

Bottle, pours jet black with creamy mocha head, awesome rummy burnt sugar aroma, sweet, full, chocolate and cocoa, light mineraled tang throughout and a bit of date, heavy bourbon finish, incredible, absolutely loved it

Pours solid blackish brown with a healthy espresso head. The aroma is top notch coming strongly from the tulip glass. Big coffee notes with vanilla, tart fruit, black licorice and subtle traces of bourbony goodness. The taste is complex with coffee, chocolate mousse, and sweet rock candy up front followed by oaky vanilla, graham cracker and a little heat from the bourbon. There¬ís beautiful bubbly lacing hanging about the glass. The palate offers a slightly syrupy texture with a good bit of carbonation to balance it. Very elegant brew. The different elements combine to create something superior to the sum of its parts. They nailed it.

Pours thick and black with a big tan head.  Nose is chocolate, black licorice, molasses and straw.  Taste is bitter mostly with a good malty sweet backbone.  Something just a bit off from previous years.  A bit metallic.  Mouthfeel is crisp and creamy at the same time, heavy body and a huge finish.

Hints of chocolate, coffee, black licorice, pit fruit, and vanilla aroma.  Slight coffee/bourbon aftertaste - very smooth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2013 Shared bomber at Lunar Brewing Co. for their Deschutes intro gathering. Only a moderately viscous pour to sampler rock glasses, showing a black/brown hue, a modest amount of quickly diminishing, brownish tan head foam, and spotty lacing. The aroma was very roasty, with barrel notes, booziness, baker¬ís chocolate, licorice, and both sweetness and tartness. The flavor was similar. I expected the soft carbonation, but also expected a fuller body. The hop bitterness was overly astringent. A little disappointed with this one of two items on the dessert course for the evening. Shared 2013 bomber the next time around. Poured to snifters with a better display, more persistence to the head & lacing, and noticeable, leggy spots. The body seemed fuller, there was an additional bit of smokiness to the taste, and the tanniny astringency was much more manageable. 3.7 + .3

One of my favorite beers and one I will always try and track down in the winter to cellar.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Enjoyed at Deschutes tasting. Poured dark, and thick with classic, minimal stout head that formed a ring around the glass. Smelled of floral hops melded with a deep coffee aroma. Drank smooth and sweet, with little lingering after taste, with coffee and toasted malt notes. A well balanced beer.

I¬íve recently had this fresh and also cellared for a year.  Both are very nice but the cellared is really the way to go.  The depth of this beer is what stands out.  Starts with the molasses and ends with a nice hops infused spice.  One of may favs this year and worth every sip.

Nice floral, hoppy aroma with sweet, syrupy molasses.
Pours like motor oil with a thick, oily, brown head that dissipates in a couple minutes but laces nicely to the last drop. 
Sweet honey, boozy malt, and licorice up front fading into a slightly grassy back bite of hoppy bitterness that lingers long.
Creamy, thick mouthfeel.
I really enjoyed this beer.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location: Bottle at Paul¬ís Blind Impy Stout Tasting, 1/5/13


Aroma: The nose has roasted coffee, some caramel, dusty notes, and booze

Appearance: Pours a dark brown color with pretty much no head

Flavor: The flavor was a little better then the nose, but it just tasted a touch old and dusty

Palate: The feel is thick and oily, fairly full bodied, with a bit of a burn on the finish

Overall Impression: 
I was honestly shocked that I didn¬ít like this more.  I¬íve been wanting to try this beer for a while, and expected a world class beer.  Maybe it was just a bad bottle or something, I don¬ít know, but I think this one will require a re-visit for sure...

10oz on tap. Second tasting.  It might be the perfect imperial stout, if not the perfect beer.  You can taste the love put into this beer - it¬ís oozes quality ingredients and craftsmanship.   Perfectly balanced for the style, just right.  I won¬ít belabor the taste description on this one, you just have to get one.  Bravo.

Pours very dark, cannot see through at all and with a thick foamy head. This is one of the tastiest stouts i've had. Worth buying for sure, but get it fast as it's a very limited release.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This used to be easy to get but know its a pain In the ass, Damn! S: Licorice, mollasses, cacao, oak, alcohol, port, just a complex smell. P: black with a brown thick head that dispenses quickly towards the edges. T: dark bitter chocolate, dark fruits, figs and plums, alcohol, wood, hints of vanilla. M: thin/medium with noticable carbonation. O: Never had this one this fresh and I would say a few months in the cellar does help to bad I dont have anymore abyss.

22 ounce bottle, 2011 vintage.  Thanks Jason!  Pours tenebrously with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of malt, chocolate, molasses, licorice, and dark fruit.  Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, molasses, caramel, licorice, bourbon, wood, and vanilla.  Truly an experience.

22oz 2008 bottle, shared at work.  Pours a deep black hue, coffee color head.  Aromas are robust coffee sweetness, slight vanilla edge, with some dark fruits dancing around.  Honestly the booziness had left the nose.  Taste was also fantastic the bourbon notes were intact, a sweet light anise on the outside edge left only a tad of bitterness and a long rich finish.  I¬ím very happy the way this one has progressed, with a few more in the cellar its tough to see this one getting any better.

Tap. Poured an opaque black with a brown head that dissipated with nice lacing. Aroma is liquorice, dark roasted malt, light tobacco. Flavor is the same plus notes of molasses and dried fruits. Medium sweetness, some bitterness but not overwhelming. Creamy mouth feel. Warming finish and alcohol was very well hidden. A very good beer.

Had on tap at JL Beers, Fargo in Tulip Glass
Pours a nice mocha head with tight bubbles.  Beer is pitch black, no light coming through whatsoever.  Head is dissipating rather quickly, but at 11% that is to be expected.  The nose on the beer is huge.  Notes of bittersweet chocolate, molasses, sligth dark fruit, slight coconut and vanilla notes.  Hint of alcohol but it is masked well by the vanilla.  The taste is tremendous...front of the tongue you get really bitter dark chocolate with a slap of molasses that moves through to a bourbon chocolate goodness.  Hints of vanilla come t hrough along with a toasted coconut. Definite leather in the finish. The barrel age blend that makes this beer lends so many flavors to it.  There is no hint onf the 11% ABV in the taste, but there is a warming in the belly.  This beer is fantastic and hestly the bottes say best after November 2013.  This was a 2012 Vintage so this is the same as the bottle that says best after November 2013.  Can¬ít wait to see what a year or two of aging does to this beer.

22oz Bottle 2012 Vintage A - Pours opaque black with a chocolate brown head, lots of lacing. S - Huge cocoa bomb, light booze. T - Dark chocolate, espresso coffee, dark fruits, hop bite, alcohol integrated nicely. M - Full bodied but not heavy smooth. Oaky dry/tannin finish. O - Very nice stout.

Tap. Pours opaque black with a medium brown head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is coffee, dark roasted malt, liquorice, light tobacco, and some whiskey/bourbon notes. Flavor is the same plus notes of molasses , citrus (lemon), and dried fruits. Medium sweet, light to medium bitter. Medium plus body with a creamy mouthfeel. Warming finish due to ABV, which is otherwise well masked.

Bottle @ home thx to benzai. We?ve decided to end 2012 with a bang and this beer should do the trick. The pouring looks promissing: pitch black motoroil goodness with a brown head. Brown head, I kid you not. Let?s smell this bad boy. The smell is iron, roasty, ash, earthy, tar. It tastes like liquorice, dark chocolate, roasty, ash, tar, some vanilla, coffee, some red fruits, bourbon and wood. The aftertaste is amazing. It keeps on going and going with a lots of tastes queing up to surprise your mouth. The body is full with a carbo that just fits perfectly.. There is some carbo, but it?s barely noticable. It doesn?t wreck the taste, it helps the taste. It?s just slightly tingly on the tongue and throat. This is an amazing beer and a great way to end my tasting sessions with Benzai for 2012. It might not be the best beer, because the smell could be even better (the smell is great, but the taste is even better), but other than that it?s a great brew! Definitely a highlight of my year.

650ml bottle [from trade with Boltz7555] shared with Dutchdrebus. Huge thick dense brown head on top of an opaque black colored beer. Head is long lasting and leaves great lacing. Aroma has malts, lightly roastyness, lightly alcohol and some liquors. Taste malts, roasted malts, liquorice, a hint of wood, lightly liquor, lightly alcohol, superb fitting long lingering roasted bitterness that reminds me of pure dark chocolate. Full body, medium perfectly suited carbonation. Very nice beer, too bad the aroma is a bit flat compared to the beers taste. Still love it though.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2013 On draft at Whole Foods Chandler¬ís Watering Hole. Pours a deep brown with a uniform mocha head. Molasses and biscuit for the nose with some licorice and more hoppiness than I remember from the 2011 release. Very licorice forward with a bit of a hop bite balanced by a malty toast note followed with smooth cocoa. Light body for a stout with an oaky dry finish; it hides the 11% ABV well.

Alrighty, this is my first beer review, so be kind...please.  I am more of a beer seller than a beer drinker, though I am finally being introduced to some GOOD beers...which makes all the difference in the world! It turns out that I actually like good beer.  I put a case of this in the store after reading all the great reviews on it here on ratebeer.  I wanted to be able to describe it accurately to shoppers, so of course I cracked one open immediately...which isn¬ít all that easy.  I would recommend this beer to anyone. The bottle is unusual..black wax hand-dipped lid-seal is a classy start to a very complex beer. I sipped at it all day...right from the bottle.  I know. Well, now I know. Snifter next time. It¬ís a strong beer & just a few sips makes ye feel pretty warmish. Everything everyone says about this beer is true. I may have to sock away a few bottles to get a good start on my personal cellar.  Yum!  Best beer I have tasted so far.

Bottle at home (thanks to Frank/Ramnuts) 26/12/12 2008 Vintage.
Light black/very dark mahogony brown with a thin tan head that clears to the edge and leaves a thin swirl atop the centre.
Nose is dark malts, dark fruits, chocolate, wood, bourbon, molasses, dark toffee, aniseed, liqourice.
Taste comprises roast malts, dark bitter chocolate, bourbon, wood, boozed up chocolate maltesers, mineral tones.
Full bodied with fine carbonation, smooth on the palate, boozey finish.
Excellent imperial stout, the alcohol is well integrated, top stuff!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 2012 vintage on tap at Pressbox in El Cajon.  Aroma is malt, coffee, licorice; taste is nicely balanced chocolate, bourbon, roasted malt, licorice, coffee.  Not as heavy and thick as other barrel aged stouts.  Overall complex and very good.

Bottle @ home from jarvit.... Thanks my friend! ... pours pitch opaque black with a medium tan head.... The aroma is roasted malt, espresso, licorice, chocolate, vanilla and oak...... The flavor is sooo nice! hard roasted malt, licorice, dark fruits, coffee, chocolate, vanilla and bourbon.... thanks for this experience.....
Bottle pours a jet black color with a thick, lacing, brown head. Scent is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and wood. Taste is bitter chocolate, coffee, bourbon and roasty. Very nice.

2010 bottle.  Super black pour, small brown head.  Looks thick!  Bitter chocolate and coffee on the nose.  Flavor is explosive.  Bitter chocolate, espresso, just a peek of sweetness in the middle.  Finishes with a bit of oak and tanins to dry it out at the end.  Full body with soft carbonation.  Like eating fine chocolate truffles.  Fantastic !!!!!

2011 vintage on tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours thick inky brown with thin creamy head that fades quickly. Aroma is charred malts with hints of coffee and licorice. Taste is big rich blackened malts, chased by a mellow hoppy bitterness. Notes of bourbon, coffee, oak, raisin, and dark chocolate are present. Doesn¬ít have the heavy barrel-aged, bourbon taste that some of the bigger imperial stouts do, but incredibly well balanced. This is one of the best. The annual race to acquire it before bottles sell out confirms it.

Bomber received in trade. Thank you Adnielsen! Pours oily pitch black with a small creamy dark chocolate brown head that leaves some thick lacing on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet, malty and surprisingly subtle with roasted malts, sweetened dark roast coffee, vanilla fudge, coconut, fresh oak, raisins, sweet liquorice candy, bourbon, bitter chocolate, alcohol, caramel and hints of citrus zest. Taste is sweet, bitter and tiny sour with roasted malts, dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate, moist mineral-rich soil, pumpernickel bread, orange zest,  pine, resinous wood, vanilla fudge, burnt cookies, coconut, charred wood and toffee. Mouthfeel is round, tiny boozy, tiny astringent and full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with roasted malts, dark roast coffee, resinous wood, vanilla fudge, burnt cookies, bitter chocolate, raisins, pine and toffee. A bit rough around the edges but still very tasty.
Bottle. Pours black with a little tan head. Aroma is molasses. Flavor is malts, vanilla, chocolate and other great flavor.  Nice beer and the abv is perfectly hidden. Nice mouthfeel, very nice beer.

Bottle at my parents, shared with my dad. 2011 Vintage. Pour is pitch black, like car oil, with a huge brown head and wonderful lacing.  Peat, cocoa nibs, black licorice, wood, dark fruits, moss, somewhat grassy, and caramel in the aroma. Taste is peaty, a touch of bourbon, big dark chocolate, espresso, oak, figs, raisins, toffee, and caramel with a big rich cocoa/bitter finish. Sticky/syrupy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Super smooth, velvety, and indulgent with dangerously hidden alcohol. Such a great beer and ages gracefully.

Bottle at A Drink To The End Of Days, 121220. Pitch black beer with a small brownish head. Malty chocolate aroma, cocoa powder, licorice, milk notes, vanilla notes, some oak, caramel, roasted, molasses, licorice, raisins, vinous, some dades. Roasted tar flavor, oak, bitter, licorice, molasses, vinous, cocoa powder, hay, perfume bitterness, dry woody, dades, vanilla. Balanced and very, very tasty. Roasted finish with raisins, tar, oak, licorice and nice bitterness.

Bottled at DTTEOD
Pitch black with an orange/beige head. 
Sweet fruits and dark chocolate in the flavour. 
Vinous and roasted. Chocolate, dark coffee. Liquorice, some tar and oak. 
Rather high bitterness.

2012 bottle. Pours dark as night with ample head that clings to glass. Cocoa, molasses, licorice, bourbon on the nose, with hops aromatics coming through after a few sips. All kinds of stuff going on on the tongue: chocolate, dark malt, a raisiny molasses sweetness lingering after, and a definite burn going down. Slick but not oil-slick mouthfeel. Leaves some coffee bitterness/oak on the tongue. Component tastes are almost segregated right now, suspect it will blossom when we get to that "best after" date, but who can wait?
Bottle (bomber), thanks to heyta. Black with medium brown head. Salmiak, gun powder, tar, some coffee, some wood.. Full bodied, low to medium carbonation. Semi dry with high bitterness.

Cocoa, Barley, oats and toffee on the nose. Deep blackish mahogany with a brown foam top and beautiful lacing against the glass. Thick and complex roast flavors of coffee beans, burnt caramel, cocoa, barley, bourbon, molasses, roasted nuts upfront. Heavy booze and notes of dates, dark fruits, earthy hops and continuous burnt caramel on the finish. Overall, This is an absolutely fantastic brew with remarkable complexity. Thick, smokey, roasty and an abundance of cocoa, coffee bean and molasses overtones. I¬íd give this an A+ rating. Definitely one to cherish.

2010 bottle.  It¬ís hard to tell if this has mellowed much in 2 years, though I don¬ít remember it being too big, not put together, or much in any particular aspect 2 years ago just after the release. I think it could still age for a few years quite well. It is still a big barrel aged imperial stout, just not so much as may others...and that¬ís good.  It pours black with a big rocky brown head, some lace, and thick legs. The aroma is aroma is very sweet, molassas, pine, and chocolate.  The flavor is burnt toast bitter (fairly strong), oak, dark roast coffee, less bourbon than I would expect, medium spice and alcohol. The licorice isn¬ít immediately apparent but comes out at the end of the aroma and flavor, especially on the sides of the tongue.  The texture is sticky and silken but with tannins apparent.  While the licorice may be a detractor for me it is still a superb beer and one I wish I had cases more of by the year.
Bottle. 2011 vintage. Pours black with brown head. Aroma of coffee. Flavors of coffee. What the hell? I¬ím not impressed.

Bottle 07.12.12
Visual: Dark black,  with a small tan head.
Aroma: Toast, caramel, some coffee and nuts.
Taste: Coffee, nuts and burnt.


Visual:
Aroma:
Taste:

2012 Reserve popped in thr first week of December of the same year. Says "Best After 11/1/13" but screw it! Pours black with big brown creamy head. Hangs around for a bit with lots of lacing. Aroma of chocolate, roasted grains, molasses, hints of black licorice, and dark fruits. Don¬ít get any bourbon or vanilla on the nose, but still smells very nice. Interesting flavor. Steong roasted flavor with seriously bittersweet chocolate. Alcohol warmth on the finish. I do get a bit of the wine barrel addition, but it is very subtle. Solid imperial, but was hoping for a bit more vanilla/chocolate/molasses. Will have to grab another one to mature and see how that helps it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Drank out of bomber poured into a snifter at home. Aroma- roasted cocoa or cofee notes. A little bit nutty. Appearance- no head. Very dark black oil look but thinner consitancy than some stouts. Taste- wonderful! Coffee nutty taste. A pleasany burnt peanut shell taste. Palate- very nice aftertaste like a good cigar would leave. Overall- top of the line stout. Nice to sit back and sip on

Drank from a large bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a thick oily brown with coffee colored head. Aroma has notes of vanilla and oak with some molasses and tobacco. Has a delicious rich toasted malt flavor. Palate is earthy, grassy and slightly bitter in a good way. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 bottle I brought to Kevin Wilk¬ís tasting. Pours jet black with with brown head that lingers slightly. nose is molasses, spices,port, vanilla and bittersweet chocolate. first sip is similar with tons of bitter sweet chocolate and nice finish with capachino and roasted chicory.

From memory.. Draft..  smooth and rich, without being sweet. I loved the concentration and balance of such a robust beer. Creamy, deep and complex. Deep roasted notes of coffee, dark chocolate and so much more... Words don't do this beer justice.. Truly awesome... You won't be let down.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

2011 Bottle.  Pitch black with minimal head.  Great aroma, roasty, molasses, dark chocolate, dark fruit, wood, hint of bourbon.  Taste of Molasses, Dark cherry, slight black liquorice, wood, very slight smoke, bourbon, alcohol is well integrated here, as are the various barrels.  Thick body with lower carb.  Great.

Bottle. Dark as night with a brown sugar colored head. Aroma is spicy and sweet. Taste is licorice with a hint of raisins and....brown sugar? Molasses? Almost fizzy when cold (<50). Mellow and soft when it warms. A bit boozy when young, but ages very well.
Opened a 2012 bottle. Absolutely terrific, complex, and smooth. A little boozy with a sharp finish. A bit of age and this will be perfect.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2014 2012 release on draught at Deschutes¬í Portland pub 11/20/12. So dark and chocolatey, bourbony and smooth. A favorite. 2013 release on draught at Deschutes Brewery & Public House in Portland 11/17/13, served in a stemmed snifter. Pitch black with little dark tan head. Aroma is oak, bourbon, and sweetened dark chocolate. Taste is roasty, toasty dark malts, cocoa nibs, cherry cordial, and oaky bourbon. Smooth, rich, and delicious. On draught at 2014 Holiday Ale Festival. 2008 vintage. Stronger flavor, smoother body. Incredible!

Black, with a medium brown, dense head, and an relatively light aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Flavor is roasted malt, bitter chocolate, hop bitterness. Unfortunately I do not get much in the way of barrel, wood, or bourbon notes out of this. They may be there, but this is a busy beer and it is hard to pick out a lot of distinct flavors. Has a slightly more aggressive or harsh edge than I would prefer. Mouthfeel is smooth and slightly velvety. This is a pretty nice beer; I would prefer something a little smoother with some more distinct flavor notes coming out. Still, an interesting beer, and I would think that it could get much more interesting with a few years in the cellar. Not really one I would need to try again without some age on it.

2007 - A nice sight with chocolate, malts, oak, licorice, and bourbon scents. The smell leads me to believe that the Abyss will have a bite to it. The flavor has a dominant sign of malts with a strong roasted flavor. The dark chocolate is not too much or too weak in flavor, its just right. The oak is a little heavy but the bourbon seems to subdue the oak. The finish is not too bad but because of the abv, the mild bitterness, plus the licorice taste it weakness the overall experience. In the end this is a wonderful brew and it is a must try.

2008. Black of color with a nice brown head. An aroma of roasted malt, liqurice, sweets, oak, vanilla, spice and weak port. A flavor of sweet liqurice, port, dark fruits, vanilla, oak and weak alcohol.

Looks like a slimy black penis in a glass. Smells like chocolate thunder, milkshakes, Tarmac. The barrel influence is only slightly noticeable upon first sip. Nice balance of sweet and bitter. Dry yet quenching and quaffable. Also, chuggable. Yes.

So cracked this Bad Boy as the big # 500. Cheers to me ;)
Pour a nicely looking pitch black, with a small mocha-brown head. 
Aroma is packed with goodies like roasted malts, licorice, chocolate, chocolate, slight wood, slight bourbon (especially in the aftertaste), other barrel notes as well, dark fruits. Plenty of stuff going on, and it¬ís pretty darn delicious. The taste is rather sweet, with a nice roasted n¬í bitter aftertaste. (Perhaps even some slightly salty notes as well(?)) - Slight warm in the throat, but hides the 11 % abv very well. 
Medium bodied, with a surprisingly fizzy carbonation.  
A huge thanks to Tom for sending me this 2010 vintage..

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2012 2010 release consumed in 2012.  Black, opaque, light brown head.  Aroma of deep malt with bready and toasty notes, toffee, chocolate, licorice, dark fruits, light bourbon barrel aromas, some tobacco/leather.  Flavor of licorice, baker¬ís chocolate, light roast, some burnt sugar and toffee, mild tar-like sensations.  Full bodied and warming.  Very complex and delicious.

Bottled 650ml. -Courtesy of luttonm, shared with him and Marko. Pitch black coloured, medium sized brown head, roasty nose with notes of chocolate. Strong roasted malt, some coffee and dark chocolate with significant licorice presence. Notes of wood in rather bitter finish. 2010 vintage.

bomber into a tulip
Review #700

Black, solid black. dark mocha colored head. Great retention to the head. Obvious ABV legs and spotty lacing on the sides of the glass. 

Lovely oak nose. Warm and inviting. Backing dose of molasses, chocolate, marshmallow,  and licorice.  Well balanced nose and quite complex. 

More about the oak in the taste. Warm and toasty. Slight notes of vanilla and coconut. Lots of molasses, dark fruits and just slight amounts of licorice.  Lots of tannins to this and quite warming on the gums. Restrained bourbon and ABV notes. 

Slik smooth in the mouth. Full bodied and low carbonation. Licorice is more evident in the mouth but a lot of chocolate notes.  Just a well done beer on every level.  Elite level beer

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a creamy brown head that left minimal lacing. Aroma of chocolate, oak, molasses, vanilla and some dark fruit. Flavor was rich & complex with dark chocolate, molasses, oak, coffee, sweet vanilla, bourbon and some licorice with a sweet warming finish.  A world class brew

2007 bomber courtesy of theisti. Pours jet black with a dark cocoa head that drops to a thin skin at the surface of the snifter. The nose is of dark roasted malt, oak, vanilla, licorice and touch of bourbon sweetness. Full-bodied and slick with just a bit of oaky dryness and some astringency at the swallow. I have taken good care of this bottle, saving it for the opportunity to share it with a friend, but I was a little concerned I¬íd held onto it for too long. Fortunately, the wax seal seams to have done its job. The flavor is of dark, roasty malt, coffee, oak/vanilla barrel notes and a touch of the bourbon that may have once been "hot" but has mellowed to an added sweetness that enhances the profile. This is a great beer, and I had the added pleasure of getting to share it with a good friend (who also loved it). Thank you again for this amazing gift, Tim.

Gigantic thanks to Matt (luttonm) for bringing this! A 2010 bottle I think. POured a black body with a brown head. As expected, pretty much opaque. Slightly salty dark malts and licorice in the aroma. Quite nice, but the taste... as it got warmer it evolved so brilliantly. Started off with fresh coffee, dry, lovely malty notes, light chicory and, hmm... light soy sauce (I don¬ít like that in beer)... but then raisins showed up, it was still dry. Then cocoa later on, getting smoother, damn soft, lovelier as it went. Definitely a great IS. Just lovely.

Pitch black beer. Good big brown head, holds good. Liquorish at the smell with coffee and chocolate. The liquor is less at the taste, good moderated bitter and sweet. Good dry bitter dark chocolate at the aftertaste. A lot going on in this taste. The booze gets trough also, more while warming up.

This thing is pretty hard to describe.  There are so many layers of favors it¬ís difficult to pick out.  There is booze, whiskey, brown butter, dark fruit, strawberry, wood, caramel, vanilla, etc.  really nice head retention as well.  Just, really fucking good.

Bottle from ¬í10.  Pour is jet black with dark chestnut brown head. Nose is dark chocolate and smooth coffee, light oak and licorice.  Taste is vibrant and bright, chocolate, molasses, faint licorice in the finish with a touch of dark chocolate lingering. Body is thick, soft and creamy, gentle carbonation.

2010 vintage, best after 11/15/11. 22 oz. waxed bottle served in a Deschutes snifter. Shared with some family on Christmas Day.

A: Do I even need to write this? Jet black body with a fluffy, two finger dark khaki colored head that has great retention that leaves minimal lace and heavy brown legs.

S: Very rich in the nose, but delicious. Molasses and licorice are there for the sweet presence and it is brought down to earth by the dark fruits and chocolate. Very minimal oak hovers in the background.

T: Wonderful. The oak shines through more in the taste than the nose. Dark fruits, bitter baker¬ís chocolate and some cocoa nibs are all present. Subtle coffee flavors peek up every now and then. The partial barrel flavors are wonderfully integrated and sit in the background. The very subtle bourbon just gives this beer another layer of flavor that is great.

M: Icredibly smooth and cream with a nice heavy body. Just enough carbonation to play with the palate, but not completely destroy it. Delicious chocolates and subtle oak linger long after the drink is consumed.

O: Well this is damn good. Very complex and the mouthfeel is spot on for the style. I¬íve got a 2011 waiting in the wings for another special occasion.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-27-2011

2011 bottle poured from a bomber very generously sent to me from Errl, into a brandy snifter. Thank you for hunting this one down for me! Pours a dark, dense black, nearing purple with just a thin tan head of foam resting atop. The aroma is so rich and complex with notes of licorice, molasses, dark chocolate, coffee, oak, bourbon, cherries, wine...holy shit this has a lot going on. The taste is just a continuation of the onslaught of awesome that the aroma so nicely indicated it would be. It¬ís earthy, roasty, warming, just a little sweet and so damn good. I can easily see why this beer is rated so highly. It truly is world class.
Last night was the night for infection the 09 abyss was 1 that I approch with some reserve alas the  vast rumors of infection turned out to be true and I was sorely disappointed

2008 Vintage, served for the family on Christmas, one of the most memorable beers I¬íve had

A: This motor oil....Abyss pours pitch black with a dark brown, almost purple, color head. Retention is really good for the ABV, but not amazing for the style

S: Molasses, caramel, toffee, lactose, TONS of fruit (dates, figs, apples)...really impossible to summarize, and anything I say won¬ít do it justice.

T: Whoa...like double rainbow shit! So complex...sweet, charred, smokey, nutty, woody (oaky), fruity, just wow. Absolutely tons of molasses. If you are reading this review for a reference, do yourself a favor and post an ISO thread instead.

MF/D: Perfectly viscous, creamy, velvety, super smooth. Carbonation is spot on, finish is lactose/awesomeness.

Notes: Truly remarkable. I really enjoyed this beer, and looking forward to acquiring another. Not over-hyped in my mind, and if you think so, I¬íll give you my address so you can ship it to me

As far as complexity...this is comparable to KBS for sure, but they are just too different from each other to compare in terms of which is better.

Sample at ABR.  
Black with brown head.  Nice sweet stout with plenty of roast.  Very smooth.
Had this at the 2012 Autumn Brew Review. Nice cola color with a tan head, the taste was quite boozy.

Just an awesome beer. We cannot keep this beer on the shelves. Probably because we drink it all! I look forward to it every year! Last time I had it was with a grilled Porterhouse steak, with a simple salt & pepper seasoning, and a baked potato. Divine.

Enjoyed at the brewpub on nitro while on vacation in the Pacific Northwest. Poured a thick, deep black with a cream head that hugged the glass. Taste was smooth and balanced with chocolate and coffee. A real treat!

Aroma- charcoal, oak, chocolate, barrel qualities, booze
Appearance- black with a tan head, lots of alcohol present
Taste- char upfront followed by barrel qualities, some chocolate, more roasted notes, slight alcohol presence on the backend
Palate- decent body, nice mouthfeel
Overall- Very nice brew here from Deschutes.  Slightly overrated IMO, but certainly tasty.

Pours a dense coal-black with a thin, wispy, mocha head on top. The nose is rich and sweet with plenty of vanilla, oak, chocolate, charred toast. Really nice. With a beer this big, I like a bit of depth in the feel. This one delivers. Heavy full-mouth with ample carbonation to back it up. Rich, velvety feel with an easy finish. There¬ís so much going on in this beer, it¬ís hard to stay focused. The vanilla makes a showing, but it is fleeting at best. The sweetness instead comes from the semi-sweet chocolate and toffee character. With such a small percentage of this seeing the bourbon barrels, I¬ím not surprised that that is downplayed as well. Mild spiciness on the back end, and a slight tart kick to finish this one out. Fantastic beer. One I was glad to trade for, and one I will hunt down again.

Black with good, creamy, chocolate shake head / Deep, muted, old nose of tobacco, coffee, oak, chocolate, and dark fruit / Medium to full body, chewy, moderately acidic, somewhat inky with good hop balance, and dry with fine, very bitter finish / Dark roast, somewhat astringent flavors of coffee, bittersweet chocolate, licorice, molasses, and caramel, with notes of coconut and dark fruit / There is a lot going on here, but it is somewhat masked by the strong burnt coffee character.  Minimal trace, if any, of  the cherry bark, bourbon, or vanilla.
Bottle thanks to Mar. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel malts. Beautiful black pour, with a nice tan top. Tasted oak, bourbon, vanilla, smoak, coco. So complex. Amazingness

Bottle shared at tasting.  Pours black with a small beige head.  Aroma is coffee in the forefront, with chocolate, vanilla, bourbon notes and light oak.  Flavour comes out fairly heavy sweet with light bourbon vanilla, oak and molasses up front, with a dark chocolate light to medium bitterness at the back.  The mouthfeel is thick and oily, very full bodied with no real carbonation.  I¬íve been excited to try this for some time, and now I am, it doesn¬ít disappoint.

66cl bottle shared with friends.
ok creamy tan head.  Clear dark pour.  Great tasting beer.  very smooth and complex at the same time.

Pours deep black with thin red-tan head. Aroma is sweet and rich, caramel, roasted malts, light coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor follows, rich, caramel, licorice, dark chocolate and smooth. Palate is solid, medium but I¬íd like a bit more. Overall, really nice

2010 Vintage (aged 13-14 months, poured into a tulip)

The beer pours a dark brown opaque body with a tan head that dissipated quickly. The head clings to the side of the glass, just by the pour you can tell it¬ís a rich thick beer.

The nose is light, some chocolate and coffee, with notes of vanilla in the nose followed by a tad of oak and bourbon.

Amazing flavor, just out of this world good and surprisingly complex. Filled with chocolate and coffee, there¬ís a touch of vanilla, licorice, a nice subtle oak-iness that gives the sweetness depth. Incredibly well-balanced smooth imperial stout.

A very full-bodied beer, the Abyss boasts in it¬ís rich creamy mouthfeel, almost like silk it¬ís so smooth. When paired with the complex flavor profile it just makes this one of my all-time favorite beers to enjoy after some aging.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2012 Bomber 2009 reserve. Pours oily pitch black with a nice creamy brown head leaving laces. Aroma is roasted malty has a slight brett character - not in a bad way though - tobacco slightly smokey dark fruits and licorice. Flavor is acidy roasted and a bit peppery in front, bitterness increases from middle with tones of licorice and very dark chocolate together with some vanilla and bourbon notes getting more sweet fruity bitter towards the end. Finish is quite different then, dry bitter and roasted. 

121120, Bomber @ DTTEOD. Pretty much as the 2009 but without the sourish bretty character. So robust in flavor yet balanced and flavorfull.
A nice brew. Flavors and aroma of oak, vanilla, anise, molasses, tobacco, chocolate, and roast. Pour is very black.

Bottle
Appearance - Black with a toffee-colored head
Aroma - Oak, raisins, bourbon, tobacco
Taste - Port wine, chocolate, coffee, cherries, vanilla, wood

This beer was as good as I expected. Lots of dry, oaky flavors and cocoa add character to the already dry body of the brew.

Bottle [2011], 22 oz.
Pours pitch black with high creamy dark beige/brown head. Intense lacing. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, wood (oak), coffee. Taste is of chocolate, roasted malt, sweetness, vanilla, dry-feelin¬í wood (oak), warming alcohol, coffee, molasses. Palate is very dry. Mouthfeel somewhat oily. Full bodied. Overall: very impressive Imperial Stout. Ougth to be respected.

A - Pours a dark black with a touch of brown around the edges and a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of roasted chocolate malts, oak, vanilla, molasses, cherry and other dark fruits with some licorice, Bourbon, wine, and a bit of booze.

T - Starts off with roasted chocolate malts with vanilla, cherry, molasses, and some licorice. Through the middle, some oak comes through with some Bourbon and wine and some more dark fruit flavor. The finish is a mix of roasted chocolate malts, oak, vanilla, wine grapes, molasses, and a bit of booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. The blend of barrels really adds a wonderful complexity to the beer and the balance is spot on.

Well, it can hardly get any better than this! Pours itch black, with medium creamy beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma: just wow! chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, roasted malt, coffe, wood (oak), alcohol, licorice, molasses... everything that makes a badass Imperial Stout! Taste is mostly about chocolate and vanilla. Sweetness goes along with slight roasted bitterness. Oily/creamy texture. Dry finish. Truly amazing one!

Bottle 2011 (22 oz). Thanks to SourNotes for this one! Pitch black with a thick creamy brown head and superb lacing. A beautiful beer! Aroma is amazingly complex with chocolate, wood (a lot), vanilla, roasted malt, liquorice, molasses, caramel and slight bourbon. Taste is about the same. Mouthfeel is creamy but oily. Warming alcohol. Huge imperial stout with an amazing complexity and great balance. A masterpiece!
2011 Reserve. Poured black from the bottle. Aroma with hints of fruit, spices and strong coffee. Rich and creamy. The Abyss is a MUST on very ones buck list.
140712. Bottle @APEX. Pours black with a nice brown head. Aroma nuts, roasted malts, chocolate. Smooth chocolate taste. Medium carbonation. Not Bad.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2014 65 cl bottle bought from Apex, Portland. Best after 15.11.2011.
Pours black color with a small off-white head. Very refined dry sweet sugar and cocoa with hints of cocoa. This seems to have managed the test of time very well, very subtle and refined brew with a lot to say. Excellent.

65 cl bottle @ Apex, Portland. 2011 vintage. Best after 04.08.2012.
Pours pitch black color of small beige head. Aroma of liquorice, dark toasted malts, chocolate, bourbon notes, tar and vanilla. Flavour of cocoa, vanilla, liquorice, espresso notes, dark ripe fruits, tar, salmiac and rye. Some mild oat notes also. Bitter and malty, sweetish chocolaty palate with a long sweet chocolaty finish. Superb.
6428

bottle [email¬†protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ black with a light brown head. aroma of licorice, dark chocolate. licorice and dark cocoa in the flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2014 
65 cl bottle vintage 2011 at APEX, "best after 4.8.2012"
Aroma has lots of cocoa, some vanilla and alcohol. Flavour is sweetish with cocoa, dark chocolate and some alcohol. Very dry finish. Too sweet and a bit too strong on alcohol, aging might really do the trick here.
8+4+8+4+15=3.9


65 cl bottle vintage 2010 @ lusikka 
Aroma has strong cocoa tones, some coffee and soy sauce. Flavour has soy sauce, cocoa and salty licorice. Too salty at first, but this settles afterwards. Fresh one was too sweet, this one is too salty. 

8+5+7+4+15=3.8


To conclude this: just too much salty licorice for my taste.

Bottle at home, Stockholm, Sweden. Probably one of the best Imp stouts in the world. Flavourful ass hell when room tempered. Black sin. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
2011 bottle.  Black pour with a small head.  Bourbon is present with vanilla and chocolate.  Only a little bit of coffee and just an absolute delight to drink.

Bottle to oversized snifter (2011 vintage).  Looks good; pitch black with low carbonation and booze-tinted lacing.  Smells good too; molasses, bourbon, sweet, and malty.  Tastes good; much like it smells.  A little thin though for this type of beer.  Still, pretty damn good!

Bottle at Aces and Ales, LV. 2011 vintage. Opaque, black liquid with small tan head. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, dark chocolate, pumpernickel, licorice, wood/oak, coffee, biscuit and dark fruit. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of bourbon, chocolate, oak and licorice. Full bodied with low to medium carbonation. Nice, balanced and quite licorice forward.

Vintage 2010. Heavy bourbon aroma, mixed with some licorice and dark fruits. Fresh, not too "heavy". Awesome flavors, lots of licorice , bourbon. Not any  heavy coffee notes, but big on the chocolate aftertaste. Pretty great

2010 Vintage. Stored at Cellar temp since release. Poured into a Tulip glass at cellar temp (59 Degrees). Allowed to breathe for 5 minutes before reviewing. 

A - Nice hiss while removing the cap. Poured a 2-Finger coffee & leather colored head. Head subsided to a quarter finger over 5 minutes and left behind a small film of bubbles. The beer was midnight black, semi-thick pour but not as oily as I expected. Decent head lacing, slight alcohol legs but nothing too intense. Expected for 11%

S - I can smell the beer from 2 feet away. Up close, I¬ím getting a big coffee with chocolate syrup scent. The licorice bombs out on the back of my nostrils leaving behind an intense milk chocolate sweetness. Hints of bourbon but nothing overpowering. 

T - Wow. Okay, I don¬ít quite know where to start. First taste is the bourbon followed by sweet vanilla and peppery licorice. I get this dry roasted almost biting chocolate espresso bean taste that fades away leaving behind an oaky chocolate sweetness that fades to a bitter oakiness over the course of about 30 seconds.

M - The mouthfeel is slick and surprisingly thin for an Imperial Stout. On  a very vigorous mouth swish, I only get about 30% carbonation mouth feel. Medium to heavy body and A super oaky sweet finish that reminds me a lot of cane syrup fresh from our farm.

O - This is a fantastic beer. The Imperial Stout category has seen a lot of changes in the last few years. Abyss holds its own against a lot of huge beers. Stoked to finally try this.

A: very near black, with a beige head and sticky, lingering lacing. Go figure...

S: Mellow bourbon, bitter chocolate, molasses, toffee, roasted malt.

T: Splendid, smooth BA stout. Bourbon and sweetness are subtle, and everything is balanced to perfection. The licorice adds a very interesting component to the overall flavor. There is a certain dryness in the finish. Slight alcohol detectable, more so in vintages that have not benefited from time in the cellar. Mouth-watering and delicious!

M: Great carbonation and balance. Smooth going down, this beer really coats your palate. What a joy to sip.

D: I could drink this until I fell over. Someday I may attempt this!

Notes: An exceptional beer. A must try.
2010 bottle. pours black with beautiful rusty head. aroma of brown sugar and some barrel. taste is not overly sweet lots of chocolate and burnt sugar

2007 Jet black with no head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, great balance. So good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber (2010 reserve). Pours black with minimal head. Aroma is bourbon, oak, chocolate and licorice. Flavor is all of the above with some booze. A little boozy but a great stout nevertheless.

This one was an interesting find. I kept it in my fridge for over a year,as it stated to wait until it reached the best after date. I guess I¬íll never know if that was actually necessary. This beer was uniquely deep, creamy and rich with leathery spice.

This is a very special beer.  If you don¬ít like Abyss, then you don¬ít like big stouts.  This stout pulls no punches and delivers.  Yes, it IS as good as very one says.  The alcohol is subtle but it will catch up with you.  The aroma is complex with tabacco, dark fruits and spices.  The mouthfeel is thick and very satisfying.  And the taste? Unbelivable!!  Only gets better the more you let it warm up and goes great with a nice cigar.

2010 Reserve, says the label.  Thanks to my cousin for breaking out this beauty.  Strong, yeasty porter aroma, with some flowers and coffee.  The flavor is complex, rich, potent, and multifaceted.  Flat, simple, black pour.  I tasted some bourbon and anise - the label says it was made with licorice and molasses, and it appears to be bourbon barrel aged too.  To me it seemed like a super-rich imperial porter.  Amazing brew!

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. 2007 vintage. Pours viscous dark brown/black color with brown head. Aromas of bourbon, roasted malts, chocolate, licorice, and wood. Bourbon and chocolate flavors with roasted malts and hints of licorice. Sweet molasses and vanilla with some sherry. The bourbon flavor is much more mellow than the aroma. Full body with minimal carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Excellent. Thanks Craig.
Lots of chocolate, coffe and a touch of licourice. Had too high expectations though..

First off, wow! This was highly talked about so I really wanted to try. This beer definitely stood up to its reputation. Pours dark and creamy with a thick head. As I drank it the head slowly ran down the glass. The look was dark and thick witha Carmel head. The taste was like heaven in a bottle. Very complex, sweet with oak notes and licorice. I want to say there was a bit of cinnamon as well.  Once it was room temp the flavors were more apparent.  The feel was very smooth and sticky.  Overall, this beer rates very high in my book. Can't wait till next years abyss. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650 ml bottle from 16th St. 2011 reserve. Pours black with tan/orange head, which sticks around for a bit. Aromas of rich chocolate, roasted malts and dark fruit. Creamy like a swig of hot chocolate. Bittersweet chocolate and espresso flavor. Nice roasted malts. Warm but well balanced.

2010 vintage.  Pours very dark and thick with a dark coffee head that is small but thick.  Aroma of raisins, dark fruit, licorice, molasses and chocolate.  Smooth and creamy chocolate and coffee with hints of dark fruit.  Almost silky in the mouth and very full bodied.  This isn¬ít the easiest beer to find, so if you like stouts grab a bottle of two if you see it.
Enjoyed in Peteluma with Jeff, Catina and Kaeti. Dark and complex, instead of identifying what¬ís in there, it was more interesting to find an IS aroma and flavor not un there.

Vintage 2010. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, liquorish, coffee, oak, vanilla and light soy. Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol, liquorish, coffee, chocolate, soy, ash, tobacco, light oak and vanilla.

Dark, silky and smooth. A soft creamy mouthfeel with a rich molasses taste. Hints of black licorice and coffee linger afterwards

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the St Louis Microfest.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a small tan head.  Coffee liquor aroma.  Taste is big with lots going on: molasses, licorice, foffee, and chocolate.  Sweet, complex and very strong.

66cl Bottle at AHBS, 2010 reserve. Black colour, beige head. Aroma of chocolate, light salty, liquorice, hard roasted malts, coffee, bourbon. Flavour is medium sweet, hard roasted malts, bourbon, dark fruits, oak, molasses, light salty liquorice, roasted bitter finish. Fullbodied. Very good.

I poured the beer into a wide mouth glass to drink.  The beer had a black body with an amber-brown hue around the edges, and had a smallish, foamy dark tan head with short retention but good cling and lacing.  Its appearance was somewhat watery; it did not have a thick or oily look.  The aroma featured roasty caramel malt with notes of vanilla, molasses and brown sugar, and also had some earthy hops for balance.  It tasted sweet and malty with flavors of caramel and vanilla, but also had some roasty earthy bitterness mixed with a bit of licorice and a subtle cherry bite.  The beer was fairly light with a thinnish body and low carbonation and fizz.  It had a clinging mouthfeel with a velvet softness that can only be described as "pillowy" and the presence of alcohol was almost nonexistent.  Excellent beer, many thanks to Eric for the delivery and sharing.

Poured from 22oz bomber to airplane and rainbow themed tippy cup:

Deep and dark, ominous black body. Dense brown froth that swells to the rim. Great lacing, even in the plastic children¬ís cup.

The nose is one of the best - cocoa, nutmeg, smoke, oak, faint licorice, molasses, vanilla, a lot going on here.

The taste is just as satisfying - big oak, warming booze, smoke, the finish is still a little hot.

I¬íd like to take a more in-depth look at The Abyss in the future but, as always, delicious.

Pitch black with a thick and lasting brown head. Intense coffee and dark chocolate aroma with a bit of licorice, some charcoal and alcohol. Very sweet dark flavour with licorice and roast malt/coffee/charcoal trying to play nice together. Not much hop character, but you sense a good bitterness. A bit of heat reveals the alcohol.

RATING # 10.000. 2010 Bottle. Tasting @ Home. Pours black with a small creamy head and lacings. Nose is heavy roasted. Mild bourbon, coffee, charcoal, liquorice. Quite vinous and complex. Flavor is hard roasted malts, coffee, liquorice, wood and mild bourbon. A bit of warmth.

Bottle. Couple years on this one either 08 or 09 at a tasting.  Darker malt flavor without a ton of chocolate but with a sweet vanilla or molasses flavor.  May be me but licorice comes to mind as well.  This bottle seemed very well rounded.

22 ounce bottle, poured a dark black color with aromas of dark roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, booze and some licorice.  Flavor is a blend of all the aromas, with some nice barrel characteristics, and some vanilla thrown in.  Really great beer, glad I have a few more bottles of this stuff laying around.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagan¬ís. Thanks beerandbeyond. 2011 Reserve. Pours opaque black with an amazing coffee like crema, aroma of coffee, bitter chocolate, forest fruit acidity, wood, wine and carobs, flavor of coffee, roast, smoke, dark chocolate, red wine, brandy, full bodied, zesty, well-made.

My 500th rating.  So I figured it would be very fitting to have a 5 year old version of a beer I have been looking forward to for a while.  So here goes: 2007 bottle.  Pours a deep black with an almost amber hue and dark tan head that disappears to a few bubbles on top, no lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted caramel malt, vanilla, anise, molasses, brown sugar, cream, and a nice mild bourbon.  Aroma is wonderful, so I have been really teasing myself and making my mouth water horribly.  So here goes...wow!  This is great... all too often I am disappointed with hyped imperial stouts and this one just lives up to the great billing and more!  The flavor matches the aroma well, which is great.  It has the right mild balance of bourbon and oak along with the other beautiful characters.  Mouthfeel is great with slight slickness.  This is great stuff!

2010 bomber, wax-sealed and labeled "best after 11.15.11," from a trade with Gription79.  Pours deep brown, very thick, and opaque in the glass.  A 3-finger creamy brown/mocha head sits on top, with nice retention and thick lacing left behind.  Aromas of rich bittersweet chocolate and cocoa, vanilla, coffee, and toffee.  Molasses and marshmallow, too.  The flavor is rich cocoa and molasses, brown sugar, licorice, and vanilla.  Bitter espresso and instant coffee, molasses, and bitter cocoa in the finish.  Creamy mouthfeel, with low carbonation and full body.  The alcohol is nicely hidden.  Really nice.  Thanks man!  [998]

2009 bottle I found in the corner of a little beer store a year ago.

Poured into a glass goblet. Pitch black with a half finger of tan head.

Rich smell of molasses, roasted malt and burnt wood.

The taste is a ride in the following order: malt, milk, burnt malt, alcohol heat, whiskey burn at the end. Amazing. Each taste blends with the next in a wonderful experience.

A crisper texture with a little cream to it. Almost no carbonation.

One of the most enjoyable of the imperial/barreled style that I have had. Great smell and taste without being a burden to drink.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2012 Bottle at Chriso¬ís Easter tasting 2012, thanks to deeblo. It pours jet black, with a thick tan head. The nose is cherry, blackcurrant, plum, roasted malt, sesame seed, soya sauce, coffee and liquorice. The taste is roasted malt, salted liquorice, caramel, charcoal, toast, coffee, tangy dark fruit, toasted sesame seed, soya sauce, chocolate and wood, with a dry, warming finish. Full body and moderate carbonation. Good balance. A well crafted imperial stout.

2010 Bottle Cellered till 4-6-12. Poured a Pitch black color,with a dark brown head. A complex aroma of dark malts, chocolate, coffee, liquorice and Dark fruit, also some oaky/Boozy notes. The flavor has notes of heavily roasted malts, balanced by a suitable sweetness, coffee and liquorice. somewhat dry finish. Perfect balance, not too sweet, just the right amount of bitterness. Medium to full bodied and the Alcohol was almost not detected. Damn near perfect.

2010 bottle...Pours pitch black with a medium dark mocha head...looks thick!..nice lacing!  Aroma is mildly boozy and very complex!...dark fruits, coffee, dark chocolate, and anise.  Flavor has anise and coffee foremost with molasses, dark chocolate, and nice charred woody notes.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy with a dry, roasty, lightly smoky oaky finish...awesome!

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagan¬ís. Thanks beerandbeyond. 2011 Reserve. Pours black with a dark, yellowish head. Dry wood, dark chocolate aroma. Tastes begins woody, then evolves to coffee, smoke, burning flavour. Long aftertaste, soft carbonation, heavy body. Awesome.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2012 2010 Bomber from The one and only Daken! Rich deep brown pour with a thin head. Lots of flavor featuring coffee, chocolate roastsy everything! fantastic thick pallet that is very long lasting.
What happens when I open the 2011?

Well I had the 2011 (9-6-12) and must say, it¬ís just as awesome as the 2010. Enjoy!

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2012 2011 Bottle. thick black with some caramel head. Lots of oak and what I¬íd call competing barrel flavors. Lots of chocolate and and coffee to go along with the wood flavors. No hint of alcohol. 

2009 Vintage: Opened July 10th, 2012. Thick black, tons of dark caramel head. Aroma is subdued bourbon, and anise. Flavor is dark chocolate and coffee, with hints of bourbon all the way through. Extremely smooth and easy drinking. It¬ís held up very well and isn¬ít even a little infected as some have said. The bourbon has aged out nicely and blended in to the final beer beautifully, and there is a subtle touch of leather that is fantastic. 

2008 Abyss:  opened 4/7/12.  some bourbon aroma, and some barrel. Has an aged smell which is great. Pours as thick a black as I¬íve seen. The flavors have mellowed due to the aging, but it is an impressive beer all around. Smooth thick mouthfeel, but not better than 2011.

Bottle at Alex¬ís - Thanks to myself ;-) Pours an opaque black with a diminishing beige head.Sweet with aromas of liquirish. Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Residual sugars. Notes of alcohol. Coffee notes. Full bodied. Medium to soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with medium frothy tan head. The arlma js chocolate and light roast. Thin mouthfeel with sweet roast, coffee, and chocolate. Easy to drink a very good Imperial stout from Deschutes.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2015 Pours black with a brown head. Nose has a lot of liquorice and roasted notes along with dark sweet fruits, caramel, molasses, butterscotch, sweet malty notes, very weak smoke, vanilla and some wood. Taste is very roasted with liquorice, dark dried fruits, weak salty or soy like notes, kinda smokey, molasses, vanilla, sweeter malts, some coffee appears here and some hops in the back. You can also feel the barrel quality here.

Rich black color; Heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, oak, chocolate, & coffee; Flavor of roasted malt, oak, rich dark bittersweet chocolate, coffee, caramel/molasses, hops, and some licorice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced & complex; The alcohol is well hidden; Overall, this is basically motor oil - but dam good!

Bottle 22 oz, trading. 2009 version. So, flip a coin: that¬ís the issue with year 2009. Infected or not? You should open it, no way. And... mmm, sweared against the entire creation and universe after uncapping. Acid and oxidation, so bad. But I thought hope wasn¬ít lost, so I stood still. Waiting. Waiting. Waiting. And after five minutes, wind turned. A MASSIVE roasted, burned malt and coffee notes rose, it was the beginning of the show. Plus wood, chocolate, cocoa, smoke, ashes, vanilla, butter, bourbon. Then the pouring: an espresso. Black as 1000 ft deep pit, creamy and almost yellow-beige foam. Spectacular. Body is full and thick, powerful but not annoying or like a brick in your stomach. It has the strengthness of malt, the sweetness of molasses. Both candy and burned sugar, bourbon again, red wine, SO MUCH coffee, caramel, oak. Overall is great, in particular the perfect clash among the bourbon elegance and the hardness of malt and oak. Between that, molasses and licorice doesn¬ít ruin the show. No boring, no boozy. Warms mouth. Finish is totally dominated by licorice, like chewing the classic candy wheels. So, another big IRS add to my notes. Verily, I had 2008 version and remember not so much (was after too many beers...); but I state that a younger version is better since - according to my memories, at least - bourbon vanishes after years; wasn¬ít so present. So, my suggestion is having with max 2 years aging.
A masterpiece, hard to have - better shared - but extremely pleasant.
Want a comparison? Well, imagine blending the Black Tuesday with a top-class coarse European IRS like Amager Hr. Fredriksen or Nogne IS. And be swallowed up by the Abyss: Nietzsche was right! :)
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 Aroma amaderado, chocolate y caf√© tambi√©n. Sabor a malta torrefacta, chocolate, caf√© y melaza.

Bottle from GBBF 2011 and drunk in March shared with AndrewC.  Hugely chocolatey on  the aroma.  Normally I¬ím not a huge liquorice but I don¬ít get a lot on this.  Espresso coffee.  It¬ís pretty decent if a little papery, newspapery on the really dry roasted malt. Some heat on the end, some alcohol.  Some dark berry fruit on the finish.  Not much hop, some sting.  Some bourbon does come through eventually.  Touch of vanilla too.  Mostly coffee and choc though.  Yes this papery vanilla flavour on some mouthfulls isn¬ít great. Quite oily.

bottle thanks RasmusOtt.  Pours pitch black no head. Aroma: savory notes, soy, salty caramel, dusty, light smoke, ham, floral, roasted, chocolate, vanilla,  oak, butterscotch, lakridskonfekt, liquorice, smells so good!! syrup, molasses, earthy, sweet coffee, nutty, browned butter, some alcohol, bourbon notes, Taste: Low carbonation, chocolate, vanilla, salty caramel, grassy, some bitterness, coffee, earthy, some alcohol burn, grape rind, roasted bitterness, resin, floral, dark syrup, molasses, liquorice, oak, bourbon, fresh cut grass, plant sap, dried fruits, figs, prunes, plums, raisins,

okay so another one of my favorites...I am a chick so I don¬ít usually describe it all, but hands down something I look forward to every year. Love the flavor!  I don¬ít actually mind the black licorice in this, but not a big fan of that in real life. A must try if you love dark beers with a lot of character!

2008 vintage on tap.  Black pour with fairly light head considering.  Nose is a bit smokey with notes of burnt wood, barrel, roasted malt, and coffee.  Taste is also smokey and woody but light on the sweetness I was expecting.  Would actually like to taste a more recent version to compare.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Holy moly, if you like stouts this is the way to go. So rich, sweet, dark, and amazing...many years of happiness to come with this one.
Deep roasty malt hot red wine, sweet and bitter, pine tree, not too pleasant. Has a good dry sweetness, fruity and spicy. The flavors are sharp and standout.
Shared 22oz 2011 vintage bottle. Solid mocha, coffee notes, chocolate, brown sugar, roasted malt notes. Creamy notes, roasted malts, touch of hops, anise.

22 oz. Bottle. plucked from the cellar after a year.  Pours black with a dirty head. A nose of amazing complexity and as smooth as they get. Flavor bombardment of coffee, Brown sugar, Alcohol, oats...Good lacing. Haven¬ít found a better finish yet. Smooth. Perfect Balance!

From notes.  First reviewed 2/9/2011.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a tulip. 2010 version.

This pours somewhere between mahogany and black, with a ruby walnut corner in the middle. A creamy brown cap sits on top, fading to a few islands after a short while and leavin a few spots of lace.

Roasted malt, dark chocolate, anise, smooth mild coffee, and a bit of earthy hops. Great balance and depth in the aroma.

The roasted malt and espresso are the first two flavors to hit my palate. A little bit of dark chocolate integrates well with anise, vanilla, and oak. There are some earthy hops that blend well with the anise as well. The end of each sip warms the stomach. 

I felt like this got a bit syrupy, which is the only true detractor for me. It has a huge body, a great creaminess, but the light carbonation contributes to the syrupy feel for sure. There is some light residue that sits on the tongue afterward.

This reminds me of Stone¬ís IRS in how balanced it is. Not a coffee or chocolate bomb, Abyss simply presents a variety of enjoyable flavors to you, one after another, letting them integrate over time. A very relaxing sipper.

Pours black with a slight head that lingers until the finish. It smells of roasty/chocolate malt with coffee-ish notes. The flavor has similar characteristics, but with some dried, cocoa in there as well. It¬ís not too sweet and is fairly balanced for the strength and style. The body isn¬ít as heavy as I thought it might be considering the strength. All around a great beer.

Pitch black with a very dark brown head that settles very quickly. Smell is mainly brown sugary sweet, along with oak, and licorice notes. As it warms i notice increasing amounts of cocoa. Taste is surprisingly more chocolate/cocoa than i expected, along with toasted malt, and faint licorice flavors. Nicely done.

Reviewed from notes.  Poured from a bottle into a CBS snifter.

A.  Pours a deep dark black, 1mm of rich full head, takes a minute to work it¬ís way down to a thin layer, finally settling at a nice thick ring.

S.  Smells of dark chocolate, slight toffee and heavy oak tones with slight vanilla.

T.  Tastes of dark chocolate, heavy malts, tobacco, and smoked oak.

M.  Heavy body, super thick and chewy, lower carbonation, slightly coarse finish.

O.  A great beer.  This is really a beer that tastes it¬ís best around 55 degrees.  It¬ís not nearly as good when cold.  Lots of bold flavors in a thick and hearty drink.  A great beer that gets even better with age.  And really hard to beat at $13/bottle.  Worth searching out.

Poured on tap into snifter. Crude oil black with a huge brown head that doesn¬ít fully dissipate. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Flavor is sweeter than most other imperial stouts, perhaps from the molasses. The licorice is a note in the background. Great malty flavor with a nice long finish. Pretty thick mouthfeel. Great beer.

It poured a dark brown/black color with a small tan head. The aroma was somewhat bitter and sweet with hints of chocolate. The taste was very malty with hints of vanilla, chocolate and coffee.  A very good Imperial Stout.

Appearance was blackish  1 finger  lasting head and little lacing. Aroma was full of sweet roasty smoky malts with hints of alcohol. Taste was sweet caramely with some heat of alcohol.Mouthfeel was malty,light on carbonation with warmth of alcohol. The body was super with lots going on warming alcohol . Love it ...(2011) Thx Aces & Ales

Poured pitch black with very little head. Smelled of chocolate and coffee. Tastes a little sweeter than some imperial stouts I¬íve had. Not too much of the coffee comes through in the taste. It¬ís very smooth on the palate for such a strong beer.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2015 Thanks to Savvy for the bottle. 2011. Beer is dark black and appears thick. Carbonation is mild. Beer is completely opaque even at the corners. Forms a thick and aggressive dark brown head that falls away relatively quickly leaving a lot of lacing on the glass. The resultant head is thin and diffuse and eventually breaks. A visage of the original head hung out in the middle of the glass for the duration of the beer. The aroma is complex. There is a lot of sweetness, brightness, some alcohol, a lot of roast, malt and coffee, almost a syrup but not cloying aroma as well. There is a hint of anise in there as well. Beer is medium to full bodied. Late roast taste followed by a strong aftertaste of bitterness and roasted malt. Definitely some espresso character. I was expecting a little bit of bourbon but got none. I did however get some warmth from the alcohol in the front of the mouth along with considerable gravity and sweetness.
Update: 2013 drank July 2015.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2015 Sample at Central Waters anniversary party.  Super thick pour of deep black with big yellow/orange head.  Heavy roast, coffee, chocolate aroma.  Didn¬ít pick up much bourbon.  Flavor is deep roasted malt, coffee, light molasses, vanilla, oak, and a hint of bourbon.  Mild sweetness in the finish.  Heavy as hell on the palate.  Grainy roast finish.  A real treat.  Re-rate:  lots of cherry character.  Good, palate thinner than I remember.  Still solid but a step back. -3
Uh, wow. Deschutes really knows dark beers. The chocolate-y flavor and molasses are great. Nice dark brown head, thick brew. Great stuff.

2011 reserve from a 1pt 6oz brown bottle with black wax on top, offered by Julien and Pierre-Luc. A young beer that is best after 8/4/2012. Thick dark black-brown ale with a nice brown head. A very complex empiromatic nose with some coffee, vanilla (oak), nice smokiness and balsamic vinegar. This ale is long, round and velvety. It¬ís easy to find tobaco, coffee, smoke and a hop finale that taste like dust. The rostiness of the malt brings out good flavor. Not an easy drinking beer, it¬ís a sipping beer to share with friends.

Holy shit.  Black as the molasses it¬ís brewed with.  DENSE foam.  Aroma of chocolate and bourbon. Chocolate and tobacco with a bourbon middle and finishes quite bitter and dry.  What an exceptional beer for #500!  Move over expedition.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2013 Pours thick and black with mocha head and beautiful lacing. On the nose I got black licorice and roasted coffee beans. Mouthfeel is slick and full. Black licorice, a bit of malty sweetness, dark chocolate, and espresso. Some nice bourbon booziness and a great creamy finish. Amazing stuff.
pours a pitch black with a large brown head. smells malty and cocoa. Taste is amazing. very balanced yet complex. tons of chocolate, molasses and cofee with a touch of licorice.
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2012 Had on tap in Streets of London is sacramento. Great stout. taste was chocalate, some coffee. creamy flavor. probably the best stout ive had.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2015 (*reserve 2010): Le moment parfait se pr√©sente, p√™che sur la glace en bonne compagnie dans un froid mordant. La bouteille f√ªt aussi parfaite. Hand-bottled sample from cgarvieuk. Thanks! Pitch black, viscous pour, even kept some brown head despite the hand-bottle. Gorgeous, massively rich nose - molasses, dark chocolate, treacle, roast malt, slightly salty/oaky savoury streak too. Wow. Just off-dry front, hint of milk chocolate in the body, some leather, big woody coffee finish. Excellent.

Pours dark as night with a 1/2 finger super dark carmel head. Aroma is of dark semi sweet chocolate and vanilla Carmel. The taste is so damn complex. Crazy amounts of chocolate, coffee, bourbon, etc. It goes on and on. Just a freaking awesome imperial stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour is a black with a small tan head.  Aroma is a decent roasted malt with rich almost chocolate cake.  Flavor is a heavily roasted malt, some chocolate/vanilla and black currant.  This was a very tasty beer and easy to sip on as there was no alcohol noticable.

On tap. Pours a very dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted coffee, cocoa / dark chocolate, brown sugar, licorice / anise, and molasses. Taste profile is similar, though the vanilla flavor from the Bourbon barrels comes through more on the tongue. Heavier on the molasses / licorice profile than cocoa / chocolate. Tasted oak too. Alcohol content is high but well masked. an exceptional beer.
2011 vintage, pitch black with a finger of tan head. Aroma is fruity. Taste lots of roasted malts and coffee, some dried fruit.  Good beer, but I think I was expecting a little more.

Sample thanks to Craig. Black with good tan head. Chocolate and ovaltine aroma, little licorice. Taste is very mellow, chocolate and roastiness, some licorice. Sweet with a bitter finish. Well balanced

2011 vintage.  Not much changed from the 2010 version.  For the style this one looks quite good. Black, completely so, with a nice dark brown head that lasted a bit, leaving plenty of lacing.  Smell is of plenty of dark, roasty and burnt malts, licorice, dark fruits, anise. Wood and bourbon are also present.  Taste is damn spectacular, I dare say the perfect tasting American Double stout has been found! Bold roasted malts and ample bourbon come through first, followed by tangy anise and licorice, woody notes, vanilla, and dark fruits. There¬ís some dark chocolate and espresso notes in there too. Extremely complex, flavorful and delicious. A bit of alcohol comes through, but this is expected for the style and ABV.  Mouthfeel is very thick, smooth, with silky carbonation and a lingering bitterness. Alcohol warms on the way down.  Drinks quite well. A damn fine beer that¬ís fully worthy of all the hype.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 pretty damn close to perfect beer. immediately noticed the best by date had been replaced by a best after date. i bet this would be super amazing after the date, but if i had another i wouldnt be able to save it. beautiful complexity comes through. slight oak, vanilla, toffee, big roast. smooth slight bourbon, different tastes each drink. amazing

Pour is pick black with a finger wide bubbly tan head. The bubbling is a bit larger than I would have liked but it leaves nice lacing along the glass. The aroma is outstanding, sweet but not overly so. Huge roasted barley notes with milk chocolate and oak chips. The taste is complex, but honestly a tad thin. Notes of roasted barley dominate the flavor and it ends in a nice bitter hops finish to balance it out.

Bottle (2010). Pours dark brown with thin tan head; spare lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, brown sugar, and toffee. Flavor matches the nose with some earthy hop undertones. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2014 Jan 2012: 2011 bottle. Dark brown with a brown head, not much retention. Powerful roasted malt aroma. Dark chocolate, coffee, dried fruit, hops. A pretty awesome beer.
December 2014 aged 2011 bottle. I get more anise this time. I don¬ít think I¬íll adjust the score any but this is still a great beer fresh or aged.
Lovely smokey aroma. Beautiful dark colour with a frothy head. The flavour is deep and rich with a lingering bitterness, which is a bit much for me, but I acknowledge this is a finely made beer.

2011 Reserve. 22 oz bomber into an over sized wine glass at cellar temperature. 

A - Pitch black body. Dark brown 2 finger head. Tons of sticky lacing and crazy retention.

S - Lots of roasty and oak aromas. Tobacco, smoke, leather, licorice, chocolate and some vanilla. More savory than sweet. There is a certain aroma that is rather dominant but I can¬ít put a name to it. Perhaps its the cheery wood?

T - Very complex stout. Chocolate and coffee notes followed by some licorice, vanilla, and heavy roast flavors. The oak aging is present as well. Nice medium mouth feel that supports these huge flavors. Alcohol is warming but pleasant.

O - I think I prefer sweet to roasty/savory, but this was a very delicious and complex beer. Glad I traded for this one. Great stuff!
Pours a nice, dark, oily black with small frothy head. Roasted malt aroma, with some coffee, chocolate. Flavor is coffee, licorice, chocolate, some fruitiness in the background. Bitter finish.

2010 Bottle. Pours near black with a firm tan head and good lacing. Big big aroma that belies the bourbon treatment, along with chocolate.and caramel. Flavor is intensely sweet, with a bit of the oak and vanilla from the barrels. Nice heft to the body.
