Delicious, complex, the alcohol flavor has mellowed and complements the dark malts. WIth great profiles all around this beer is worth it. Its on the high end as far as complex flavors go. WIth a thick mouthfeel that complements the rich flavor. The hints of all the oaks make a complex beer even complexer (sic). THat is why that when it goes down so smoothly you are even more amazed. Well done Deschutes, I have liked your porter but this beer is wonderful.
650ml bottle. 2010 Reserve. Black with small brown head. Oily texture. Vanilla, coffee, liquorice. Heavy. Wonderful stuff.

Bottle:
2010 reserve:
It starts with the pour, pitch black, motoroil. Than it starts growing with a nice brown head.
Medium to smaller vast brown head on top of a pitch black beer. Looks good and promissing.
Smell hops, liquorice, some roasted malts, hint of molasses, not much else to be smelled. Nicely, soft and smoothly balanced.
Taste is a good liquorice and vanilla mix. Roasted malts, vanilla, coffee, liquorice, medium bitter, soft and smooth. Really good and smoothly balanced. Deep and pretty intense.
Nice roasted aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft almost silky mouthfeel, full body and a good creamy almost oily texture.
Another damn good imperial stout. Delicious!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Amazing beer. Sweet and roasty with chocolate and oak. The cherries are amazing and its my favorite vintage

2011 reserve bottle.  Thick dark pour, dark head lingers a while.  Wonderful aroma of molasses and burnt malt.  The flavor follows the aroma and coats your tongue, lingering for a long time without turning bitter.  Amazing.
Bottle. Pours an oily body with a small brown head. Powerful body with vanilla, chocolate. Sweet taste, albeit not over the top. Really maginificent beer, an examplary ris.

¬í10 bottle courtesy of dcschiller. Pours jet black with a thin tan head that sticks around leaving a little lacing. Aroma is Chocolate, coffee, vanilla. Flavor is much the same with a little coconut in the finish. Body is full, and smooth. Absolutely loved this!

A very sought after brew in the world of craft beer for a reason. The Abyss has everything I¬ím looking for in a world class RIS. Great aroma, phenomenal appearance and mouthfeel with a complex and delicious flavor profile. I love this beer and will enjoy it a lot more once it has been hanging out in my cellar for a year or so...if I can wait that long. If you haven¬ít ever tried Deshcutes¬í "The Abyss"....what are you waiting for? Get some enjoy it, love it. I certainly do....
Dark black with a big brown head. Aroma of molasses, licorice, chocolate and vanilla. Taste is medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation.

Bottle to glass. The aroma has lots of dark chocolate to it as well as a but of coffee and a hint of dark fruit. Or maybe its more molasses. Either way, the aroma is awesome. It¬ís a very thick, heavy bodied beer with a black-brown pour. It also has a small tan head to it as well. The finish is slightly bitter, but has a lot of chocolate to it. 

Awesome beer. Not quite my favorite imperial stout, but a darn good one.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2014 12-28-11. This is an incredible dark beer. Never had anything as dark. The film alone on the glass leaves a dark amber residue. There is a heavy molasis flavor, light carbonation with nice thick brown head. (7-28-14 josh- 10.0)

Bottle. Pours black with a brown head. Very intersting aroma! Notes of oboy, vanilla, coffee and something salt. The taste is thick and vinous, with notes of dark chocolate, liquor and licorice. Although the taste is enjoyable I can¬ít really find the same magic and complexity in the taste, as I did in the aroma. Overall: Very good!

Bottle.
Very nice brew, complex taste with chcolate and licorice. Very heavy but still smooth and drinkable.

Bottle of 2011 reserve with Carla. Pours a dark brown/black with mocha foam. Smells bitter and sweet with hints of chocolate. Taste super malty with hints of vanilla, chocolate and coffee, ends with slight alcohol burn.

Pours like motor oil. Really slick oily mouthfeel. I have had this beer after some aging but had this one fresh and it had some really strong piney hoppiness to it. Lots of bitter chocolate, molasses, and some dark fruit to it. Always interesting.

Black with a small golden brown head. Aroma is coffee, oak, vanilla, soy sauce. Taste is chocolate, coffee, vanilla, licorice, oak. Mouthfeel is slightly slick. Good body, boozy finish with a hint of bitterness. Pretty well balanced. An enjoyable imperial stout with lots of character.

650ml bottle pours black in color with at least 2 fingers of thick tan head which leaves some really nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is roasted malts and chocolate with hints of licorice and alcohol.  Taste is roasted malty bitterness with some sweetness from the chocolate and malts.  There is very little hops and a trace of oak as well.  Heavy bodied and nicely carbonated.  This is a truly complex brew that I was very satisfied with.

Tap at pracna on main. Pours Dark oily black with a khaki head. Very soft aroma. Just mere hints of coffee, roasted malt, some molasses sweetness. Pretty tame. Some slick, sticky molasses hits first with notes of anise, wet wood, bitter chocolate, and roasted malt. Nice body on this one. There¬ís almost an oats quality on this with how chewy it is. Finish is charred ash and sticky sweet malt with a little heat. A tad but of time on this would help.

Pours like black sludge and a has a small toast colored head. Aroma of licorice and molasses. Additional flavor notes include bitter chocolate and roasted malt. Good carbonation, very viscous, and plenty of lingering warmth. Tough to find anything to criticize.
The carbonation on this one is a little to noticeable. Twas a deeply complex taste with prune/ strawberry/ nutty/ coffee like flavor. worth the cellaring!

I¬ím pleasantly surprised by this beer¬óit¬ís much more complex than I thought it¬íd be. The aroma mostly speaks of dark chocolate, but there¬ís a lot more going on than just that. There¬ís vanilla, a bit of caramel and molasses, some coffee, and also dark fruits. Nearly perfect. The taste starts sweet from the molasses, then it hits you with cocoa-like bitterness, and ends with a somewhat fruity sour feel to it, and also a weird skunk (not fully unpleasant, though). Lots of heat throughout (it is 11% abv after all), but no smell or taste of alcohol. Weird, but that¬ís the impression I had. The palate is sticky and mildly carbonated.

Draught, 2008 vintage at CityBeer. Pours opaque black with a tan head. Smells of espresso, chocolate, some bourbon, and alcohol.
Tastes of espresso, creamy chocolate with a hint of bourbon and oak. Texture is creamy. Full bodied.

Its good, but could have been better.

Bottle. 2011 vintage. I¬íve had Abyss multiple times but I¬íve never sat down and really rated it before. I tried with the 09 but that was a huge, infected fail. Moving on... Pours a deep, dark brown color with a nice mocha tan 2 finger head. Head leaves nice lace as it settles down in the glass. Dark chocolate, coffee, mocha, vanilla, it smells nice and rich. Medium mouthfeel, velvety. Smooth sweet upfront with a nice roast coffee and dark chocolate back end. Lingering bitterness. The oak is there but to me is pretty subdued. A nicely balanced, solid beer.

On tap at the Blue Nile. Pours a very deep brown with a finger of sudsy, light brown head. Aroma is French roast coffee, cocoa heavy dark chocolate, brown sugar, licorice, and molasses. Taste profile is similar, though the vanilla flavor from the Bourbon barrels comes through more on the tongue. Heavier on the molasses/licorice profile than the typical chocolate/coffee profile of some other imperial stouts. A nice change of pace. I must say, the alcohol content is very high but it¬ís well masked. The palate is a hair off . . . this is a heavy beer but the alcohol content renders the beer a bit "zippier" than I would like . . . still, overall an exceptional beer.

Bottle, from the 2010 maltage. Pours a thick, opaque brown-black with a fine cinnamon head. Nose is vanilla, espresso, grape/raisin, cherry, and burley tobacco. Almost port-like in its complexity on the tongue; very bitter in the mid-palate (espresso/licorice), but closing sweet and smoky. I find the palate a bit of a disappointment; I wanted more richness in the mouthfeel. Good, and worth it, but not the best.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2017 flavors meld to waves of joy andall I want is more. damn this is good. not even a big stout fan. 11%? Are you kidding? easier to drink than water. (should say it is a 2010 that was consumed). why O why did I not buy more. oh yeah, because it flew off the shelves. maybe I will grab more 2011 before it goes away.

An awesome imperial stout. Great frothy brown head, nice roasty, toasty, caramel, chocolate - the flavors go on an on.

Really hard to beat for a commerical imperial stout. My only complaint is that the bourbon and oak flavors are not there as much as they should and could  be.

Nice, but not the best I¬íve ever had for the style. The bourbon was very faint, and the oak wasn¬ít real prominent. The licorice absolutely dominates this flavor profile, and there¬ís also flavors of blackberry and raisin really strong in this. It was quite nice, but for the style was not real exciting. Quite tame.
This is great stout, very well done Imperial stout. I wish i could drink this everyday. I nice tough of bourbon makes this one of my favorite stouts!

Draft at Capone¬ís. Pours a pitch black with a thin mocha head. Aroma is very barbecue sauce. kind of a neat flavor for a brew. Taste is reminiscent of a smokey barbecue sauce. More with the coffee aspect of a stout that the other  components of a stout.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2012 Around December of 2011. In a growler from Chuck¬ís 85th Market, 2011 vintage. Pours a nice head. Two finger, tan head. Completely black. Aroma was so inviting. Chocolate, strong coffee, vanilla, so much going on, this was amazing. Taste is incredible. Chocolate, coffee, vanilla, molasses, caramel...so many sweet flavors and yet they still have the powerful flavors of a regular imperial stout. Says it is best aged, and it does get better, but it¬ís also drinkable fresh. Mouthfeel goes down so easy, still very carbonated, but I can tell that this becomes better with age. Very viscous, and lingers well. This is incredibly drinkable. This is still easily in my top 3 of all time. Delicious, drinkable (and completely masking an 11 percent), and the favorite style of beer on this sight. I know this is a Winter Seasonal, and hard to get, but this is an amazing beer. Great great great imperial stout, everyone should try this at some point.

August 12th Re-rate with a 2010 on tap from Mutiny Hall for the opening. Pours black with a finger head. Smell is caramel chocolate and molasses. Taste is thick syrup, chocolate, molasses, sweet but not cloying. Still fantastic.

2010 bottle drunk after the best after date. Pours a pitch black color with a tan roasted looking head. Super complex aroma with roasted malt, molasses, dark fruits, oak, bourbon, vanilla, coconut, salty notes from the bitterness, dark chocolate, coffee and some liquorice. The flavor is again very big, with lots of deeply roasted and lightly burnt notes, some peppery notes, oak, bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, whiskey soaked raisins, molasses, coconut, salty flavors, dark chocolate, liquorice, coffee, some burnt caramel and sugar notes. The body is full with a creamy mouth feel. Overall a really good Imperial Stout, I would have liked some more sweetness, but you might get that in a fresh bottle, other than that this has aged very well.

Wow.  The richness and complexity of this is astounding.  Tastes of port, licorice and molasses with a foundation of chocolate.  Dark as night pour.  Bought and shared in Tempe, AZ with Nick, Josh W., Josh N., and our hosts.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2015 Had a 2009 bottle previously I will give them a chance of redemption. 2010 bottle.

It pours a deep, rich black with a frothy, creamy dark brownish tan head that sparkles with bubbles and eventually leaves beautiful ringed lacing on the sides of my snifter. It sure looks great.
Had a 14 and 13 on draft recently, too much tartness, downgraded.
It has a thick-smelling molasses, caramel, and chocolate bonanza. There is some nice biscuity scent in there as well. The oak comes in slightly with oakiness and some vanilla. Roasted malts and coffee round out the scent profile. The one thing I¬ím missing in the scent is the advertised licorice. It surprisingly smells very similar to last year, minus the hint of sourness.

The flavor is very nice. This is a rich, robust stout with plenty of bitterness unlike some of the other big-name stouts. Lots of bitter cocoa, roasted malt, and coffee, it just comes in waves. The barrel aging doesn¬ít present itself as much in the flavor. There is some oak flavor but not an oaky smoothness. It is woody but in a way that accentuates the bitterness. It could be just because this stout is so much more bitter than its counterparts. Usually you see the oak melding with the sweetness creating a smooth, rich flavor. This one instead opts for a woodsy bitterness. I love it. Plenty of hops too. The sweetness is there though. It creeps up on you, most of it is chocolate. It isn¬ít too harsh with the alcohol, but you can feel it is a pungent brew. The things it lacks in the flavor though are bourbon and licorice, but maybe they just blend in so well that I don¬ít notice them.
 
This one stands tall in the imperial stout category. I think the reason people love it is it doesn¬ít get over the top with the sweetness.

This is the 2010 vintage, best after 11/15/11. One day after the best after date - 22oz into small tulip.
caramel, bakers chocolate and a lot of molasses with a bit of oak. Had one of these about 2 weeks after it hit shelves and it was much hotter, loads of booze in the nose and the taste.  Here everything smells smoother, easily identifiable characteristics that blend nicely.
Looks very nice, a bit too much fizz in the head, and leaves little once it settles.
light sweetness and lightly bitter with a nice amount of booze, the finish is all bakers chocolate.
I thought this was too boozy when I had it the first time, but the degree to which the bourbon has faded is unfortunate. With a touch of bourbon and oak in the aroma, I would have expected more in the taste and a nice booze bite in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2011 2009 bottle (not an infected one - lucky!) One of the best beers I have ever had. Pours black with a nice tan foam. Smells of chocolate, coffee, just like it should. The flavor takes this beer to a whole new level. Rich dark chocolate, vanilla, dark roast coffee, touch of anise and a delicate bourbon hiding in the background. One of the best beers out there. Definitely worth sitting on for a year... or two... or three. Aging nicely, looking forward to this years release.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2015 Date: October 29, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Blue Nile. Full description not available as I was sampling many beers as part of a tasting event.

Had this again March 28, 2015 and dropped aroma, taste and overall down by 1 each to get to a 4.1.  This was a 2012 bottle at the Rare Beer Fest.

I don¬ít think enough can be said about this beer.  It is literally one of the most complex beers I have ever had the pleasure of enjoying.  I tried this for the first time at a beer tasting back in March, then got to try a bottle all to myself (choosing not to share)!  The beer pours an deep, rich, inky black color almost like motor oil.  It sure seems to have a similar viscosity.  No light penetrates this beer; it¬ís like a black hole.  A toasty, brownish head forms up like a film atop the beer and sticks with it all the way to the bottom, leaving a beautiful web of lacing.  Once I let it sit for about ten minutes in a footed tulip glass, the beer was giving off lush and deep aromas of bourbon, oak barrel, bitter cocoa, soy sauce and black coffee.  On the palate, the beer follows up and rounds out the nose with hints of molasses, dark fudge, light espresso, chocolate cake, oaky whiskey, anise, dark fruit and a burned, caramelized sugar taste like the brittle coating on a creme brulee: WOW.  The finish is luscious yet not cloying, with a delicious smokiness cradling some wood and mocha.  Overall, this beer is unfathomably complex and a real treat to drink.  A++

2010 Reserve. Incredible beer, after I finally broke through the wax and got the damn thing open. The beer poured black with a small brown head that reminded me of the Speedway Stout. You could tell there was already a lot of stuff going on in this beer. Aroma had coffee, chocolate, roasted figs and  a mild sweetness to it. The taste was even better, extremely rich.  The first thing I noticed was the sweetness. Almost candy-like with caramel and molasses. The coffee notes came through  with cocoa and some vanilla. The flavor was so busy it¬ís hard to keep describing. Extremely rich with ultra long finish. Mad that I had only one bottle but I got to share it with a good buddy who was blown away by it. Definitely will stock up on the 2011 Reserve.

2010 vintage.  From the pour it is clear this is one hell of an imp stout, pitch black, oily body with fluffy brown head.  Aroma is strong and multifaceted, with notes of oak, burnt sugar, red berry, wood chip, lactose, soil, cocoa.  Flavor produces a much greater chocolate sensation, dark, rich, and bitter, with notes soft notes of oak and bourbon and a long finish, a little bit of heat.  Overall pretty fantastic.

2010 @ Stub and Herbs "Darkness Eve"- Very fine imperial stout. Very smooth with a bit of a burn at the end. Dark and viscous. Molasses, chocolate, coffee, barrel,  and black licorice. In my mind, second to KBS ¬í10, but still very awesome.
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2012 This beer is phenomenal. Dark, smooth, complex, at first sniff you know this is something special. It just gets better from there...

2009 Bomber poured into an Appalachian mini-pint.
A - Pours dark as night with a small brown head that dissipates to only a few patches of head and a ring around the outside of the glass, leaving only spotty lacing.
S - Rich coffee, molasses, licorice, and chocolate notes. As it warms more and more booze comes thru. No hints of infection in this one. I must have gotten lucky.
T - Lots of deep roasted flavors up front slowly giving way to hints of chocolate, coffee, and other dark, earthy, flavors. Finish is pretty hot from all the booze with a lingering roast. Flavors were pretty well balanced but the heat from the alcohol is a bit much after a few glasses. I enjoyed this one but not as much as I did when I had it on-tap during philly beer week. 
M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Strong burn from the booze with a heavy roasted finish. It was a bit overwhelming after a few fills of my glass.
D - Fairly high. Opened this one last night. I figured if it was infected I would rather find out now rather than later. Luckily it was fine. I enjoyed this one a lot. It was still a little too hot for my liking but it was still very nice.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2012 Bomber all alone. 2010 vintage.

Appearance : Pitch black with big foamy creamy brown head. Amazing head retention.

Aroma : Big hops with brown sugar, molasses. Hops are quite piny.

Taste : Big molasses, big chocolate, big hops too. Hoppy finish with quite a lot of coffee. Finish quite sweet but fairly well balanced with all the hops. Great rich chocolate finish.

Palate : Soft silky mouthfeel. Rather thick.

Overall :Amazing finish, great rich sweetness well balanced with the hops. Opens up a bit with time. Really nice but a whole bomber was a lot for me that night. My rating would be maybe a bit lower like around 4.2 but I¬íll leave it like that. Truly an amazing beer.
 
Bomber, 2010 vintage thanks to Ynot2. Shared with Eloi.
Appearance : Pitch black with small foamy head.

Aroma : Resinous hops with roasted malt and molasses. Notes of licorice. Nice bourbon notes, very complex.

Taste : Awesome molasses with nice licorice. Nice sweet molasses on the finish. Great roasted malt with nice light coffee. Some chocolate too with light vanilla. Very persistent finish. Nice wood notes.

Overall : Wow, awesome stuff. I really like the big molasses notes along with the well balanced bourbon barrel notes. I really like the long and rich finish. Not too much alcohol, not too sweet. Very, very nice. Think I like this one a bit more than DL because it¬ís a bit less sweet. Maybe not as elegant as Darkness because the hop profile is not as present. Still an awesome beer. I¬íll get to re-rate this soon. October 13th 2011. 9,4,10,3,18;4.4
Pours black with a light tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, coffee, bourbon and roasted malts. Flavor is coffee, light bourbon, chocolate, vanilla and molasses. Medium bodied with light carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2014 65cl, as The Abyss 2010 Reserve, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex Stout, roasted/woody and slightly alcoholic/spicy, balanced, hazy, small head, very good Winter brew, yet very expensive!

Ported from BA.

poured into a Darkness goblet.

Appearance:
By the time the foam hit the edge of the glass, it was sitting around a finger and a half, a chocolatey light brown color. The beer itself is jet black, even if I put it between me and a window. The foam gradually cuts itself down into a light covering with thick lace.

Smell:
Sweet and licorice-y, with the molasses coming in loud and clear too. the oak/bourbon is fairly subtle but present. I could imagine someone mistaking the licorice and molasses for chocolate.

Taste:
Sweet, like a liquid molasses cookie. licorice in the background, slightly masked by oak flavor. Hints of bourbon and chocolate, with just a touch of coffee. There is a very very light hop bitterness, just enough to balance with the sweetness.

Mouthfeel:
Syrupy and thick. Chewy certainly comes to mind. Low carbonation, and very full body. Coats the mouth and doesn¬ít let go, forcing me to savor it forever.

Overall:
I think this may be my favorite sweet stout. It really is amazing. Everything about it screams deliciousness. Probably one of the best beers I¬íve ever had.

Anybody want to volunteer to make Abyss ice cream?

Oh how sweet that deep, dark Abyss (2010 Reserve) ¬Ö

For quite some time I have been reserving THE number one spot of my Beer Hall of Fame for THE best brew.  Deschutes Abyss is THE brew!  From the moment I peeled off the wax covering and removed the cap I knew that this would be a brew like none other.  Many friends and brew-aficionados had long been telling me that this was the brew of brews that were along my taste preferences.  What a fool I was to wait so long to partake in this enticing beverage!

After refrigerating for a few days and then into the freezer for an hour, I let this brew ¬ërest¬í for an hour to warm up a tad. This brew poured up a decadent near-black colored body sporting a healthy mocha-colored foamy head with retention like I¬íve never experienced (so much that I had a lot of foam left on that last sip!) and lacing that left you holding the glass and admiring the artwork long after that last sip was taken.  Amazing scents of warm cocoa, roasted malts, alcohol (not too much), and slow roasted robust coffee.  This coffee is complex and tantalizing with flavors of dark chocolates, coffee, roasted hazelnuts and hints of vanilla and well-aged bourbon that beckons you to take another sip just as soon as you finished taking one!  The body of this brew is just astounding with the just-right thickness and that smooth, clean finish with a warm, bitter, chocolaty, light bourbon aftertaste.  Delicious.

I enjoyed this beverage all by itself and it¬ís definitely a warmer-upper!!  At 11% ABV (alcohol by volume) this bad boy does the job right!  So it is definitely NOT a brew to be quaffed!  Slow down, relax, and enjoy.  While this brew is recommend to be enjoyed during the wintry months, it is definitely one that can be enjoyed all year round.  When the next reserve is produced, I know I will be stocking up and cellaring many, many bottles of this fine beverage.  Heck, I might even share a bottle; might, that is!

Pairing Recommendations: Enjoy it by itself or pair this brew up with a hearty slow-grilled porterhouse steak or some wild game (venison, buffalo, feral hog, etc.) or even some slow-smoked brats/sausage.  Either way, you will enjoy this amazing brew!  Hats off to the folks at Deschutes; you nailed it with The Abyss!

This brew is DEFINITELY in my top 5 favorite brews!!!!

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2011 2009 bottle, from trade. Jet black body, big creamy caramel head. Very, very nice. Aroma is leather, licorice, wood and hints of tar; surprisingly low on the usual coffee/roasty/dark chocolate tones that are so common in the aroma of imperial stouts. Taste is licorice, leather, coffee (more here than the nose), smooth roasty malts and hints of grassy hops way in the back. Some coffee liqueur tones and milk chocolate in the aftertaste. Palate is wonderful; creamy and full; just the way a beer like this should be. Very nice and rock solid, but nevertheless not quite as awesome as the rating indicates.

22oz bomber
A:chocolate, oak/woody, dark stone fruit, roasted malts
T:chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, fruit from alcohol, dark stone fruits,  slightly nutty
The lighter body of this Imperial Stout made it very drinkable and one of the best.

(bomber, 2009 Reserve. Sampled 1/20/11). Black color. Medium brown head. Moderate bourbon alcohol aroma, with moderate chocolate, sweet malt, molasses, and light roasted malt. Flavor of the same, with moderate oak. Long duration. Moderate alcohol finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

One of the 2009 infected bottles.  The infection was not so bad that it ruined the beer but it really overwhelmed what Ive heard is a fantastic Imp stout.  Aroma is heavy tartness with not much else.  Flavor has light tartness and some funk with muted notes of coffee toffee and chocolate.  Hope to have a clean bottle some time.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2012 2009 bomber, Brett is taking over the nose, some ash and bourbon in the background. Very thick roasted ashy flavor, some Brett. Too bad the bottle is infected.

2011, perfect brew, light smoke, sweetish molasses flavors. Love it!

deep, dark, sweet. I was fortunate to have only had uninfected bottles as Deschutes has acknowledged that the 09¬í batch was infected. This is a great beer, that should be reasonable to trade for, if you can get access give it a go!

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2015 Aroma:  Initially some grassy hop, bitter coffee and bitter chocolate plus licorice.  After it warmed a bit:  the licorice came forward then coffee and bitter chocolate followed.  
Flavor:  Bitter, grassy hop initially, then bitter coffee and smooth dark chocolate liquor with bitter coffee, hop and chocolate on a 1 minute plus finish.
After it warmed:  Licorice dominated with coffee and bitter chocolate and it finished with chocolate transitioning into coffee, bitter hop and mocha.
Comments:  Extremely rich and filling.  Dinner and dessert in a glass.  Good even at room temperature.

8/2015
Draft at My Office probably aged 1 year in keg.  
Aroma:  Black licorice, dark chocolate, bitter coffee and grassy hop.
Flavor: Rich, deep dark chocolate, black licorice, big grassy hop.  Long finish of biter grain and roasted coffee bean.  41 points.  The full flavor of the malt reminded me of less elegantly version of the Narke Porter.

Bomber courtesy of bigmmartin, thanks Mike!  Shared with my father-in-law on the day my son was born on August 25th 2011.  Pours pitch black with a nice brown head and some lacing, the aroma was huge with notes of chocolate mixed in with touches of bourbon and oak and vanilla, the flavor was actually a little too sweet for my liking but was still complex and very enjoyable, good amount molassess and caramel with a finish of bourbon and oak, great beer matched up with some nice cigars on a day to celebrate!

From tap. Pours dark and roasty; hints of coffee notes and chocolate goodness dominates the nostrils. Taste is...wait for it, WOW! A porter lovers dream. A great medium between alcohol content and taste, this is the beer or beers. Simply, one of the best craft beers I¬íve ever tested, tasted or whatever. Thumbs up Deschutes.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Almost pitch black with strong initial head that dissipates but leaves lots of bubbly lacing.

Aroma: Massive amounts of molasses and licorice. Nice layers of oak mustiness, coffee and light citrus.

Taste: Oh my God, this is unbelievable. The sweet molasses and licorice complement the harsher roasted qualities of coffee, char and dark chocolate. The partial oak aging imparts an extra Bourbon-like layer, as does the slightly bitter and citrusy hop finish.

Palate: Extremely smooth with low carbonation and a thick full body. Nice dry and warming finish.

Overall: Simply fantastic. Maybe the best Imperial Stout I have ever had. Now I need to find another bottle to cellar.
Melon nose with thin tan head. Pitch black with smooth body and plenty of dark chocolate.

[1pt 6floz bottle, courtesy of Stephanos] Thick black pour, tan head. Roasty malt aroma, some fruit, some bitterness. Strong first taste, bourbon and liquorice harshness. Too big, too harsh upfront for me ¬ñ it then gets almost thin on the aftertaste as a result ¬ñ the damage is done upfront. Having said all that, I¬íd still drink it, of course [19082011]

2010 Bottle; Pour is murky dark brown with an average beige head that retains fairly well, actually. This brew has a nice sweet and savory aroma on the nose; bittering hops, chocolate cake, and booze is present as well. The flavor profile is chocolate cake, toffee, caramel, licorice, molasses, booze, and bourbon - I love the savory notes on this one ; it makes you feel like you¬íre sampled a smoked brew in essence. Anyway - a fantastic, complex imperial stout.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2014 660ml bottle from Brewery Creek Liquor Store, Vancouver, BC

Pours pitch black with a nice beige foamy head. Aroma has notes of oak, vanilla, chocolate, licourice and coffee. Smooth, slightly roasty taste with notes of oaky vanilla, licorice and salmiakki. Warming and long lasting finish is bitter and roasty with notes of smoke and ash. Well balanced, excellent barrel aged imperial stout. 9-4-9-4-17 = 4.3
Re-rated on 11.10.2014. 2010 vintage. This vintage bottle is slightly smoother and mellower than the bottle I tried previously. Bourbon notes are quite subtle here. I prefer the fresh version. 8-4-8-4-16 =4.0

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 Bottle at Craigs. A black beer with a thin dark tan head. Aroma of caramel, little sweet chocolate and coffee. Flavours of coffee, caramel and dark chocolate. Nice oily mouth-feel. Light carbonation with a little CO2 prickle. Lovely! Had this again at Craig¬ís, lots of roasy malt and quite bitter. Alcohol lingers nicely with dark cooking chocolate and a little liquorice also.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2012 2008,2009, 2010, and 2011 on tap at Aces and Ales. This was a black brew with a thick, dark brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, licorice, and chocolate was outstanding. Great feel to the body and the deep malts were well balanced. I could taste the molasses and licorice but they weren¬ít overpowering. 2009 was sweeter. 2008 drier. Finish was clean and dry. This could be my daily drinker but the alcohol is a factor. Try some as soon as you can!

2010 Release, shared with two others at a small beer session. Pours pitch black with a small tan/beige head. Smells of chocolate, coffee, and tobacco. At first taste got heavy notes of roasted malts and tobacco, as the beer warmed it slowly changed into more chocolate and coffee notes, clearly can taste the oak from the barrel aging. Overall, great beer, better enjoyed room temperature than cold, and an interesting note, could not taste the licorice nearly as much as i expected, which in my opinion, is a good thing.

650 ml bottle, 2010 vintage. Pours absolutely pitch black, not even the sun would be able to penetrate this darkness, with a gorgeous, dense, brown head. Nose picks up coffee, dried fruit, oak, liquorice.  When tasting I also get some vanilla, chocolate and toasted oak, and liquorice that kind of sneeks up on you and lingers for a long time. Big flavours, rich mouthfeel, a bit of warming alcohol towards the end. I¬¥ve had the 2008 and 2009 (infected) vintage before, I would rank the 2010 vintage higher than both of those.
A great way to end my son¬¥s first birthday, with a top class beer!

I think this is a pretty great beer, but the Licorice gets a but much after a bit for me. The oak comes through and is easily felt too and is welcome. Good beer that im glad i didn¬ít go insane to go after.

Poured from a 22 oz bottle into a Darkness snifter, shared with a fellow BA. 2010 vintage. 

A- Two finger frothy brown head, dissipates to a nice bubbly ring around the glass, dark pitch black color, nice lacing and retention.
S- The aroma is pretty boozy but not off putting, coffee aromas come out up front followed but roasted notes, the aroma is fairly bitter with some hints of chocolate/cocoa.
T- The taste is similar to the nose, nice coffee flavors, roasted malt, slight vanilla taste, definitely taste the oak from the barrels, bitter aftertaste, molasses comes out as well. 
M- Big mouth feel, thick and chewy, well carbonated, smooth in the finish, sticky on the palate.
O- This is definitely a solid quality RIS, it deserves the praise it gets on a consistent basis, would I say it¬ís one of the best in the World¬Ö.No but I would drink this on more than one occasion. Looking forward to ageing a couple bottles and trying them in the future.

This is a beer I have been wanting to try for years, and I finally scored a bottle in a trade whilst on an epic road trip to Portland, Oregon. Strong, smoky aroma has tones of molasses, wood, bourbon, licorice and semi-sweet chocolate. It pours midnight-black with a thick and rather persistent fine-bubbled tan head that leaves substantial lacing. Flavor is beyond delicious - rich and smoky with tones of molasses, licorice, toffee, caramel, quality coffee, nuts and chocolate. It seems as though each sip is a little different. Thick, smooth flavor has a firm fizz that leaves a persistent tingle to go along with a smoky, nutty, mocha finish. This beer is worth a drive all the way to Oregon!

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2011 22 oz bomber poured into a cup.   Pours pitch black, with brown head.  Looks like used motor oil. Aromas of salt, chocolate, and roasted coffee.  Taste is licorice, molasses, roast coffee, and dark chocolate.  Overall, a tremendous IRS.
Chocolate syrup nose, with espresso accents. Black, thick tan head, good lace. Full body. Molasses, chocolate syrup. COffee and bark finish.

Thanks Andy. 2009.  Clear near black with bright red highlights.  Sweet cherry and licorice and roast, chocolate, molasses, cherry juice. I¬íd like to sip on this for an evening.  Warming sensation on the back end, but not hot.  Good complex fruity dark brew.

Sampled at SIB. Pours black with a slight hint of ruby red in the light, with a thick frothy tan head. Aroma of sweet, dark roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and sweet dark fruits. Flavour of bourbon, oatmeal, dark roasted coffee, and dark chocolate. Luxuriously smooth, slight hops, full bodied. So filling it could easily replace a meal!

Bottle, 2010. Black with dark mocha head. Vanilla, oak, anise, bourbon, some smoke and slightly burnt malts. Initially sweet, then nice bitterness with a bourbon taste, builds to a nice dry and hoppy ending with vanilla and bourbon notes. Great depth and finish that keeps on giving. Great beer.

2007 vintage

Pours a nice deep black with a thin head that lingers awhile leaving just a bit of lacing. It has a nice roasty smell with chocolate, coffee, molasses, bourbon, licorice. The taste was excellent. It followed the nose and showed exceptional balance. Just the right amounts of bourbon, molasses, and licorice to go with the roasted malts. This beer shows why it is so highly rated. It was thick and smooth with light carbonation. This was a lovely stout and I did drink it slowly, but it certainly wasn¬ít a chore to drink. I finished the whole bottle and started thinking of how I could trade for more when I was finished.

Dark black with thin layer of tan head. Cocoa powder, root beer and molasses aroma. Very complex flavor profile: coffee, vanilla bean, port and bourbon,. The longer you let it sit on your tongue the better it tastes. Fresh layer of hop flavor to balance the roasted malt.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2014 Tap. Pour is pitch black with a tan head. Pleasant aroma of chocolate, smoke, oak, and bourbon. Taste is rich chocolate, oak, and bourbon. Palate is smooth and well weighted. AWESOME beer.

**Had a 2009 bottle that was infected. Did not alter my rating.

Pitch black coloured body with a dense, viscous look and an oily, fast-dying deep brown head. Aroma of alcohol, oak, vanilla, pine, roasted malt, licorice and candy sugar. Full-bodied; Deep hop flavour at first, then showing some nice alcohol, oak, vanilla, roasted malt, coffee and caramel tastes afterwards. Aftertaste shows a good roasty malt flavour with licorice, anise, pit fruits, caramel, nuts and a good pleasant alcohol warmth, but not too much. Overall, a very nicely done Imperial Stout that doesn¬ít have too many strong flavours, yet has great complexity. Even though this in a large format bottle, I really like this and if you can find it, well worth sampling! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Brown Jug (Old Seward) in Anchorage, Alaska on 18-June-2011 sampled a day later in Talkeetna, Alaska on 19-June-2011.  Bottle Best After: 15-November-2011.

On tap at Capone¬ís during Philly Beer Week.  Pours black.  Aroma is dark with woody overtones. Mouthfeel is silky smooth.  Taste is Licorice at the start followed by a bit of burn on the back end.  Licorice sweetness lingers in the end.

For as much as I love the Mirror Pond Pale Ale, I cannot believe I have never had this before. This beer is absolutely stellar. The coffee colored head does not last long, but the aroma and taste are outstanding.

aroma is soft chocolates, ganache, ground nuts, candied pecans, earth.  appearance is dead opaque, tar. fudge tinged wisps lace the surface and create a similar ring around.  flavor is cocoa upfront, largely unsweetened with pleasant bitterness, booze sweeps in briefly with a lightning strike.  wood is known but does not press obtrusively.  chocolate turtles, extreme nuttiness at work.  palate is medium for style, thin upfront but coating with oily attack in the end.
UPDATED: JAN 25, 2014 Tap. Very dark pour with a nice full tan head. Great aroma of chocolate, smoke, oak, and a touch of bourbon. Silky mouthfeel. Rich chocolate, oak, and bourbon. Awesome.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2016 MAY 2011 bottle. Damn.  I don¬ít typically like the over-boubonized nature of many of these barrel aged stout, but this is what they all should be like!  2009 version.  Dark pour which appeared flat but a really nice head emerged, and then tremendous lacing.  Kind of an odd metallic booty aroma.   Chocolate and bourbon hit the tongue first, both in immense qualities with a nice ashy finish, like charred oak.  Vanilla was also noted.  Very complex.  Silky smooth on the tongue as well.  Very excellent beer.

RERATE FEB 2016. On tap at Draught House Austin. I have nothing new to add. It¬ís still just as awesome.

Bottle shared with plovmand. Pours black with a medium creamy light brown head and sticky lacings. Aroma is coffee, milk chocolate, roasted malt, oak, bourbon, leather notes. Flavor is bitter chocolate, espresso coffee, bourbon, oak, roasted malt, burned caramel. Wow. This is very well balanced, soft carbonation without being flat. The alcohol tickles a bit on the tongue. This is great shit.

Bottle shared with Hallinghansen. It pours pitch opague black with a dense brown head. leaving nice brown curtains in the glass. The aroma is loaded with roasty notes such as espresso coffee and burnt malt. Notes of liquorice, vanilla and oak hits you in the background along with some chocolate. Dark fruit comes along as the beer evolves in the glass. Lovely! The flavour is very intense with exploding notes of liquorice mixed with hard roasted malt and coffee. Bitter chocolate, vanilla, tar and bourbon hits you in the finish. The alcohol is there but tickles the tongue along with a nice hoppy bite. Thick slick smooth body. Beer porn!!

Poured into a tulip. Immediate noticeable aromas of coffee and roasted malts.  Taste started with roasted malts ending with a not too strong bitter taste. The alcohol was not repugnant even though listed at 11%! Very good beer.

Bottle. 2009 vintage. Shared with Ron and Tony at Churchill¬ís. Pour is a deep, pitch black with minimal but spotty lacing. Aromas of fresh hops, annis, chocolate, little bit of bourbon. Taste is very hoppy for a stout as heavy as this. Amazing balancing act by the brewer to keep floral profile in between the roasted heavy stout notes. Huge amount of brown sugar, molasses, toffee. Very good stout, finishes rich and flavorful.

Vintage 2008:  Pours pitch-black with a dark brown head.  Looks ridiculously viscous, almost like that black slime monster from Creepshow 2.  The aroma twists around your sinus cavity, daring you to name all its components;  there¬ís a defined oak-barrel base, but also with a coffee liqueur sweetness that fades into Raisinettes and grain alcohol.  But, God, how this brew is tasty.  Beyond tasty, in fact, a near-perfect Imperial Stout tweaked to godlike status.  There¬ís a bitter undertone, a hop-current, that provides the circulatory system for the beer, but the competing drool-inducing flavors all allow the IBUs to pass by unmolested.  Why worry about hops when there¬ís bourbon, oak, coffee, chocolate, dried fruit, and molasses all engaging in a gladiatorial death match upon your taste buds?  Boozy yet smooth, the texture sticks to your mouth like the best cake batter ever.  Awe-inspiring.  (3/26/09)

2010 bottle as pictured.  Pretty much a standard (yet extremely delicious) big stout.  Heavy on the coffee and chocolate, both in the smell and the flavor.  Very smooth and complex.  Really delicious.

Immense depth. Plenty of honey here. Light licorice and some vanilla. Rich and sticky but totally mellow. You know it¬ís boozy but you can¬ít taste it. It commands respect.  The malt is king. The nose is quite light and chestnutty. It gets down to business in the mouth.

Bottle shared at the CL Rosso Batch 3 Release. 2010 Vintage. Pours thick dark brown, almost black, with a tan head. Huge aroma with lots of booze and molasses, roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, coffee, chocolate. Taste is full bodied but surprisingly smooth with more dark fruit and hints of vanilla. Quite delicious, would love to try again.
Smells of coffee,alt and chocolate. Toast of roast and bitter chocolate. So good :)
Bottle. Pours black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma is toffee, licorice, and coffee. Flavor is licorice, belgian spices, and cocoa. Medium sticky mouthfeel with some heat.
From a bottle,black in color,licorice,Chocolate,roasty,average carbonation, slick feel, full body, It¬ís a ok imperial stout.

Beautiful nose. First sip was a pleasant burst of molasses like I haven¬ít before experienced in a beer. As I progressed through the beer, there were waves of chocolate and licorice. Didn¬ít pick up a ton of bourbon on this. Really a standout brew.

22oz bottle at the Portland brewery.  Pours pitch black with medium beige head.  Aroma is toffee, dark chocolate, espresso, and black licorice with a hint of oak.  Taste is heavy on black licorice but has nice dark chocolate, espresso, and vanilla oak with hint of bourbon. Likely would be much better in a few years - flavors  a bit harsh, but nonetheless a great beer. Doesn¬ít hold a candle to GI bourbon county or 3F dark lord.

Snifter.  On tap at the Red Bird.  Pours closer to black than brown.  Aroma is chocolate, fig, and anise.  Fairly full bodied.  The taste is great.  Fig, coffee, licorice, coffee.  Not a fan of licorice but I like it in this beer.  Very complex beer that shouldn¬ít be drank very cold.  Highly recommend trying.

2010 bottle.  Aroma is of roast malts, coffee, chocolate, molasses, caramel, and faint black licorice.  Pours inky black with a thin brown head, poor retention as expected for such a massive beer.  Flavor is quite roasty, lots of coffee and chocolate, some bitterness, some black licorice in the background (pretty subtle).  Big body with low-medium carbonation, thick and chewy.

8 May 2010, bottle. sooo black. can¬ít see through it at all. thin, foamy brown head. lots of coffee on the nose followed by dark chocolate. the molasses isn¬ít around but you can definitely find licorice. med body and slightly fizzy. roasted coffee is strongest flavour. not syrupy so it doesn¬ít coat your mouth. had bitter chocolate finish. after a few sips i noticed sweetness more. this is an outstanding beer!
coffee, chocolate, booze, molasses, caramel, malts. dark with very little head.  liquorish, coffee, chocolate, molasses.

Bottle shared with jerc & mabel - Dec 22/08. Midnight black with a small tan head. Deep, rich aroma of charred malt, roasted coffee, molasses, bourbon, vanilla, hazelnut, oak, woodsmoke - just fantastic! Flavour is a bit more controlled than the aroma suggests, but is still damn good, with lots of dark, sweet malt, vanilla and oak notes off the top, and a dry finish of coffee, licorice and hops. Outstanding!
Rich, caramel taste, toffee, spice. Licorish. Molasses on the back end kind of ruins it for me

On tap at The Daily Pint. Black with not even a hint of light through any corner. Strong one-finger dark brown head that fell over time to a solid film and left exquisite lace. Chocolate, roasted coffee/espresso, oak, vanilla and bourbon are among the array of aromas. Dark bittersweet chocolate flavors with espresso and black currant also coming on strong. Creamy malt, warming Southern whiskey alcohol, anise, licorice, and a nip of bittering hops toward the end. Full, full body, creamy, creamy mouthfeel, minimal carbonation, and a long, dark chocolate and espresso finish. Superb.

I LOVE THIS BEER! This year was it¬ís first release in TX and I snagged 2 bottles.  Thick motor oil pour, milk chocolate head. Aromas roasty coffee, bittersweet chocolate and some dark fruit. Palate is creamy with flavors of coffee, cassis, and of course a little dark chocolate...description is a little redundant but this stout is killer.
22oz bottle, 2010 vintage. Pours jet black, little head, aroma of molasses, oak, and bourbon. Smooth, the bourbon rises up on the backend. Great.

Bottle thanks to ygtbsm94: Pours a deep black oil with a two finger thick light brown head. The head leaves a caramel like streaks down the edge of the glass. The aroma is to die for nice sweet roasted malt, molasses, and yet vanilla aged wood. Taste is upfront bourbon that subsides to leave nice molasses and sweet malt. The flavor engulfs the tongue leaving my buds happy.

Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. 2009 edition. Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a large dark brown head that lingered and produced prodigious lacing. The aroma was faint tart apple, light oak and a hint of bourbon. The flavor was tart and bitter apple, roasty malts, cocoa, coffee, anise, wood and a bit of bourbon. The finish was long with bitter malts, coffee, wood and anise lingering. Thick and full bodied. I had a taste of the 2010 and liked it significantly better but had not rated it since I had a full bottle of 2009 at home. I feel the rating suffered for the waiting.

got a bottle of this at zorbaz with friends.  It pours black with a light brown head that is there after every sip.  The smell is of bourbon and licorice and some sugar.  The taate is mouth coating and warm.  You can¬ít just drink this beer you need to sip it and enjoy it.  This is a great beer.

Shared 22 oz bottle with Todd / Sherm 1016.....well done.  This is definitely a ¬ísipper...¬í.... pours black / with tannish head...nose contains hints of the licorice / malts / licorice....drink this one slow and warm...it get better with each sip....will enjoy having this one again next year..

22oz bottle, 2010 vintage.  Pours a jet black with a tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, licorice.  A bit thin on the palate for an imperial stout, but with nice, soft carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, a bit of oak and bourbon.  The dry finish is a bit different from most imperial stouts.  Overall, very good, and I¬ím interested to see how this ages.

2009 Vintage, poured into a tulip. Beer is dark black and appears thick. Carbonation is mild. Beer is completely opaque even at the corners. Forms a thick and aggressive dark brown head that falls away relatively quickly leaving a lot of lacing on the glass. The resultant head is thin and diffuse and eventually breaks. A visage of the original head hung out in the middle of the glass for the duration of the beer.

The aroma is complex. There is a lot of sweetness, brightness, some alcohol, a lot of roast, malt and coffee, almost a syrup but not cloying aroma as well. There is a hint of anise in there as well.

Beer is medium to full bodied. Late roast taste followed by a strong aftertaste of bitterness and roasted malt. Definitely some espresso character. I was expecting a little bit of bourbon but got none. I did however get some warmth from the alcohol in the front of the mouth along with considerable gravity and sweetness. Overall its a good beer. Its not my favorite imperial stout but it is really good. Drinkability is good and mouthfeel is good too. I would be interested to see how this beer changes over time.

Serving type: bottle

Sampled at Nashville Beer Summit 1.22.11 - 2009 bottle. Dark black pour. Tan colored foam. Sour fruit aromas with dark chocolate, roast and coffee. Medicine. Cough Syrup. Liquorish. Tastes very full and big. Impressive.

Deschutes The Abyss. It pours out a deep black hue permeated with the aroma of chocolate malts, molasses, oaks, and brown sugar and some vanilla. The flavor is a revision of the aromas but more complex. The bitterness is the first flavor that gets you as well as the oaks and the malts. The sweetness from the molasses comes through afterwards and in the finish. The 11% abv isn¬ít very upfront. It lies dormant within the brew to provide a slightly warming as it goes down. Very nice beer. Bitter and sweetness in perfect unison.

It pours a motor oil black with a very dark tan head. It stays pitch black even in the light. The head rises about 1 finger and stays there for about a minute. Tht lacing is light and watery, little small raindrops clining to the glass. 

The aroma is very strong. As I write the review I start to get whiffs of yuminess from about 2 feet away. I really like this smell because unlike most stouts its biggest note isn¬ít coffee. The coffee is there but very subtle so it allows other things to come to the front. I get a lot of sweet cherry, vanilla, bourbon, a smidge of alcohol and a little oak. A very nice combination all the way around. 

The taste is a little of a let down from the aroma because its not as complex, balanced or as sweet as the aroma. Don¬ít get me wrong it is very good, just a little below the high expectations of the aroma. The main taste is coffee from start to finish with a little bitterness, and alcohol at the end. There is also a little vanilla and oak.

The beer itself is full bodied and heavy, and its very long lasting on the palate.

Poured into a snifter. The Abyss pours an impenetrable black, which makes the name fit perfectly. A dark tan head sits on top, with a low rate of retention that eventually leads to the halo effect. Decent lacing. Not a very overwhelming bouquet, but I did pull out some sweet malts, bourbon, woody/oak, some liquorice and molasses. The first thing that popped in my mind on the first sip was...holy crap! Malty, rich sweet roasted malts, burnt flavors, liquorice. Nice hop balance. Bourbon hits in the end and rolls under the tongue. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy for the style. Moderate carbonation. Not sure how much of this I could drink in one session, but it is amazing. I would love to be able to buy it at will. Thanks for the trade SAS.

Bottle, 2009. Pitch black, pretty brown head. Aroma has a nice coffee-like roast, liquorice, dried fruits, oak, whisky, some alcohol, spices, charcoal, raisins, vanilla. Very smooth and buttery. Some molasses and a slight hop finish. Taste has a nice subtle sweetness, followed by an intense bitterness with vanilla and roast. Very smooth with a nice bitter liquorice-feel. Very strong with a bit of alcohol which lessons as it warms.

2010 bottle.  Pours a dark black with light just coming through at the edge when help up to the light.  Small light tan head with good retention that leaves a decent amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is chocolate, licorice, molasses, and bourbon.  Alcohol is fairly strong on the nose as well.  Initial taste is sweet, dark chocolate going into more molasses and licorice.  A little bit of oak and bourbon as well.  Finish has a decent bitterness and a decent amount of alcohol.  Medium body.  Light carbonation.  Great beer.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2012 I look forward to this beer every year; one of the perks of living in the northwest, I guess! 2010 Reserve poured into a snifter. Pours black as night with a thick, brown head. Aroma is huge and complex! Dark chocolate, licorice, coffee, and dark fruits. Flavor is even more complex! Burnt oak, chocolate malts, brown sugar, licorice, dark fruits (like raisins), and a slight bourbon-y presence. Pretty heavy alcohol backbone, but not overwhelming. Mouthfeel is rich and oily. This is a phenomenally complex stout! Deschutes really guaranteed themselves a place in brewing history with this one. Overall, one of the best imperial stouts I¬íve had to date. Definitely in my top ten! I¬íll be looking forward to the new releases each year :-)

2010 Reserve. Small brown head, black beer. Aroma of oak, bourbon, chocolate. Taste is oak, chocolate, bourbon, sweet with some bitterness, some alcohol. Body is full and extremely thick, oily, soft carbonation, with a long slightly bitter finish. Amazing!

No light penetrates penetrate this beer, it redefines pitch black. An absolutely stunning brown head rises slowly and clings to the glass forever. Dark unsweetened baking chocolate, faint anise, prevalent oak with a hint of vanilla, and a very faint yet sharp char aroma. Viscous, smooth, almost-to-syrupy body. Heavy hand of roasted and toasted malt, though not overwhelming. Anise and vanilla are modest but noteworthy. Tart black-currants meld into a small but wild fruity ester. Creamy malt undertone, middle to end, with a slight warming alcohol in tow. Suggestions of burnt toffee and mocha come to mind. Small push towards a long, lingering finish.
The sheer "depth" of The Abyss is more than remarkable. This beer is a good example of American brewers coming into their own and bringing it to the table. Definitely drink one now and cellar some more. Rosemary crusted Rack of Lamb, very buttery smashed potatoes and Maple-Molasses glazed Butternut squash was amazing with this!

This beer was awesome. I had it in a brandy glass and the complexity of the beer as it warmed was delightful. I was saddened that I didn¬ít pay heed to the best use by date and waited a couple of months to enjoy it fully.

2008 vintage bottle. This one pours as black as the night and topped by a small, smooth head of tan colored foam that slowly recedes to a thin film. Scattered spots of lace cling hard to the glass and rejoins the body below. The aroma is rich and decadent showing dark chocolate, anise, licorice, and roasted espresso along with subtle notes of bourbon laden oak. Some earthy hops add some balancing bitterness on the back end. The flavor follows and is based mostly in rich dark chocolate, cocoa powder, and roasted espresso. Licorice and molasses add to the flavor profile while subtle bourbon and vanilla laden oak add further depth and smoothness. The dark chocolate and roasted espresso reign in this beer though. Nearly full bodied and creamy on the palate with balanced carbonation that leads to a roasted chocolate finish. The oak and bourbon are subtle, but really add a nice dimension to the base imperial stout. Awesome brew that is worthy of its high rating.

On tap at Streets of London Pub during Sacramento Beer Week. Poured 10 ounces in a sniffer glass. Very dark with a thin tan head that leaves little lacing. Aroma is strongly hard alcohol, probably due to aging in burbon barrels. Some chocolate on the nose. Flavour is incredibly smooth. Chocolate flavour is prominent, virtually cannot tell it¬ís 11%. mouth feel is very nice, full bodied, and great Carbonation. Overall a fantastic beer. This was the 2009 reserve.

On tap at Streets of London in downtown Sacramento. In a Deschutes goblet. Color is jet black with a reddish brown head.  Aroma is dark chocolate and alcohol.  Flavor is chocolatey with roasted notes and some alcohol on the finish.  Suprisingly smooth palate.  Deep, dark beer as claimed.  Very good overall.

Pours pink with a purple head. Aroma is strong on the liquorice and coffe, sft burnt caramel, vanilla, vanilla milkshake, sweet chocolate. A nice hoppy finish in the aroma. Taste us strong on the roast, coffee, liquorice, hints of raisins and melasses. Quite alcoholic. Neither elegant nor finesse, but pretty tasty anyway,

2009 Reserve

Pours jet black with the typical tan head one would expect from an IS. The head lingers and slowly falls leaving behind a wake of beautiful lacing.
Roasty, chocolatey, sweet, coffee. Don¬ít get any of the licorice, but there is a slight bit of the molasses coming through. A bit of the oak, but mostly malt and the roasted aromas. Very complex bit of aromas fighting for you nose¬ís attention.
All the flavors show themselves in the taste. A little bit of the licorice is there, but it is easily masked by all the other flavors present. A little bit of a sour bite. Not getting any of the bourbon, just the woodiness. All the flavors meld together very well in this beer. I wouldn¬ít have imagined such an array of ingredients would make such a smooth tasting brew. But they did.
Viscous. And a bit bitter. Not as sweet as I imagined so your lips stay cleaner than most other RIS since you don¬ít have sugar caking up on your mouth. Not too hot either, weird considering the ABV.
Very drinkable. The complex taste profile makes taking the next sip an adventure. You are waiting to see what tastes make an appearance next. If not for the strength I could keep on drinking this malty goodness.

Shared this beer with some friends during a tasting with Surly Darkness, Darklord, Kate the Great, Abyss, Sexual Chocolate, Cigar City 110K OT Batch2, Speedway stout, Stormaktsporter regular and Kaggen! Pours very dark with a brown thick head. Smell: espresso, molasses, dark chocolate, dark fruits, some hints of alcohol and bourbon. Taste: Most components of the smell come back in the taste. Bit sweet in the beginning, but bitterness (roasted malts) in the end. Alcohol is slightly noticeable. Perfect balance Mouthfeel: chewy body, but so silk and smooth...damm, perfect! Medium-low carbonation. What a fantastic beer.
Bottle (2009). Pink with a thin purple head. Aroma: coffee, milk chocolate, caramel, burnt sugar and asphalt. Bitter and sweet, full-bodied with a dry, roasty finish.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2015 On draught at 540 Club during SF Beerweek. Coffee and chocolate mousse on the nose. Extinguished firewood. Opaque with a deep brown head of two fingers that paints the side of the glass as it is emptied.  Full chocolate flavor, very smooth like a hershey bar. Sharp bitterness in mid-palate and lingering roast on the finish. Medium mouthfeel seems to mask the alcohol. Finish seems to linger eternally in the mouth.  I have this every year and fail to figure out the plot on this...I am clearly missing something everyone else understands!

2009 Reserva. Bottle kindly shared by gunnar. Black pour covered with a creamy brown head that leaves an excellent lacing. Vanilla, dark fruits, prune, chocolate, liqorice on the nose. Complex and inviting aroma and flavors developing as the temperature rises. Roasted notes, malty, liqorice filling the mouth. Smooth and full bodied. Perfectly balanced. Bourbon becomes noticeable. Long roasted finish with a dry end. 
The only "problem" with the Abyss was finding the balls to give it a perfect score (, my first). It is like saying that nothing can be better. However I found nothing missing. On the contrary, drinking this elixir left me ecstatic and joyful. Masterful brewing and blending.

2008 wax topped 22 oz. bottle for my 1000th rating.  This is a live rating, and this beer is #33 of the top 50 for me.  Such a momentus occasion for me.  July 31, 2008 I joined just so I could be a part of the RBSG activities at Stone.  Little did I know what was in store for me.  Thanks Ratebeer and Ratebeerians.
Pour is black.  Head is warm brown in color, with a mixture of dense foam and big bubbles mixed in.  A swirl of the glass leaves a yellow stain for a few moments.  Nose is chocolate covered banana with vanilla.  Alcohol and molasses.  First taste, with glass too cold for optimum drinking, is sharp malt bitter and alcohol hot sweet.  Licorice is poking its head out a bit.  Lots of different sharpness: roast malt, alcohol, licorice/aspirin in the back.  Gooey in the throat.  
As it warms, the mouthfeel goes velvety.  BA character starts to smooth out the rough edges.  Bourbon and vanilla and chocolate-molasses.  
First thoughts were there¬ís no way this is a top 50 beer.  The bottom of the glass makes it clear it really is.  Beautiful brew.
Sampled at the ITAP Big Black Beer Bash.  Oh my is this good!  Anise, chocolate, coffee, and dark sugar just blend perfectly.  Some very nice oak, dark fruit, and bourbon.  Fantastic!
Dark pour with minimal head. Incredible nose of chocolate and coffee. The flavours of this beer became more smooth and creamy as it warmed. The best imperial stout I¬íve ever had. Bravo.

Expresso, toffee and dark fruit emanate from the glass.  Inky black pour wiht milk-chocolate thick head.  Chocolate mixed with roasted malt that has amazingly blended together.  A terrific ebony beer.  Finishes with a satiny cleanness.  Velvety and creamy with a hint of oakiness.  Great imperial stout; like a coffee-cholcolate bar with faint alcohol trace until the end.
Bottle. Nice bitter coffee flavor. Wow. The aftertaste is a well balanced coffee/coco theme. Nice.

22 oz bottle, thanks to a trade with Daknole, served in a tulip.  Pour is onyx with three cascading fingers of deep beige head; the head goes the distance, but leaves only a modest show of lacing.  Nose is molasses, bourbon, wood, roasted malt, caramel, light vanilla, and notes of chocolate covered cherry liquorish.  Taste very closely mimics the nose, however, the liquorish takes a much stronger stance than indicated by the nose.  The finish is lingering roast, liquorish, wood, molasses, and a nice boozy punch that revealed itself during this phase in the brew.  This one is fantastic, and until the finish, conceals the booze quite well.  This is easily one of the better imperial stouts out there, and one not to be missed!

Pours black with a nice plush deep tan head. Aroma of molasses, coffee, pine, bourbon and licorice. Taste is pretty much the exact same as the aroma. Molasses up front,  bourbon and pine notes in the middle, followed up by black licorice and chocolate.  Such a nice balance of flavors. Maybe just a touch thin in the middle taste but still wonderful.
Fat black liquid with a moussy brown head. Heavy flavours with a perfect amount of bourbon. Coffee and sweet but dark chocolate. Bitter and licoricy aftertaste. Heavy stuff!
2010 bottle from Cavie.  Dark pour with a brown head.  Aroma is coffee, alcohol, and very roasted.  Taste is chocolate, coffee beans,  a little hot, and roasted.

Thanks to GabrielM.  Bottle pours almost thick and almost black with small tan head.  Nice aroma of licorice, roast and malts.  Complex taste with molasses, oak, licorice, malts and roast.  long finish of oak and roast.  Taste evolves as it warms.  Palate thick and creamy.  Alcohol well disguised.  

Once you get scores over 4 it¬ís largely a matter of taste.  This is a very good imperial stout but if you¬íre looking for an "in your face" stout this probably isn¬ít it, this is rather a very smooth and balanced stout.
Tasted the 2009 and 2010 in a vertical.  Very different beers, but both are wonderful
A very nice Imperial Stout. The 2009 version have a sour perfume a vanilla and licorice component. It is sweet, smooth and the alcool is very well hidden. Nice job !

Pours jet black with fully, fluffy brown head. Smells like licorice, molasses and bourbon. Tastes strongly like bourbon, molasses, licorice, and rich roasty stout. Full-bodied, creamy texture, and little mouth-carbonation, Deschutes The Abyss 2010 Reserve finishes smooth, deep, and sweet.
Super  stout. U can taste the molasses In the beer. Amazing head. Found this at my hot spot Tacoma boys
Black, bourbon heaven.  I must give this a wow and then another wow.  The best american stout for sure!

I love this beer. I had a bottle of 2009 and though it was slightly off it was still very good. But since it wasn¬ít as good as it could have been I will just review the 2010.

It pours black with a half inch of of tan head that seemed to stick around for days... It looked fantastic in my stone IRS tulip. I couldn¬ít wait to dive in to this glass of motor oil.

The smell was as good as a stout gets. Oak, chocolate malts, vanilla, molasses, bourbon round off the initial whiff. The smells brown sugar and chocolate/vanilla stick around the longest. Love it!

The taste is amazing all the smells shine through in the taste, the sweet yet awesomely bitter taste keeps me going back for more. The first third of the bottle has lots of oak and chocolate malts with a ton of sweet molasses on the finish. The bourbon flavor is a bit subdued and I¬ím sure that¬ís bc it is only 33% aged in barrels. The beer is a bit rough on the edges and all I can think is how good it will be in 1,2 or even 3 years from now if I can wait that long to revisit it (have 2 more bottles). 

Overall it is a fantastic beer to drink now even though it is a bit young. I feel this could be one of my favorite beers if it ages to the potential I think it has. If you can find a bottle hold onto it and if you can find 2 or more drink 1 now and you won¬ít be disappointed!

2007-2010 vertical showed up at the Big Black Beer Bash 2011. I had an infected 2009 one a few months ago and didn¬ít think that deserved to be rated. The 2008 was the standout of this bunch, but my palate was raw and my notes were getting scribbled by this point. Here goes: pours a viscous, opaque brown, basically black, with a small tan head. Notes of bourbon, oak, vanilla, roasted malts, dark fruits, dark chocolate, and molasses. Full-bodied, with a totally smooth mouthfeel and low carbonation. I have a 2006-2009 vertical at home, so I will re-rate this once I get the 2010 and get through the whole thing.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2012 2007 Bottle thanks to Glouglouburp. Dark black pour, with no head. Aroma of licorice, black berries, coffee, hops are gone, but you can tell they were definately there. What is left is a nice balance of fruitiness/herbalness from the berries and anise. Taste is rich coffee roastiness with herbal licorice notes, light barrel aging flavors - just a hint of booze on the finale, bitter finish. Palate is a bit flat, but full flavored and creamy. 

Re-rate: 2011 vintage. Much better than the ¬í07, tons of wood both in the aroma and taste. Aroma also has a lot of tobacco, smoke, unsweetened chocolate and the likes. The palate is very rich and creamy, silky smooth and generally awesome.

Let me start out by saying: holy crap. Bottle. Pours black with a nice tan head which leaves tons of lacing. Aroma is all over the place: bourbon, oak, molasses, chocolate, coffee, espresso, licorice, vanilla. Flavor is just as good: rich, full-bodied but goes down easily. No booziness. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Better than Expedition, IMHO.

Thanks to cbkchubert!  Deep dark pour with a dark brown head. Aroma was roasted malt, oak, licorice, coffee, a little chocolate. The taste was the same as the aroma but it exploded in my mouth. Such a flavorful beer. A liitle dryness to it. It left a nice roasted malt and woody aftertaste. The taste seemed to multiply s it warmed. Nice lacing.

Bottled, 2010.  Pours black, completely opaque, creamy brown head, small, great, creamy lacing.  Aroma of molasses, dark fruits, esters, vanilla, boozy.  Fullish, creamy palate with great carbonation, balanced finish, not too sticky.  Flavor is lightly sweet up front, dark fruits--prune, plumb--molasses, lots of roasted grain, long, bitter finish of fresh and piny hops, baker¬ís chocolate, and a distinctly strong and bitter anise flavor.  Needs to age at least 6mos, 1-3yrs would be good.  A pleasant surprise to find something so abundant to be so nice.

Pours a dark thick black color with a foamy cola almost reddish colored head. Nose is espresso, vanilla, clean laundry, dark chocolate, toffee, char, molasses, and roots.  Taste is exact same. The palate is creamy and thick yet drinkable. Extremely well balanced with will hidden alcohol. Excellent.
Black pour from bottle with a nice tan head.  Aroma is roasted coffee, oak and booze.  Taste is molasses, booze, oak, and roasted coffee beans.  Strong finish.  Excellent!

Review from notes, sampled 2/26/2008

I got a surprise shipment from Liquid Solutions today and couldn¬ít resist ripping into one of the bottles I preordered months ago. I was actually pleasantly surprised that I got any at all.

All right about the beer:
2007 edition.
Pours a solid black with a huge tan head that subsided a bit, but lasted through the glass. Aroma gives up some chocolate, some oak, a sweet lactose type smell, some hops in the background. Really a lot going on here. Taste hits with some chocolate, some ash, there¬ís some alcohol and an almost vinous and bitter character in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel is thick and a little gritty. Great complex stout, I can¬ít wait to see how the other bottles develop.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2012 750ml bottle 2010 Reserve.Pitch black with light head around the edges.  Moderate lacing - chocolate, oak, slight alcohol aroma.  Smells decadent, tastes even more so.  Incredible flavor - this is THE Russian Imperial Stout!  Some licorice sweetness.  Overall just incredible, i?m glad I bought a few so I can see what some age does to it.

2010 Bottle (Consumed 1-20-11).  Good beer, but I like it better on tap with a bit more age. Pitch black pour, with fairly dark head that dissipates to a ring of lacing that coats the glass.  Nose is dark fruit (raisins, prune, etc), a bit of smoke, some burnt malt, and burnt sugar.  Taste is much the same, with the fruit a bit more pronounced in the middle/end of the beer.  Finishes with a smoky dryness that bitters nicely.  I do enjoy this beer, but miss the coffee notes, I seem to get when on tap.

first of all the wax around the top is sexy looking, not gonna lie haha the aroma is sweet raisin and chocolate you get some alcohol in there as well and also some notes of the molasses, pours a dark black, one of the thickest beers I have ever poured it has a dark tan head, not overly coffee like at all in the aroma, unlike most imperial stouts I have had the first taste is the sweet molasses and middle tongue is the coffee and a little raisin, plum like and leaves you with a slight coffee like flavor, and absolutley wanting more, the mouthfeel is so thick and creamy, overall an absolutely amazing beer, it is only the 2010 reserve, I tried to hold on to it for as long as I could, but I gave in and am I grateful for that

2009 vintage. Poured into a snifter. Big thanks to kbutler1 for this one. Due to the recent infection scare, I¬íve decided to do my own investigative reporting. Here are my results:

4.5 A: A suspicious syruppy black enters my snifter. Two fingers of medium brown, frothy/creamy hybrid head stares me down for a slightly better than average amount of time. Indeed, the last quarter inch beckons me to attempt a sniff. Tormented lacing covers all angles of the glass.

5.0 S: Half expecting lactobacillus to bring forth pain and destruction, I lean over my glass. Instead, I am greeted with a lovely bouquet of amiable aromas. Sweet chocolate is most apparent with vanilla oakiness and molasses tying for the silver. The next wave brings a subdued bourbon and brewer¬ís licorice.

5.0 T: The taste is as magical as the nose. Bourbon and licorice step forward from their stealth positions take command. Vanilla and molasses are second. Oakiness, a mild bitterness, and roasted barley play their roles as well. Alcohol is apparent, but not overly so.

4.5 M: Lighter heavy body. Good moderate carbonation. Creamy and smooth with a moderate warming aftertaste.

4.5 D: The barleywines and RISs of my cellar rejoice. Their comrad has not been subdued by illness, but rather by Emporer DavoleBomb, who chuckles with delight as another great brew has done his bidding. Lots of great stuff going on with this one. I dare say this is better than the 08. One day an epic vertical will decide the true victor.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-22-2010 23:05:58

Enjoyed at the Burger Bar at Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas, NV.  Flat out incredible.  Aroma consisted of alcohol, coffee, and chocolate, equally balanced between the 3 items.  Appearance in a goblet, pure black with a  thin tan head, just beautiful.  Taste purely decadent with notes of alcohol and chocolate.  Really stings the throat, it hits you with the punch of alcohol but it¬ís also very smooth.  Extremely good.

appearance: deep black, oily pour, with a thin tan head.
aroma: dark chocolate, roast. maybe a touch of licorice
flavor: chocolate, roasted malt, espresso. bit bitter.
nice imperial stout, well balanced
annnnd tasty

dark ruby brown pour with a brown head.
aroma is awesome roasted malt. nice bourbon vanilla. 
coffee. sweet toffee/molasses.
Flavour is smooth coffee, chocolate, vanilla, hint of fruit and molasses sweetness.
very nice.

2009 release.

Dark, deep black beer with a dark brown head.  Lasting lace.  Tons of lace.  Like ice, with each sip the lace builds upon itself.  Beautiful looking beer. 

Big and complex.  Rich but mellow roast flavors.  Exceptionally well done.  Dominated by dark roast flavors but with no bitter or burnt flavor.  A bit of earthy tones, even berries, and a malt sweetness with hints of caramel/chocolate sweetness comes through as it warms.  

Rich, mellow, and big.  I keep returning to that.  Very easy to drink for a beer with such big flavors.  

This beer stands out as exceptional beyond other remarkably well done stouts.
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmnnnnmmmmmmmmmmmmmnnnnmmmmmmm Mmmmmmmmm.

22 oz bottle, pours black with a brown head. Aroma of oak, bourbon, vanilla, licorice, chocolate and potent roastiness. Flavour beings with bourbon and oak, followed by vanilla, bitter hops, oatmeal and chocolate. Extremely layered and complex, exceptionally well-balanced and an immense treat.

From notes:

2007 vintage. Pours pitch black and almost completely opaque with only faint mahogany edges when held to a light source and a two finger frothy mocha head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glass with chinks of soapy lacing.

Slightly smokey, roasted malt aroma with lots of luscious, silky chocolate as well as some licorice, subtle oak, vanilla, coffee bean, toast and toffee.

Chewy medium body with an incredibly luscious, silky chocolate malt flavor. Hints of mocha, toast, oatmeal, mocha and toffee as well as some caramel and sweet alcohol. Slightly creamy presence mid-palate makes this beer incredibly smooth and extremely quaffable. Slight bitterness up front is countered by the chocolate malt as well as the oak, bourbon and vanilla notes. The ABV is excellently masked making it dangerously drinkable. Also, the barrel aging adds to the complexity and balance of the beer and instead of it being a complete bourbon bomb it results in an incredibly complex, flavorful and well balanced, amazing beer.

From notes.  Tap.  Deep brown in color with a dark tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit, and anise.  Taste is dark chocolate, vanilla, and some anise.  Not overpowering or boozy like many barreled imperial stouts.

2009 Reserve: Black colored brew with a nice brown head. Dark malts,oak and bourbon in the aroma. Flavor has bourbon, vanilla, dark chocolate, coffee, molasses, sweet and rich taste . It¬ís a bit boozy. Very pleasant beer.

Unbelievable depth in this beer, with a new flavor coming out every few moments. Pours pitch black, no light shows through whatsoever, looks for real like crude oil. Coffee, chocolate, alcohol rum raisin taste a little bit (probably molasses along with something else). Great feel on palate, can taste one small sip for a long time. Thanks deschutes for making so much more of this in recent batches.

Tap pour. Appearance is dark brown to black with a lace, sticky head. Aroma has a wonderful bourbon scent with  coffee, vanilla, and a hint of molasses with some alcohol. Taste follows the nose with coffee, bits of chocolate, hints of vanilla, slight raisin and tobacco finish. Surprisingly bitter finish; overall a great Deschutes beer!

Ridiculously great brew. Pours super dark and thick. You can really taste the bourbon barreling, makes this brew awesome. Alcohol is huge on it as well. Not to be taken lightly. Top notch brew well worth a try if you can find it. Aged for over a year.

O jeez what a beer.  2010 release.  I didn¬ít bother with aging it, too impatient.  Pours out tar black, cannot see through any of it.  Medium-ish yet lasting head with lots of lacing, with a color not unlike dark chocolate milk.  Aroma is incredibly enticing, sweet, and complex.  I¬ím getting strong notes of artisan dark chocolate, bourbon-oak, and clean coffee grounds, with lighter notes of vanilla extract, molasses, with maybe a touch of roasted caramel.  Diving into the taste is a remarkable experience.  First of all, the alcohol is very hidden.  Tastes about 7-8%.  I¬íve had 9%ers that burned more than this.  This is very smooth both in alcohol and in texture.  Texture is somewhat oily with very, very little carbonation.  It¬ís barely prickly, but it¬ís an interesting mouthfeel, yet it fits superbly with the flavor profile.  Flavor has a lot of roasted chocolate, some wood, light notes of burnt caramel, lots of roasted malt, and a surprising cappuccino note, interesting only because no coffee was used as an ingredient.
