Also getting flavor notes of molasses and a hint of black licorice.  The finish is noticeably hoppy, but is hidden behind an overwhelming sweet and malty body.  It¬ís probably as hopped as a common IPA, but good grief its so underscored.  But not in a bad way.  This should make the Top 5 of any Stout lover.  It¬ís delightfully chocolatey, smooth, too complex to describe it with words, and as bold as a radio talk show host.  Save this one for special occasions, as it is a bit tough to drink without sharing, and I cannot see myself getting another one till next years release.  But it¬ís a dang fine beer, and deserves your attention.

2009 bottle.  Huge beer in every respect.  Deep dark black, viscous, lots of molasses, roasted malts, dark chocolates, some coffee, brown sugar, light smoke/oak from the barrels.  Drank along with an Alesmith Speedway and actually preferred the Speedway, but this is a very good brew.

Tap, 55f, little foam, great toffeecolored lacing.  Aroma is sweet and roasted  sugars, a light acidic edge in the scent.  Full mouthfeel, but less cloying than the bottle I tried in 2009.  Some coffee, some roasted caramel flavors.  Overall similar to the bottle but lighter body and lighter mouthfeel.  Tops!

2009 bottle, courtesy of Cletus or phaleslu. Pours black as can be with a 3 finger, dense, creamy mocha head that has excellent retention. Aroma is huge on roast, dark fruit, molasses cookies, charred wood, wet autumn leaves and a touch of vanilla. Flavor is roast, molasses snaps, char, hints of dark fruit, subtle oak notes, toasted white bread, espresso, nilla wafers, chocolate truffles and walnuts. Palate is fairly heavy bodied, super creamy on entry, off dry finish and has a somewhat light (just right for this brew) carbonation. Fantastically delicious beer, reminds me a bit of Kalamazoo Stout, albeit much stronger and sweeter.
An excellent beer that has a nice flavor that passes through several phases. It has a rich dark color and a pleasant aroma.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2011 Super roasty aroma, slightly boozy.  Black (Abyss-ish?) with nice tan head.  Sweet, with strong roasted and chocolate notes and a boozy complexity, warming on the way down...a fantastic stout!

Latest bottle 2011 Reserve

2009 release... Definitely scared that this was infected... Deep black pour opaque dark tan head crazy lacing and retention... Aroma was way off though, kind of funky, some mild oaky vanilla notes a little licorice, coffe, chocolate, complex but all under the funk that clearly shouldnt be there... Very nice flavor, the funk from the aroma wasnt present, oaky, not very roasty or burnt, some coffee, complex but doesnt seem right... Creamy full bodied boozy.... Aside from the off aroma, the complexities were still there, flavor wise the beer was still very above average if the bottle was in fact infected... i cant wait to try again...

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2016 My first brew of 2011! Shared with Parksy, 2009 vintage. Viscous, hearty, near-black pour, lazy rising red-brown head. Aroma of fig paste, chocolate, burnt sugar, licorice, vanilla cookie. Richly flavoured, full of dark fruits (fig paste, prunes), spicy chocolate, cigar box, blackstrap molasses, vanilla and licorice. Dense, creamy, chewy mouthfeel levened somewhat by a nice acidity in the finish. A stunning impy that takes me back to when I tried my first imperial stout (Samuel Smith¬ís), with loads of port-like influences that eclipses all others I¬íve had to date. This take on the style (less hops, more malty depth) REALLY appeals to me. My new #1!!! I¬ím taking one point away, as I do not think that the perfect beer has yet to cross my lips, but man this is the one so far!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Notes from 10/2008. Received in my first trade. 2007 vintage.

Black. Fantastic lacing, really, no exaggeration. A dark almond colored head. Very nice.

Metallic until it warms. Dark chocolate reigns, with molasses, licorice, and coffee bringing up the mid-to-rear. Flavor profile resembles some of the other imperial stouts I have had, but there is something wonderful about the chocolate. The texture? Its particular bitterness? Wonderful fudge, followed by a light bourbon from the oak barrels, and a sweet but dry finish. I also pick up minor vanilla. Heavy roastiness.

Mouthfeel, as I¬íve alluded to, is wonderful. Medium to full, but there is a creaminess and particular stickiness I have not experienced before The Abyss. 

Perhaps I¬ím just having a wonderful day, but this is a great conclusion. And what¬ís more apt than The Abyss for the one and only VP debate for 2008? - a very drinkable and lovable RIS.

With the arrival of the 2010s, decided to start into my 2009s. 22 oz Bomber poured into a Great Lakes snifter I got as a Xmas gift. Pours a motor oil black with a light brown head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Tastes of dark chocolate, espresso, molasses, and licorice, with a bit of bitterness on the finish. Rich, with very little bourbon-barrel flavor for me, mostly espresso. Still, the smooth mouthfeel has a decent amount of carbonation and is very nice overall. Guess I got a good one.... One down, 4 more to go.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2011 2009 Reserve black pour tan head ... had at two different tastings bottles opened both infected ... had a sour aroma but not too strong still smelled light molasses and roasted malts light chocolate .... sour and oaky roasted taste light molasses and licorice but its hard to tell will have to try a different year sometime had hardly any barrel taste 3.5 ........ 2010 black pour orange head .... aroma of licorice, cocoa and molasses with a nice roasted kick ..... taste is roasted and cocoa with light licorice and molasses with a dry oak ... bourbon is minimal the cocoa and roasted flavors go together very well in this brew very dry and roasted finish abv hidden well

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2013 ¬í08 bottle drunk Dec. ¬í10.  Amazing nose shows the molasses and licorice along with terrific coffee and caramel sweetness.  Totally opaque in the glass with thick legs and lacing.  Tastes incredibly rich and complex with a great stout profile and coffee, licorice, and caramel again.  Bourbon only shows in the sweetness and is very subtle...this beast keeps it in check.  What a treat.

>>Not changing numbers on this for now.  2012 bottle had with a year on it.  Licorice and camomille, wiht dark burnt malts, dark roast coffee on the nose.  Strong burnt malt and hop bitterness, on dark chocolate and dark malt core.  Not nearly as sweet as I remember.  Think this could easily go a couple more years.   Brooding beer at this point or just very different from what I recall of the last one I had.

On tap at Craft and Commerce.  Pours dark as night with a nice thick head.  Smells of chocolate, burnt wood and coffee.  Tastes of roasted nuts, coffee, chocolate and very little booze...it is hidden really well.  Smooth mouth feel.

Sampled at Gerry¬ís Xmas Big Beer Vertical. Thanks Gerry! This was a 22oz bottle of the 2009. Pours a super deep black with slight brownish lacing. Aroma is deep and complex. Iodine and licorice dominate the nose, some woodiness. Flavour is a bizarre mixture of chicory, smoked salmon, licorice, roasted brown sugar sweetness in the background. Alcohol evident but not overly boozy. Finish is delicious and lingering. Most excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2011 Bottle split with Linh at Toronado. Vintage bottle 09. Pours a pitch, jet black with slight chocolate-brown lacing. Aroma is deliciously sweet and complex - with notes of chocolate, bourbon, brown sugar, licorice, and molasses. Mouthfeel is velvety smooth with notes of bourbon, oak, chocolate, molasses, wood, coffee and a slight burn in the finish. What a diesel stout. ::: second try at capones on draft. A lot more woody barbecue sauce dang not too sure about my overall impression. Would like to see a more balanced version of this as I originally remembered from the bottle.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a beige head.  Aroma shows notes of roasted malt, tobacco, bourbon, oak, licorice, salted meat, molasses, and chocolate.  Flavor shows the same with an additional dark fruit sourness that has developed over time.  Very nice.

Wow, this did not disapoint.  Brand new 2010 release.  Bought 2 - 1 to try and one to age since the "best after" date is 11/11.  Definitely stll didn¬ít suck now, so it may be hard to wait the year.  Pours thick, deep black (pours like molasses) with similar thick tan head.  Head seriously lingered, making that much more visually appealing.  Nice sticky lacing throughout.  Smells delicious, sweet.  Molasses, as implied, as well as chocolate covered raisins and licorice. Full-bodied beer that pleasantly coats the mouth.  A touch of bitterness, along with the 11% evenly match the sweetness that carries through to the end.  This may be a long 11 months...

Tasted from a 2010 bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Dark brown/black body and dark brown head.  Aroma is pretty complex- there¬ís the dark roasted malts, the oak, and even Bourbon.  Initially dark roasty malts just like an Imperial Stout should be.  You get most of the oak, vanilla, and Bourbon in the back of your mouth.  Unlike many Bourbon barrel aged Imperial stouts, this one does not have an overwhelming Bourbon flavor that many times overpowers the rest of the flavor.

2009 Reserve

Poured from a bottle into an imperial pint glass. This bottle was gotten due to a good friend of mine wanting to go to a CCB cask event and me taking his shift for him so he could attend. Im sure that will make it that much better.

A-pours an insane black that when help up to the light changes nothing. Never seen a beer this dark and the name fits. I very thick head in the shade of mocha with a rocky top is taking a while to melt. impressive do to the abv. The heal melts very slowly and leaves think sheets of bubbly lace.

S-The smell is very complex. Waves of dark chocolate and hints of coffee. Smells are cohesive and no alcohol is apparent. 

T-I cant express how much excitement built in writing the previous parts to this review and on the first taste I am AMAZED. I have had a number of highly ranked souts and the flavor of this only beets them by a small amount. But the best thing is that the balance is perfect. This bottle will reach its recommended consume after date next month but as of right now. The waves of dark chocolate and mild sweet coffee with hints of licorice even bits of oak. They all come together with perfect balance and without any other offputting flavors. EPIC.

M-mouthfeel is luxurious smooth and full. It has enough fullness to coat your mouth with complex flavor. Leaves no dryness or any funky after taste.

D-Drinkiability is amazing and flawless...this beer leaves me speechless... believe the hype.

09 Bomber. Pours black with camel head that fades, leaving little lace. Nose mostly of oak and molasses, with hints of coffee, vanilla, and roasted malt. Very full bodied. Taste of semi-sweet chocolate, molasses, honey, roasted nuts, and dried dark fruit. Absolutely no sign that this is 11%ABV. Full bodied; very little bitter on the finish. Just yummy! My hat is of to Deschutes for this gem.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 2008 Version. Thanks to azbucfan for setting me up with the bottle.

G: Poured into an oversized brandy snifter.

A: Pours motor oil black. The head is a caramel-color with a bit of a crimson streak and plenty of bubbles. Excellent lacing. 

S: Plenty of dark espresso, ripening into a malty sweetness. I can definitely make out some of the brewer¬ís licorice. Clear scent remains from the bourbon barrels, although I can only make out a bit of the oak.

T: In addition to everything from the nose, a bit of burnt chocolate, in addition to slightly-burnt coffee and roasted dark malt. 

M: Incredibly creamy with low carbonation. Very full-bodied. 

D: So smooth and complex; this is a good one to sip for quite a well. Nice addition to the great week I¬ím having celebrating my 25th birthday. So far, I¬íve had Dark Lord and Pliny the Elder. We¬íll see how many top ten¬ís I can fit into this week.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-28-2009

Wax Dipped 2009 Bomber. Obsidian black in appearance with an inch of thick and creamy cappuccino head. The aroma is a blend of licorice, dark roast coffee and bittersweet chocolate with a touch of whiskey. The taste begins with potent molasses and roasted malt flavors along with espresso, licorice, caramel and vanilla. Also some pleasant smoky oak and bourbon flavors in the background. The mouthfeel is appropriately thick and creamy with soft carbonation and a malty, boozy finish. It¬ís incredibly well-balanced considering the intensely rich and dark flavors and 11% ABV level. Damn good Imperial Stout that should only improve with age.

Although not a huge licorice fan, the oak flavor of this beer impressed me immensely. Very rich, very refined, I bought a bottle thinking I would simply enjoy it on a cold night by myself and wound up pouring tastes for any friends who happened to be nearby. Just fantastic.

Bomber. Black pour with a tan head leaving moderate lace. Dark chocolate, black licorice, dates, coffee and dark-roasted malt flavors, with the latter two being stronger near the finish. Heavy body with oily mouth feel, the way an Imperial Stout should be! Very tasty, but far from sessionable due to the intensity of the aroma.

¬í09 bottle.  Aroma is peat, dry roasted malt, bitter chocolate, a light barrel influence, sweet molasses, and perhaps subtle, dark cherry.  Aroma profile is wonderfully tight with nothing out of place.  Reminds a little of the Zhukov but there¬ís more going on here behind the dry, peat smell.  Flavor is massive smokey, roasted malt, bitter and decadent chocolate, minor bitter hops in a perfect supporting role, and trailing cherry/dark fruit notes.  Like the aroma the flavor profile is tight.  Stunning.
Bottled sample at Ftahers Office in Culver City.  Unreal tasting beer.  Had it with a beautiful cheese plate. Abosultely loved it.

¬í09 bottle generously traded from brewolf.  Ok, so I opened this bottle a little sooner than initially intended due to some talk of infection with this batch.  In short, if any infection does exist it¬ís light but this still wasn¬ít a mind blowing experience.  The pour is thick and black with a good sized beige foam on top.  Coffee and chocolate aroma, nice mocha smell, with some molasses, plum, and licorice joining.  Roasty flavors consisting of rich malts, mocha, a bolder coffee note such as espresso, molasses, and a slight tart apple/cherry.  The last one is the only reason I even suggest a mild infection might be there but it¬ís completely nonexistant as it warms and the bold and roasty flavors take over.  The palate here is chewy, heavy, but relatively drinkable for what it is.  There¬ís some alcohol heat but I don¬ít really pick up any bourbon.  Just alcohol meaning the abv is high.  Burnt char and wood on the back end with some lingering bitterness.  I think I can safely put this one in the good but not great category.

2009 Bottle.  Coffee/chocolate aroma with oak and vanilla mixed in.  Flavor is nice, well balanced, and is relatively easy to drink considering the ABV.  Something about this beer didn¬ít meet expectations, however.  I¬íll re-rate when I get the chance.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Pours clear black with a beutiful big creamy tanned head. Aroma is something Willy Wonka would recognize, it is heavy malty, light and dark chocolate, liquorice, vanilla and prunes. The aroma develops during this tasting, and becomes even more inviting as it warms up. Could sniff this all evening, but it is time to let this elixir massage my water filled mouth. And the taste is as good as the aroma suggested, and nothing is out of shape here, this is a well balanced beer, not overdoing anything. Heavy roasted malts, all the chocolate notes, liquorice. The finish is long and dry. This could be the best beer ever for Willy Wonka !

Review #300, and it¬ís a good one!
22oz bottle, best after Nov 1, 2010.  Wanted to crack this right around the 1-year mark although I was getting tempted to open it earlier due to threats of possible infection but it appears this bottle is safe!  Whew!
Pours thick black with a large foamy brown head, holds a light cap and leaves a few random clumps of lacing.Aroma is heavy on the oak, bourbon, and vanilla, a lot of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and anise round things out.  Good strength.  Give it some time to warm and the aroma gets even better...had to bump it up another point as the strength improves as well as the complexity and an added smoke character and more chocolate, although the main stars are still the wood, bourbon, and vanilla.Flavor is rich and malty, a ton of dark roasted malt, heavy doses of chocolate and coffee, vanilla and oak are also very prominent with a hint of bourbon, some anise, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, incredibly complex and delicious.  Alcohol is pretty much non-existent although the second half which was left to warm on the counter has a bit of an alcohol bite on the finish.Mouthfeel is fairly thick and creamy, however the carbonation can be a bit prickly at times but subsides a bit as it warms.There are a bunch of adjectives I could throw down here but I¬íll just use one:  Magnificent.  A work of art.

Bottled, as Deschutes The Abyss Reserve 2009, kindly shared by gunnar. Pitch black colour, excellent brown head. Lovely and complex aroma of dark malts, chocolate, coffee, tobacco, liquorice and leather, also some oaky and vinous notes. The flavour has notes of heavily roasted malts, balanced by a suitable sweetness, coffee and liquorice, hints of sandalwood. Superb!
Right from the get go the roastiness mixed w/ the overwhelming creaminess of the molasses/licorice make this an inviting treat. The 09¬í licorice note lingeres on to long as you drink your way in
2009 (bottle) very dark brown - almost black, with medium tan head; aroma of light soy sauce, caramel, coffee; intense flavour on more on the bitter side, with long medium bitter finish

With great thanks to Blankboy. Appearance: Pitch black with a beautifully creamy tanned head. Aroma: wonderful creamy coffee, milk, baileys, malt, tons of oak and leather, whiff of peat and bacon, shortbread and brown sugar, just delicious. Flavour: wow, deliciously creamy coffee, oak, whiskey, malt, dark chocolate, cherry, tons of spices, roasty as hell, lots of smoke, bacon and a tremendous blast of leather, long spicy, alcoholic, roasty finish. Tremendous.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle. 2009 version. Black body with tall brown head. Sweet, malty nose that is also slightly sour. This was worrying to me. But taste really nice of malts, chocolate, licorice and caramel. Finish gets sour then turns malty again. A truly amazing ride.

2009 pours solid black with a huge frothy brown head. Aroma has mild bourbon, chocolate, dark fruit, a little bit of tart, wood, vanilla.  Taste is very rich, dark chocolate bitterness, milk chocolate sweetness. Body is silky with medium carboantion. Finish has some coffee and burnt malt bitterness and alcohol. Very good and complex. Not sure if this is a bottle that has a slight infection from wild yeast, but if so I think it is very mild at this stage and compliments the beer. I think some of the funk that people are getting could be mistaken as wild yeast but is really the bourbon and oak.  When I initially smelled the beer I thought wild yeast but the more I get into it, I smell it as bourbon.

2008. This beer has sure been getting a lot of hype lately around my neighborhood so I took the $10 plunge and bought a bomber of this beer.

A- Abyss black with a 1+ head and pretty good lacing. The brown head had an almost oily consistency with rainbow bubbles. 
S-Dark roast malts with chocolate, carmel, and licorice.
T-Complex but balanced dark malts, molasess, chocolate, and licorice. Pretty good alcohol kick too. 
M-heavy and chewy with good carbonation
D-I wasn¬ít as impressed as some people I¬íve talked to about this beer, but it is very good. I probably won¬ít buy this again just because there are some really good similar beers in Colorado for similar or cheaper prices.

[2009] Opaque black with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, light pine, some floral hops, light oxidation, cocoa. smoke, and alcohol.  Taste of roasted malts, dark chocolate, grassy hops, smoke, light dark fruits, and some alcohol.

Bottle share thanks dalzale. Pour is oil black brown with big tan kahki head. Aroma is burbon wood and coco with some faint hops as well. Taste is coffee and coco with wood with some vanilla and hop spices. Palate is full and creamy with a thick sticky feel that finishes dry. This is a great beer.

2009 Reserve, with a "best after" date of 11/1/2010. 650 mL bottle from AJ¬ís Fine Foods in Tucson, served in a snifter. Pours dark, opaque black with a tall frothy dark tan head. The head has good retention and coats the glass with lace. On the nose, there are aromas of oak, licorice, coffee, earth, whisky, berries and molasses. The flavour is surprisingly dry, with a moderate hop bitterness throughout. Notes of berries, coffee and charcoal lead to a deep, intensely roasted finish with strong hopping. On the palate, this is full in body with an alcoholic texture and soft carbonation. On the whole, this is a beautiful imperial stout. It is drier than many others and presents huge roasted notes along with molasses and whisky. It is also well hopped, and the final impression is of a very well balanced brew. It is incredibly complex; easily one of the best imperial stouts out there. I understand that many bottles of the 2009 vintage were infected with wild yeast, but there was no sign of that in this bottle. An amazing experience. I wish I had a few more bottles to keep in the cellar. 2010-09-24
The aroma is sweet malts, hops, soy, and strong overall. The color is black with an awesome creamy cocoa tan head. The flavor is a nice thick body with some roasted malts and a bit of hops.

Pours black with a brown head. The aroma has choclate, coffee, molasses, vanilla, and a slight hint of oak. The flavor has a big whack of licorice, chocolate, vanilla, roast, and again oak. The oak is held well in check. Excellent ballance and a really nice beer.

Bottle, 2009 Vintage. First bottle out of the freaking CASE I bought that wasn¬ít infected. Stupid ¬í09 vintage bullshit... Anyhoo - Pours completely opaque black, thin and highly persistent dark tan head, lacing is spotty to good. Nose is really profound with the coffee/molasses notes, loads of acidity here, but not infected acidity (I smelled enough of that), just a bright, clean, coffeish acidity. Flavour is very dry and ashy, a total departure from the Cigar City/Dark Lord/Surly Darkness school of super-sweet Impy Stouts, this one is wonderfully, refreshingly dry, more like Expedition. Flavours of coffee, chocolate, molasses, heavy on the molasses, plus roast, very dry and clean finish. Lovely, though I¬ím trying not to let the other 11 infected bottles, and the anger thereof drive this score lower.

A: The pour is a viscous elixir, nearly black in color with a solid finger¬ís worth of mocha head.

S: A wonderful combination of roasted malts, licorice, coffee, and sweet, creamy chocolate. A few notes of oak, vanilla, and maybe even dark molasses.

T: Lots and lots of chocolate and roasted malts up front. There is a subtle woody character that comes through nicely, along with a hint of bourbon, vanilla, and licorice. Wonderfully balanced between the sweet and roast/bitter flavors.

M: The body is silky, smooth, and creamy with a low-ish level of carbonation.

D: This is probably my favorite vintage of Abyss, and with good reason. So many great flavors and so easy to drink. It¬ís really too bad this year¬ís developed an infection.
22 oz. bottle 2007.  wow this beer ages awesome.  I¬ím not huge on the licorice that i taste in the fresh bottles, but that really mellows in this aged bottle.  black, tan head, roasty and awesome.

(bottle - 22 oz - 2009 vintage) Dark black pour with a thick tan head. Huge roasted aroma with a big oak and bourbon backbone behind it. Flavor is a big roasted malt bomb at the start with a smooth and sweet oak and bourbon middle. Very bitter and roasted note, almost coffee-like, at the finish. The molasses definitely helps to give it that thick body but I couldn¬ít really taste the licorice. Doesn¬ít really matter though. It¬ís awesome.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 08 bomber courtesy of JohnnyJ.  This is one bad mutha fu.  SHUT your mouth.  But i¬ím talkin bout shaft.  Seriously, I have never poured a beer that had so much freakin¬í aroma.  HUGE chocolate and molasses nose.  The color was Joan Jett black with a big brown head.  The taste was outstanding with massive molasses, bitter chocolate, dark roasted malt, and subtle oak.  It¬ís chewy and perfectly balanced.  This is one of my top 5 imperial stouts....

(2006 reserve) - Blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah....this stuff is freakin good!!!!!!! This is the BEST Imperial Stout I have ever had. Not really picking up the licorice though. Well n/m was good till my 4 year old knocked it over...now it just looks like motor oil on my carpet....dang!!!!!!

Bottle.  Thanks vtafro for the share. Pure black with a khaki head and nice lacing.  Chocolate comes through strong in the aroma with deep roasted maltiness.  Quite hoppy in the flavor on top of the burnt malt, very dry finish on a fuller body.  This is true class and a very awesome brew.  Worth the hype.

Decidedly perfect. I picked this up on a whim as an extra to bring home (California to Canada) and it impressed my fellow tasters. As black as the abyss.. midnight is scared to look into this one. Deep, cavernous and thick layers of wood, coffee and a thick rich molasses. The bitter chocolate and hops help round out  the black licorice.. I am sure there is more.. I would love to get my hands on this one again. Pours like thick, gooey motor oil with wool thick head. I would love to through myself down this chasm again..

Bomber shared with mrbunn, even though our wives hate us and don¬ít want us to be happy.  Pours Satan¬ís soul black with an initially thick, but fast-fading brown sugar head.  Aroma is a all leather, earth, and cocoa.   Flavor is bitter chocolate, then I detect a medicinal/metallic taste 2/5 of the way through, followed by spicy , herb flavor to complement the leather, rich fertile earth, and cocoa, anise and dark fruit, though the latter is far less pronounced than in the aroma.   Good stuff, lasting palate, creamy full mouthfeel.  Nice, very nice, but not awesome.

Bottle shared at BCTC 2010. Pours pitch black, a little oily, with a sturdy brown head. Big roasted malt aroma with dark chocolate, espresso, bourbon and candy. Flavor is intense and beautifully layered. The foundation is a deep, rich malt character, upon which notes of cocoa, caramel, molasses, hard alcohol, dark fruits and coffee dance together. Full bodied with mild carbonation and a velvety mouthfeel. Finishes richly sweet with lingering smokiness. Extremely good. First class Imperial Stout.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2012 2010 vintage on 1/7/12 purchased at Davidson¬ís.  pitch black pour with a 1 finger tan head with tiny bubbles.  sweet nose with licorice, molasses and deep malts.  full chewy body with chocolate, light coffee, molasses, licorice, sweet malts, sugar, dark fruits, light oak and vanilla.  smooth and complex throughout.  this beer continues to impress me.  bright finish with big dark fruit notes along with vanilla, oak, chocolate and molasses.

my 100th Imperial Stout!  2008 Vintage bomber poured into a snifter.  Pours a nice black with a big 1 1/2 finger tan rocky head - which fades down to a solid creamy lacing.  The nose is full of licorice, molasses, light coffee, chocolate, light oak and a touch of Bourbon.  I was expecting more barrel notes, but the base really shines through the most.  Big chewy body with smooth sides, a bitter front and heavy roast on the back end.  You can feel the depth of the malts through this one - almost like drinking oatmeal.  Lots of flavor throughout - coffee, licorice, deep dark fruits, light vanilla, light Bourbon, oak and big roasted malts.  Things have mellowed out since bottling no doubt - I would like to grab a fresh bottle this winter and compare.  Excellent Imperial Stout - although I would like to see more of the barrel portion come forward.
Malty chocolate. Super strong. The smell makes my stomach hurt. The taste is strong. Good in small sips. Why is this in a bomber? I need this to be sold in an airline bottle.

5 from me. Black as a black hole, with a blood tinted beige foam on top that you can cut with a knife. Nose starts with oak cask that is blended with  dark chocolate, espresso, caramel and some plums, followed by molasses and licorice, and a respectable amount of hops. Medium dense body with medium carbonation, very very oily. Probably one of the strongest characters I ever tasted in a stout.

0,65 l bottle from CrackedKettle, courtesy of Balazs. Thanks!
Yes. This ale is deep. Both in appearance, aroma and flavor. Deep black body, impermeable for any light. Pillowy, creamy head with beige color, some reddish tinge in the foam like blood. Unbelievable laces on the glass. Characteristic aroma with deep roasted malt, wood and coffee. Fine dark chocolate, vanilla and licorice, sweetish caramell and molasses. Somewhere some herbal hop is lurking in the background. Oh my god, the flavor. Consistence of rock oil, rich and complex texture. Deepdeep roasted malt with the oak casks character, coffee and molasses, dark chocolate, tobacco. On the middle of the slips a bit of herbal hops come throught, but the oily, roasted grains rules the palate and the longlong aftertaste. Yes. And yes again. And again.

2009 Vintage, this one was mildly infected.  Served from bottle into a Stone nonic.  Pours black with a massive tan head that remains throughout.  Maintains phenomenal lacing throughout.  The aroma was comprised of malt and a tart note (first sign of infection).  The flavor was of syrup, licorice, malt, and a slight tart taste (also due to infection).  It was medium on the palate with low carbonation.  Overall this was a nice beer even though it was infected.  Goes down smooth regardless of that fact as well.  Would love to try a non-infected bottle to be able to give it a true rating of its capabilities (hint hint traders...)
Its dark almost black in color. It has a nice chocolate molasses syrup taste with hints of liquorish. This beer is paradise. Absolutely love this one it was a 2007 vintage.

Deep deep balck with an almost brown head. Big, busty aroma of roast and raisins with hints of coffee and licorice. Palate is heavy and rich and warming, quite amazingcomplex flavours going on in this beer. I¬íve had some big stouts before but this has to be one of the biggest! So rich I almost, almost struggled to finish the 22oz on my own, but I don¬ít think I could share it anyway. Great beer, well done Deschutes!
Ambrosia pure and simple. The only beer greater in the stout/porter category would be the Abyss aged! If you want a truely amazing beer let this beer age a year or two.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 A: Pitch black body.. brownish edges... dark, dark brown with hints of gold in the light... decent lacing... solid retention

S: Rich chocolate, licorice and hints of coffee... subtle booze and bourbon lines the background.. slightly woody and earthy

T: Spot on... I think this is, hands down, the smoothest tasting beer... each flavor transitions effortlessly to the next... licorice runs throughout with coffee and chocolate taking up positions in the front and back respectively... nice semi-dry finish with a dash of bitterness

M: Surprisingly light... on the spectrum i¬íd place this in the middle of medium bodied... which is a very nice thing for a beer of this complexity

O: Hands down the best stout with decently large production on the market... i¬íve had all the big boys

2009 vintage bottle thanks to hopscotch. Pours black with tan head. Nose is deep roasted coffee, oak, bourbon, chocolate. Taste is molasses, bourbon, oak, heavily roasted coffee beans, mocha and licorice.

2007 Reserve.  Lots of things going on in this stout and that¬ís only from taking a deep whiff. Sweet aroma mixed with chocolate and roasted coffee.  Bourbon taste has mellowed with age.  Definitely taste the licorice and molasses mixed with bitter chocolate, roasted malts and espresso.  Hot alcohol when it was first released has really mellowed out.  Good stuff!

2007 black wax bottle courtesy of jake65.  Thank you Jake for this gem.  Awesome pour, pours a viscous jet black with no head to speak of, just a ring of mocha colored foam around the glass.  Intense aroma of heavily roasted malts, cocoa, burnt toast, coffee and some booze.  Flavor is huge on the roasted malts.  All over the place flavors.  Coffee bitterness rounds out the finish which stays with you for a bit.  Some bourbon flavors kick in towards the end of this one, nice indeed.  Thick and creamy mouthfeel does not disappoint.  This stout is huge and my first offering from Deschutes, hopefully not my last.  Glad I saved this one for the 115th rating.

2007 reserve, black waxed bottle courtesy of mreusch. thanks, matt! pours a thick, velvety black with a thick, red-clay colored head leaving sheets of oily lace on the glass. aroma is fantastic with huge roasted malts, dark chocolate, char, and molasses up front with very subtle notes of top-soil, earthy hops, and oak as it warm with hints of dark fruits and licorice hiding amidst the roast. flavor is absolutely delicious with massive roasted malts, burnt wood, and bittersweet chocolate blended seamlessly with notes of caramel, molasses, and sweet oak with smooth, subtle notes of bourbon on the swallow. palate is full bodied and silky smooth on the tongue with light carbonation and a long, lingering roasted finish with a touch of coffee. overall, a wonderful world-class imperial stout.

Aroma:Upon first whiff, I get a slightly sour bourbon smell. There is just a hint of chocolate and caramel in the nose.

Appearance:This is a dark, dark beer, with a thick and creamy head, that you can cut with a knife. Very decent lacing.

Taste:Alcohol burn hits you squarely upon the first sip. The foretaste is a slightly sour bitterness with dark malts. The creamy dark malty flavor continues through the mid and aftertaste. The hops play second (or third) fiddle to the malts and bourbon.

Palate:Thick and creamy, with alcohol heat. Not very much carbonation in the mouthfeel.

Overall:This 2009 beer is Best After 11/1/2010, and could definitely use more aging. As the beer is still young, it makes sense that the bourbon is on the heavy side, but still an enjoyable sipping beer.

Roasty, coffee, chocolate, molasses, licorice, vanilla, bourbon, oak, hops...what else is there? A fairly viscous imperial stout that is inky deep brown with a dark tan head fairly persistent head. Slight legs from alcohol. Bottle says 11% but this is an ¬í07 so maybe it¬ís picked up a bit in the bottle. I haven¬ít had one of these in over a year, but as I remember it this one has definitely smoothed out a bit. A great beer young, better two and a half years old, but I can¬ít wait to see what a few more years does for it...well I guess I¬íll have to. Silky creamy mouthfeel with pleasant alcohol warmth. Considering the age, maybe the best Imperial Stout I¬íve had the pleasure of drinking. Too bad my friend decided he shouldn¬ít finish his half since he had to drive!

2009 bottle thanks to Bigmmartin.  Black beer with a decent tan head.  Chocolate, coffee and dark fruits in the aroma.  Licorice comes across bittersweet.  Finishes dark chocolate and coffee with the bitterness you would expect of those two but in a nice subdued way.  Alcohol comes out as it warms up a little more than I would like.

2009 bottle, big thanks to Matt.  Pours black with a deep mocha head that settles to a fine lacing.  Nose is a tight collage of dark malt, bourbon, ash, and vanilla.  A bit of coffee creeps into the flavor, which is focused on the ash with a light bourbon backing.  Fairly bitter in the finish.  This is a nice, refined package.  I¬ím still trying to get the taste of the horrid Mikkeler Black Hole (Red Wine) out of my mouth, which was a drain pour and a lost $14.  This serves the purpose, and it¬ís quite a good imperial stout without any blaring features but quite a nice, balanced package for the style.

Serving: Bottle 
It pours pitch black with a small tan head.  The nose is full of dark fruit, slight burnt notes, loads of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate.  The flavor is flinty and very roasty with a hint of very dark chocolate, raisins, dates, and a touch of warming alcohol.  The body is rich and creamy with a lingering roasty finish.  This brew is outstanding.

Bottle shared with bigmmartin and ewestern.  What a different stout.  Aroma is sweet with burnt malts.  Notes of dark fruit, chocolate, molasses, licorice, and yeast come out.  On the palate, it is a bit chewey.  Flavor brings out the molasses and subdues the licorice.  It finishes with a coffee, dark chocolate flavor.  Very different, complex, and good.  Thanks Mike for sharing and thanks 1_2many for sending it.

Bottle shared by kestral.
Coffee, chocolate. Soft porter, cocoa, liquorice. Smooth and pleasant.

Sampled at SAVOR 2010.  Pours a lightly oily, opaque black with a thin, beige head.  Nose is nice, woody, coffee, burnt toast.  Flavor is brown sugar, coffee, licorice, wood pulp, umami, malts.  Finish is full bodied and just a touch hot.  This needs more time in the bottle, but still good.

Bottle, 2007 vintage. An opaque black beer with an average sized, creamy, mostly diminishing brown head. The aroma is heavily malty and lightly to moderately hoppy, with notes of roasted grains. chocolate, coffee, grapefruit, vanilla, licorice, alcohol, with a hint of berries and some oak and bourbon. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly sour, lightly to moderately bitter. Heavily roasted malts and a good balance. Very nice an dcreamy mouthfeel, full body, soft to lively carbonation, very long finish with medium to heavy bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Very good, creamy, hugely malty and roasted, with a nice hoppiness.

Popped a bottle of 2007 this past weekend as part of a big tasting party.  poured a nice dark oily black with a thin tan head.  Lots of nut and chocolate in the nose with a hint of alcohol.   Smooth and easy at the start with a strong finish.   By far the best stout I¬íve ever had.  Beat the Dark Lord, hands down at the tasting.

Draft at Humpy¬ís in Anchorage.  Pours a thick black.  Almost perfect for a stout but could have been slightly more viscous.  Aroma of booze, chocolate and vanilla.  Excellent beer, I¬ím happy to have tried on draft.

2007 Vintage Bottle
released January of 2008
consumed in January of 2009

Appearance: Double wax covered bomber poured into a pint glass. Sexy black color with crushed red velvet corners. An oily sheen glazes over a brown mocha crown with mahogany highlights. Nice! Fair amount of head retention, quite rocky, some lacing.

Smell: black licorice, a small coffee tinge, molasses, and a touch of alcohol melded into a smooth yet complex nose. A touch faded with the year of cellaring on it so I¬ím giving it a 4.0 instead of a 4.5

Taste: Still some bourbon zing up front after the year of aging. Its a shame that the bourbon zing has an astringent quality. A nutty bridge comes next and then it finishes with a a bitterness normally associated with coffee. I might have caught this one at a transition period because the flavors seem to lack the strength and boldness of a fresh bottle, yet they fail to be completely fused as I was hoping for.

Mouthfeel: Lots of carbonation help this high ABV full bodied Imperial Stout. A touch thick but not to the point where I¬íd use the word syrupy. Very nicely done.

Drinkability: The mouthfeel really helps boost the drinkability of this 11% brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-21-2009
Pours oily black with a thin brown head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is almond and dark fruit.  Taste is muted sweetness.  Starts thin and finishes thick.  Alcohol warms the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 Pours a dark black color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit, chocolate, and alcohol.  Has a sweet taste.  More watery and alcohol biting up front.  Then turns more malty and chocolaty on the back end.  2009 Vintage.  Needs some aging.   Too harsh and not worthy of a BA top 5 spot.

2009 Vintage. Pours a very dark brown almost black with tan mocha head. Aroma is very roasty with coffee, licorice, and oak. Taste is similar with some chocolate bar and very bitter coffee taste. Pallet is a little on the thin side for an impy stout. Overall pretty good though.

2009 Vintage...

Pours a dark brown with a beautiful fluffy thick tan head.  Aroma is a bit sour actually with a flavor to match.  After the initial sour-ish flavor passes there is a nice malty/roasty taste that begins to take over.  As it warms up the flavor change and it becomes much more enjoyable and drinkable.  Definitely something I want to revisit with a bit more age on it...

Tasty!

Pours a deep, brutish black and topped with creamy milk chocolatey brown head from the 22oz. bottle courtesy of Doodler (thanks, Scott!): Nose of dark roast, smoke, vanilla, burnt wood, subtle chocolate, oat, beef jerky, sharpie pen, and alcohol. Flavors of thick wood, chocolate, licorice, vanilla, deep roast, espresso, some citrusy hops, and spicy yeast. Low in carbonation. Drinkability: Sweet, hot, and vindictively boozy. Pairing: A chunk of venison. Rebuy: For when I want to feel formidable. #439 on 05052010, DG.

09 Vintage. Bottle thanks again to Owen. Pour is jet black with large dense beige coloured head. Heaps of lacing as this falls away. The licorice definately comes through in the aroma as does toasted malt, plenty of vanilla toffee and dark fruits. Good nose and certainly very complex. Flavours are more straight forward for me. Plenty of hop and toasted malt bitterness, sublte sourness from the roasted malt and a touch of dark choclate. Mouthfeel quite oily. Nice beer but no where near as big as I thought it would be.
bomber shared by kyle-thanks man-black pour-brown head-aroma and tast of chocolate, coffee, raisin, -smooth chocolate fruit finish

(22 oz bottle).  Pours black-almost like oil-with a brown, chunky head that has come cascading action.  Beautiful! I thought the aroma would be overpowering given the bourbon barrels, but it not the case.  Perhaps if the entire brew was conditioned in them it would be too much.  Otherwise, it provides a nice aroma.  Scent of spices, crystal sugar, anise, and wood to match the bourbon. Taste is prickly on the tongue; sweet in the beginning, but bitterness finishing things off.  Dark roast/burnt/smoke. Alcohol is noticeable.  Quite good, but I¬ím not a fan of the burnt/dry finish.  I would have rated this higher if it were sweeter-my preference in a stout.  Good nonetheless, and very much appreciated.

¬í08 vintage. Shared w/dad as our beer to ring in the new year.

A- Body is a solid dark brown/nearly black hue with a slight tint of auburn to it. Pours with an approximately 1 finger foamy dark tan head that quickly subsides to a thin collar. Small traces of lacing are left in the glass. When held up to the light the hue does not change and no light passes through.

S- Magnificent. This truly has the perfect aroma for an imperial stout. Upon opening the bottle a sweet aroma came through of sweet molasses, vanilla, and mocha. These are the dominant aspects of the nose but there is also a hint of roasted malt. Not even a hint of phenols can be detected.

T- The flavor is mildly sweet and complex upfront. Vanilla and molasses are the dominant flavors upfront but oak and roasted dark malt flavors provide a very substantial backbone to mellow out the sweetness. The finish is sweeter with a rush of molasses caramel and vanilla which are quickly doused by a big roasted malt bitterness. Everything subsides and balances out in the end- Roasted malt is the highlight but vanilla, molasses, oak, and a mild alcohol heat are also present.

P- Medium carbonation and a medium to heavyweight an ever smooth body.

O- This is a wonderful stout and one of the best that I have had. I see why it is ranked among the best. The best thing about it is the balanced character it portrays in the flavor...one of my new favorite imperial stouts...and I will be trading for it again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-01-2010 05:45:48

Unfortunately I had this last week and can not remember all specific tasting notes...  a very nice black/deep red beer with light brown medium head and nice lacing; really a nice beer to look at if there is such a thing.  The licorice definitely came across as well as brown sugar/molasses, some coffee and an alcohol tone.  Pretty good stuff. Since I don¬ít have all the specifics, I¬íll unfortunately need to have this one again ;).  There were def some detractors so hopefully I¬íll be able to get those down.

The Abyss has a dark brown almost black in color with a dark brown brown head with little retention. The aroma is of roasted barley and rich coffee. This stout imparts an intense coffee flavor on your palette with minor hints of chocolate. There is very little carbonation which allows for the coffee flavors to really stand out. This is one of the few reserve series that Deschutes puts out that you can really taste the heat. There¬ís not a lot of residual sugar to mask the 11% ABV so despite its looks, it rolls through the mouth with a light body feel. Overall though I think this is another great reserve beer from Deschutes and I can see myself drinking it whenever I have the option.

Trade with Blutt59.  Beautiful appearance, Deep black, light brown head.  Aroma has a lot going on, licorice, brown sugar, oak, coffee, very light bourbon sweetness.  The flavor is coffee, licorice, oak (some things come through more in the aroma than the flavor.)  The fiish is roasty, coffee grinds, light bourbon warming.  Nice thick body, creamy mouthfeel.  Excellent beer.  Thanks, Bob.

2009 Reserve. My god... MY GOD! What a beer... Pitch Black with a nice sized frothy brown head that leaves a beautiful lacing. Aromas of licorice and molasses dominate. This is a thick, creamy, velvety monster. Pure perfection on the palate. Tastes of burnt roasted malts, chocolate, raisins, licorice, vanilla, oak, and bourbon are all present, a complex one this is. Get your hands on this one folks, it¬ís actually well worth the price of admission.

2009 bomber from Liquor Max in Loveland, CO.  Pours a deep black with and enormous billowing tan head.  Head sets and becomes rocky, slowly collapsing to a thin ring that leaves great lacing.  Nose is strong on the licorice and molasses, so much that it almost covers the coffee and roast malts.  All is right with the flavor, bringing complexities unlike any stout I¬íve ever had.  Dark fruit, dark roast coffee, burnt malt, molasses, and loads of licorice.  Velvety texture and a perfect alcohol presence make this quite possibly the best beer I¬íve ever had!  (Let¬ís see if BA Yeti can dehtrone it!)

Has a dark, roasted, smokey quality to it. The oak and the bourbon really comes through, more in the after taste then in the first encounter. The color is dark and thick. On the heavy side. Bring a friend to finish it.

2009 in a tulip glass - I had to try because I want to age a case for my birthday. An opaque, rich dark brown with a nice brown creamy head with frothy and fine bubbles. Subtle aroma with light traces of fumes. Very smooth with a sweet complex taste with light bitterness surrounding my mouth. Fine mouth feel that seems to linger on the tip of the tongue.  This is one of the best beers I have ever tasted. I would like to drink this all day.
22oz bottle into stemmed pint glass. Not much aroma but amazing flavors and a perfect full creamy feel. Spicy as it warms up & a little bitter too. 11% isn¬ít noticeable at all. Incredibly drinkable.

2008 vintage. Bomber served in a snifter. Beautiful, dense black coffee pour with a thick, medium-sized brilliant brown head. Medium retention and mild lacing. The complex aroma has nuts, molasses, oak, and roasted coffee. There¬ís also a slight sweetness. Flavor is rich and roasty. Black coffee with a dark chocolate bitterness. Full body, viscious, with a roasty, bitter, warming, supremely long finish.

Finally rating after many bottles and pours enjoyed over the years. Tried 08 and 09 side to side, preferred the aged. 08: Darker head, smoother body. Booze is more mellow with more licorice and molasses. Red wine, cider, apple tart. Coffee and dark chocolate. Rich and very deep, worth every drop. 09: Lighter and fresher, boozier up front. Bittering hops come through. Still great. One of my all time favorites

Bottle of the 2009 batch shared by Dogbrick at his Portland beer tasting. Pours black with a medium tan head. Malty aroma with notes of chocolate, molasses, raisin, licorice, roast and smoke. Flavor is malty chocolate at first, giving way to smoke before the raisin and licorice hit. A little of bit of alcohol makes itself known before the roasty coffee finish. Very good beer. There was no way it was going to live up to what was in my head, but it came close. Can¬ít wait to try a bottle with some age on it.

2008 vintage. Pours a deep black with an intimidating head. It looks like a thick dark, dark roast coffee brewed superhumanly strong. It¬ís an intimidating pour but looks quite appropriate in the snifter. Great aroma. At first, it¬ís thickly smoky, but this gives way to vast complexity. It¬ís sweet with fiery alcohol and earthy with the subtlety of oak. The taste has a lot of strong notes that are all battling it out. They¬íre all quite good and I certainly enjoy the beer very much, but everything is not yet quite melded. There¬ís strong alcohol, strong bourbon, strong smoke, strong wood, strong malt, good bitterness and good sweetness, but the battle almost burns the mouth.  This burn is a bit of a problem on the palate and the carbonation is a tad sharp but maybe just in relation to the flavor. It¬ís not so much that the carbonation is strong, but that it burns the flavor in a bit uncomfortably.  Will improve with age.

2007 bottle split with EithCubes and L.  Pours an opaque, inky black body with an average, creamy, milk chocolate brown head.  Light coffee roast and bitter chocolate nose with some faint bourbon.  Flavor of rich dark coffee, light licorice & bourbon, along with oak and vanilla rounding it out.  Full, viscous, smooth body with average carbonation for the style.  Mild alcohol warmth and a slightly sticky finish with a touch of lingering bourbon.  Overall a very well-made Imperial Stout.  Layered and mature, this beer is full of flavor, without trying to be a sledgehammer like so many of its peers.

2007 bottle (here at the end of March 2010) from a long-ago trade with jake65, if memory serves.  Thanks!  Huge nose - chocolate, molasses, licorice, light bourbon, vanilla, lighter alcohol.  Pitch pour with a lasting, lacing, leggy, rocky light brown head.  Gorgeous.  Taste is lightly tart, sweet, has vanilla and firm licorice much stronger than the chocolate or any sign of roast, vanilla, smooth as silk and drying out well into the aftertaste.  Ridiculous velvet smoothness.  Licorice is more than just an accent but not at all overdone; this might be the best showcase of licorice in a brew that I¬íve had.  Great character, big complexity and somehow manages to maintain a high degree of subtlety.  Well worth the wait!

Cocoa, coffee, vanilla, and oak.  Jet black liquid with tan lacing head. Heavy oily body with some carbonation. Starts with deep chocolate and some coffee, licorice and oak.  Bitter finish that sticks with you.

3/20/10:  2009 bomber ordered online through brewforia.com.  Dark black/brown pour with a frothy tan head and tons of stick.  Complex and subtle aroma of chocolate, dark malts, burnt wood, metal, alcohol and oat.  Tastes of wood, dark chocolate, espresso, roasted malts, slight yeast and licorice.  Dry ashy bitter finish.  Medium texture with a light spike of carbonation and a metallic hint.  Interesting stuff for sure.  Seems to be a good one to sit on for a couple years.

pitch black and viscous with a large tan head.  huge vanilla and roasty nose.  thick mouthfeel with some bitterness followed by vanilla, chocolate, licorice, and roasted notes.  alcohol providing a ton of depth, an amazingly flavorful beer that tastes as though it¬ís of half the alcohol.  extremely impressed
Lost my tasting notes for this one, but I recall not enjoying the overpowering licorice. Mouth feel and flavor fell short for me.
22oz bomber courtesy of mashmaster.  Had this right after Sexual Chocolate.  This one has more of the dusty chocolate characteristic and has a much bigger hint of grain to it.

Bomber poured into a snifter.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Aroma of coffee and bitter dark chocolate.  Taste of chocolate, coffee, molasses, and black licorice, with a bit of bitter hops.  Don¬ít taste any bourbon barrel aging, mainly coffee.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel, mild carbonation.  Good, but not sure I see why it¬ís so highly rated.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2010 great malty aroma.  beautiful dark color with an amber head.  Theres the honey!  And licorice!  great feel, and the taste reminds me of shots of whiskey and honey for a flu lol.  great beer!

Big bottle, kindly shared by Kestral. Dense and foamy light brown head. Body is as black as it get with no clarity. Roasted malt aroma, bordering on burnt, with a sourish and ashy accent.  Black chocolate and cold coffee as well, and tones of dried dark fruits. Taste is hard roasted, alcohol-soaked dark malts, bitter coffe, bitter chocolate, tar and wood. A noticable caramelly sweetness beneath.  Thick, almost syrupy mouthfeel. Hot, malty-bitter and roasted ending. Very potent and tasty, not fully balanced according to my tastebuds.
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2011 Draught at Mountain Sun. Black with tan head. Aroma of chocolate, molasses, and sweet malty booze. Flavor is chocolate, bread, caramel, and whiskey. Great!

2009 bottle thanks to DuffManSW.  Black pour with a 1-finger, loose, tan head and nice lacing.  The aroma is deep, bitter black coffee, licorice, strong dark chocolate and a hint of bourbon and alcohol.  The flavor is intense bitter black coffee and pure dark chocolate followed by a touch of oak and vanilla and then a hot, alcoholic bourbon finish.  The body is oily and full with moderate carbonation and a big alcohol bite on the end.

Black body with a nice tan head.  Chocolate with sweet caramel aroma.  It¬ís not horribly interesting.  It¬ís just like any other imperial stout.  Flavor is pretty solid though.  Dark chocolate notes with a nice bitter coffee flavor to balance it out.  Finishes with a nice and full body, and is overall a pretty good beer.

2008 vintage, thanx to my buddy Thomas. pours dark brownish black, lovely luxurious chocolate head, nose is boozy with oak and bourbon, bourbon is muted in flavor just adds a nice touch roasty and rich boozy and chocolate. amazing beer would love another to age.

2009 Reserve. Bomber at homebrewing extravaganza. Black as hell pour with no light coming through. Thick cappuccino colored head rests on top. Big earthy chocolate aroma with notes of wood. They should make an air freshener like this. I take my nose out of the glass long enough to take my first sip...body is surprisingly medium, thinner than I expected. Earthiness compliments the bitter malt, ash, and coffee. Slick, smooth feel. I have a diamond toilet! Niiiice!

Bottle from scrizzz, thanks man! Pours black, with a big, rocky light brown head, chunky sticky lacing. Nice. Aroma was immense, with peat, bacon, cocoa, chocolate, weed, coffee, plums and prunes. Very layered and complex. A sip brings forth ashes, tar, liquorice, and a big, strong burnt, bitter espresso finish. I would have liked this toned down just a tad. This is a thick, oily and viscous brew, with smooth and creamy carb. Couldn¬ít have been better in that aspect. So yeah, this is really good actually, but not perfect.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2010 Rerate

Black; medium tan head. Rich aroma, rubber, licorice. Flavor - not sweet at all. I love me some licorice but this is a little bit overboard. Has the effect of being very dried out. Persistent woody bitterness.



Unusual, rubber, peat, earth. Turns out to be a ton of licorice root. Medium sweetness. Relatively low roast levels. Unique for an imperial stout.

Thank you Tim(my brother)from Seattle.This was a serious beer.Complex as all get-out.I tasted chocolate,coffee,rum,caramel,bourbon,etc.....poure thick and smooth.Drank like a champ and I wish I had 1 MORE TO SAVE.Oh well looks like I¬íll have to head up to Seattle soon...
bottle, pours pitch black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is oaky with lots of wood.  Flavor is rich malt and earth notes.  Strong bitter expresso in the finish.  Crazy wierd.

Pours very dark, almost black....not much head.  Rich aroma, can smell the oak/bourbon combo. Tastes of burnt coffee and licorice. Can taste the complex notes but still quite drinkable. Thumbs way up, nice!

Eminently sippable beast. Obsidian beer with a milk-chocolate brown head. Potent nose of chocolate, roast espresso, vanilla, bourbon. Roasty, well-rounded bitterness is firm but not resinous or sticky... harmonious with the light sweetness. Fulsome, supple flavor. Good body but not too thick. Drinkable enough to kill a bomber in a few hours on my own, and usually I can¬ít do that with this sort of beer.

2009 Reserve. Bomber via Stefanje the magnificent.  Pours black with erupting tan head... woo hoo! Body is surprisingly medium. Milky slick and creamy with a gentle acrid malted bitterness supported with a nice oakyness.  Spots of thin lacing.  Gentle bourbon nose comes and goes.  Great by the fire with a thick book.  Presence of alcohol is unknown to the tongue.  Props to the Santee connection!

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2010 Bottled, deepest black pour of any beer with equal thickness huge chocolate head,  sweet roasted aroma with slight spice and rootbeer like quality, sweet malt up front with large roasted flavor finished by more sugary sweet taste and hop bitters, full bodied mouthfeel, yum.

very sweet aroma with hints of coffee and vanilla - dark, almost Guiness-like pour with thick brown head - strong flavor profile with coffee, toffee, licorice, brown sugar taste - leaves an excellent taste on the palate that lingers for a long time

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 ( 22oz bomber 2007 vintage thanks to cavie) Pours near jet black with nice oily bubbles. Nose of metal, Sawdust, dark chocolate, and cocoa. Taste of huge oak, cedar, bourbon, licorice, bitter semi-sweet chocolate and cream. thick body and lasting bitter finish. Good, but not what I expected. Many other stouts top this highly touted player.
Pours nearly jet black with ample head. Complex nose with subtle vanilla and coffee. Palate reveals syrupy molasses flavors. Gentle for the ABV. Long balanced gentle finish.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2011 Bottle. Pours a thick black with a light brown head that laces nicely. Aroma is full of dark grains, molasses, oak and a strong bourbon note. Flavor is complex with notes of oak, chocolate, coffee, molasses, oaked bourbon and licorice. Amazing on the tongue, nice and thick.

2008 bottle of the famed Abyss was a  blacky black beer with a beautiful looking head that dissipates. The aroma  had chocolate slight roastedness & some tar. This is probably the smoothest Imp. Stout I have had just a wonderfully smooth & intense of a beer with some chocolate in it & no noticeable alcohol whatsoever. The mouthfeel was superb so rich & creamy & coats your mouth nicely with a slight bitter ending.

"Midnight in a glass with a large, frothy brown head and enormous amounts of lacing. Lush aroma of cream, chocolate and fresh roasted coffee. Full bodied, mildly sweet and exceptionally smooth. Flavors provide a medley of milk, nuts, dark chocolates, coffee, vanilla and raisins. Great stuff here."

Tasted from a bomber from the 2008 Reserve.

This beer pours BLACK and it is completely opaque.  The head is spotty and brown with a red tint.  The first aromas that come to mind are molasses and cereal.  Other aromas include carob, black licorice, and toasted oak with a little bit of an alcohol burn.   To put things quite simply, this beer tastes almost exactly like it smells.  The addition is the black espresso flavor on the back of the palate and the finish.  The beer is extremely full bodied and oily.  The carbonation is still very alive, but has a creamy texture.  The finish lasts forever with a bitter coffee flavor.  Overall, this beer is awesome!  Exactly what I hope for in a huge stout.
****************************************** Tasting on the Same Night, here are the notes on the 2009 Reserve.  I know it says best after November of 2010, but I wanted to taste these two side by side.

Appearance (5/5) - Pretty much the same as the 2008.
Aroma (7/10) - Completely different...smells almost like a cola, considerably sweeter.  Chocolate malt, fertile soil, and a brown sugar sweetness.
Taste (6/10) - This is really bitter...maybe overly so.  Over-ripe plum, black pepper, carob.  Bitter, bitter, bitter.
Palate (4/5) - Full bodied, not as oily, much fizzier carbonation.  The finish still goes on forever.
Overall (15/20) - This is too young.  The note on the side of the bottle should be heeded.  That adds up to a total score of 3.7.

2007 bottle thanks to CaptainCougar.   Pitch black with a medium-small tan head.   Sweet aroma with intense malt, caramel, burnt sugars, and roasted malt.   Seems a little mellow, but at a couple years old, this was to be expected.   The flavor is dryer than I expected with a roasty bite in the finish.   Overall though, quite smooth with just a little more angular roast and a hint of alcohol towards the end.   Rich all the way through with a light lingering sweetness.   A touch of wood mostly adds to the dry feeling that I get, but bourbon is not at all evident, which I sort of like, but also doesn¬ít seem to be adding anything positive.   Medium-full in body with medium-low carbonation.   Pretty nice stout, but not the most intense, good or bad.   Mellow after a couple years, but still hanging on.   I¬íve really got to get around to cracking one of my relatively fresh ¬í09 bottles to compare now.

Poured from 22oz., darkest of browns with light tan head.  Nose of chocolate and dark coffee, roasted malt,  on the sweet side.  Taste was chocolate, booze, on the strong side.  Thick bodied and creamy, a very enjoyable brew for sipping.

Poured from 22oz bottle to snifter.

A: Pours a dark brown body that is basically black. Large brown head with great retention and interesting lacing after each sip. Almost perfect looking beer, but could have used a bit more lacing.

S: Strong roasted malts with a molasses sweetness tied in with licorice. Strong notes of alcohol and chocolate. This is a very strong scented beer, the king that you can pick up across a room.

T: Sweet and roasted malts upfront turn into licorice and molasses sweetness with some hop undertones. The finish turns into a strong bittersweet chocolate with a small hint of coffee laced with bold oak and a nice dash of bourbon. What impressed me most about this RIS is that all the flavors I love about the style made themselves very present. For the alcohol content I was surprised that more didn¬ít come out. This was absolutely amazing in flavor, completely lived up to the hype, it was perfect to me.

M: The mouthfeel was just as impressive as the taste or smell. Not too thick but still full bodied. Just the right amount of carbonation, small bubbles grace the tongue just enough to help pull out the complexity of this stout.

D: Wow, for how big of a beer this is it¬ís very drinkable. Usually with big stouts, I find it very hard to take down a bomber. This beer is easily drinkable by the bomber for one person, much more than I can say for anything else I¬íve had of the style. I honestly can¬ít believe this beer lived up to the hype of #3 on the top 100. I know some don¬ít care for it that much, but for me it was pretty much perfect.

22 oz. bottle 2007 vintage (tasted fresh and a few times since).  Pours black with a medium tan head.  The aroma is dark roasted malts with molasses, licorice, oak, and alcohol (stronger when fresh).  The flavor has a big dark roasted malt base with molasses, anise, dark chocolate, black coffee, earthy bitterness, light hints of oak and bourbon and alcohol.  Full bodied with moderate carbonation.  I have enjoyed this each time including a vertical from 06-08.  At the time, the consensus was for the 07 batch.  This is a standout beer.

Rating #708 for this beer.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2010 Rating the 2009. Medium chocolatety head. Coffee aroma is dwarfed by the alcohol smell, however the taste of the beer is incredible. Notes of coffee predominate the hint of chocolate, however both are present.. Finish is very malty and quite delicious.

5/21/10  2007 Vintage.  Aroma  7/10 Appearance 5/5 Taste  9/10
 Palate 5 /5 Overall  18/20  Total 4.4
Smell of alcohol still quite predominant, however it seems a bit mellower. The coffee is powerful and the chocolate i remember in the 09 is not present at all. Finish is very smooth. Aged beautifully 
.
Thick, black and sticky. Decent sized head. Toasted molasses, chocolate, with a little bit of hops, heavy alcohol. Long duration. Excellent.

2008 bottle via trade. Pours out black with a nice tan head. Aroma is of heavy roasted malts, chocolate, oak, slight vanilla and a little touch of alcohol. Taste is very complex, roasted malts, chocolate, some oak sneaks in there along with bourbon, but both are rather subtle and seem to just add to the complexity, the mentioned licorice even shows up in the taste. Slight vanilla and a touch of alcohol in the finish, but overall for this high of an alcohol content, the boozy taste is very well hidden. Definitely a top notch imperial stout.

I was lucky enough to try this twice in three days in mid-December, the first time a 2007 and the second time a 2009. I am scoring the 2009 but will also include a review of the 2007.

2009 bottle provided by Exiled.
Pours black with a brown head. The aroma is smokey oak with some roasted malt. The flavor is strong chocolate with some vanilla and licorice. Medium-thick mouthfeel. Tried this with Ghiradelli cocoa with a caramel center and it was amazing.

2007 bottle provided by Cavie.
Aroma was more coffee and chocolate than in the 2009 vintage. The roasted malt and slight smoke were absent. The flavor was more of a milk chocolate with some vanilla. Overall, I think the 2009 was a little bit better but the 2007 was still a great beer.

A number one top gun, in the name of justice, John Q. Public can trust us. Hail to thee dear old Paroon, hail to thee. 
 Hail to thee!
 Hail to thee!

2008 vintage.

Pitch black (and I really mean pitch black) with a very big, brown head that leaves plenty of lacings.

A very pleasant, fine-tuned and balanced smell. Lots of roasted malts, some licorice and notes of dark fruits and chocolate. As the beer warms up, the bourbon notes get a little more prominent.

The taste is really good and showcases a good balance between lots of different flavors. There¬ís lots of things going on here, but its still manages to come out as clean and easy on the palate. Plenty of sweet and roasted malts. Notes of wood and some charcoal. Some vanilla, molasses, burnt sugar and dark fruits. Even tough the beer is sweet, it¬ís not as sweet as I had expected and definitely not cloying. The bourbon makes a subtle appearance every now and then. The finish is great with a pleasant bitterness to it and some warming alcohol, but most importantly a rather powerful and lingering taste of licorice that seems to lie as a separate layer of its own, detached from the the rest of the flavors in the finish.

Big body with a slightly sticky, but still smooth, texture. Carbonation is good.

A very good imperial stout. Well balanced and actually quite easy to drink. The contributions from the licorice in this one are a work of art.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

220z 2009 Reserve 
Appearance: Opaque with a large dark tan head and lots of lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malt, oak, bourbon and sweet dark candy 
Taste: Bourbon, roasted malts, coffee, sweetness and bittering at the finish 
This is a big beer that changes character as it warms up. Very smooth and silky on the tongue and bitter with hops and alcohol in the finish. Very good.

700th rating for this beer!  2009 reserve bottle from Beverages 4 Less ($13.99) enjoyed on New Year¬ís Eve.  Pours pitch black with nary a highlight of brown shining through.  One finger of nice dark brown foam has good retention and leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is on the mellow side with the oak and bourbon being quite noticeable as well as roasted malt, licorice, and a bit of coffee.  Flavor strong with VERY dark chocolate as well as dark stone fruit (cherry) and coffee.  The bourbon and licorice flavors are very subtle.  The mouthful is smooth and velvety, but unfortunately there is some alcohol sting.  Really good, but I think it will be better when I open the bottle that I¬íve been aging.  This bottle seems to have been too fresh.  (205, 700)

Bottled 1 pint 6 fluid ounces. Opened before the "best after"-date. It would have been wiser to keep a bottle of the same vintage for another time. Anyway: Absolutely mindblowingly marvelous aroma with turkish coffee, baguette, oak, licorice, mint, sage and vanilla showing up. Great taste. Amazingly complex. Low carbonation. Subdued fantastic hop profile. Perfect balance. Moderate bitterness. Faint cress reminiscence in the finish. I enjoyed the journey. I prefered its aroma.

¬í09 Vintage.  Served in a pint glass (snifter broke in the dishwasher).  Opaque black pour below a tan/brown, long-lasting head with nice, sticky lacing.  Complex aroma made up of oak, vanilla, chocolate, roasted malty sweetness, slight pine.  Flavors - oak, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, nice bitterness on the finish to balance it out.  Full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish.  A remarkable beer by Deschutes... definitely worth the $10+ price tag.

I was told this beer is better after a few months.  As good as this beer was fresh, I can¬ít even imagine it getting any better.  
Deep dark and opaque, as black as the name implies.  Slight tan head.  Thich velvety mouthfeel.  An explosion of flavor, dark roast, lots of notes from the wood, deep chocolate, a little coffee, ripe sweet fruit with just a little hint of tartness which is well balanced by the bitterness of the hops and roast.  An amazing stout, best I¬íve ever had.  Too bad it¬ís so hard to find.
2007 bottle, thanks to Cavie, inky black with iodine swirl, aroma of dry cocoa, coffee, flavors of dark chocolate, burnt coffee, roasty finish as well

Wow, what a beer... Aroma is sweet like brown sugar or candied dates... Dark black with a reddish tan head... Flavor is black licorice initially, then comes dark chocolate... Finish is coffee grounds on the palate... Delicious beer.

Bottle courtesy of B√ºckDich. 2007 Reserve. Dark black pour with a foamy tan head. Lovely chocolate aroma. Gentle perfumy scent as well. Taste is deep rich chocolate with bitter coffee. Very nice finish. Lovely.

2009 Reserve.  Outstanding Imperial Stout, maybe the best I¬íve had.  Aroma is of alcoholic cherry chocolate, a holiday-time delight.  Hints of toffee.  Flavor follows suit in even more robust and actualized form.  Goes down like silk coating the throat.

22 oz bottle 2008 reserve.
The wax top was cool but a real pain to open.
Deep black, no light penetrates at all. 
Head is thin, but lasting, leaving spotty lace in it¬ís wake. A layer of alcohol floats on top like a nice port. 
Aroma is pure black strap molasses, vanilla, creamy chocolate, and a faint wisp of alcohol.
Flavor is definitlely molasses, vanilla, toast, with some milk chocolate and toasty wood. Finsh is long and has a hint of anise. 
Creamy smooth mouthfeel, and no alcohol burn.
Exceptional.

22 oz wax dipped bottle of the 2007 reserve. Pours a thick pitch black with a tan cappuccino like head that leaves some sticky lacing. Aroma of dark chocolate, molasses, wood, vanilla and alcohol. The flavor is bittersweet chocolate with lots of roasted malt and hop bitterness, very light alcohol taste. Very full body with average Imp Stout carbonation and a frothy thick mouth feel. This is a very rich desert sipping beer, drinking it at cellar temperature really brings out all the flavors. My only complaint is that it¬ís a bit sweet.

Brought this to the ORF tasting.  My bottle was an ¬í07 and someone else there had an ¬í08.  Wow this was absolutely delicious.  I wish I could make two different ratings here though.  The ¬í07 was significantly better than the ¬í08.  You could definitely tell the benefit of aging this beer.  The ¬í07 was black with dark caramel head and a pungent bourbon aroma.  There were tastes of bourbon, caramel, molasses, toffee, and a few dark currants or other dark fruit.  Smooth, complex, and delicious.  Loved it.  Thanks Brad for such a great beer!

*The ¬í08 had a high hop or carbonation content that made it not as smooth.  I would highly recommend aging this beer for 2 years.

2008 bottle thanks to bockeyhorsey.  wow is this stuff good!!  poured pitch black with a copper head and some lace.  aroma was baking chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, and oak.  flavor was bourbon, baking chocolate, licorice, and oak.  medium-full body with low carbonation.  man was this good.  thanks bill for the hook up.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2011 2011-09-02, reserve 2007, 4 years old, 8-5-8-4-17=42The aroma blends well cookies and caffelatte; roasted malt; lightly breadish too. The body structure seems to be less interesting than 2 years ago, but still with an excellent chocolate flavor, roasted malt, strong bitterness and a hint of liquorice and vanilla. Excellent.2009-10-24, reserve 2007, 2 years old, 8-5-9-4-18=44Black night color; big creamy head, beige, leaving a nice lace while reducing. Perfect aroma of milky coffee, coffee truffles, barley coffee (a substitute for real coffee), vanilla icecream. Silky and seducing body; strong roasted malt flavor, chocolate and quite evident liquorice, light vanilla; salty, thick; the final is powerful, bitter, with strong roasted malt presence and even saltier; light acidity from the roasted malt; there is a comfortable alcohol warmth. Mighty. It deserves the appreciation.
Pours black with a brown head.  Smells of cocolate and coffee. Tastes of black licorice, oakiness and smoke, also hints of hazelnuts.  A bitter finish.

2009 22 oz bottle.  Poured pitch black with a deep tan head, smelled of lots of anise and smoke. Tastes of thick anise up front that goes into a dark smoked taste at the end. Not my favorite parts of a RIS, but an excellent brew with really complex tastes. When warmed up, however, the molasses comes through and perfectly balances the smoke, and is perfect!

09 bottle, not as good as the 08 fresh. some age will do this one good, it¬ís a bit hot which detracts from the palate and finish. a bit hot on the nose as well, masking some of the nice nougaty, earthy yeast notes. a year or two on the 09 will def put it up a few notches.
Pours pitch black with a dark brown head. Great stouty flavor with licorice and oak highlights. Perfect texture as well, rich but not overly sweet. Totally worth it

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 Re-Rate 2010 Reserve: Pours black with a rich tan head. Aroma of maple, black licorice, chocolate and malt.. Flavor is rich dark roasted malt, black licorice, chocolate, malty, maple, sweet, bourbon and aged oak. Mouth feel is very heavy body with low carbonation. Overall, a DAMNED GOOD BREW!

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a deep, dark brown/black with copper head. Aroma of very nice dark roasted grain, nice bitterness, little astringent, some black licorice. Flavor is malty, dark roasted grain, baking chocolate, dark roasted grain bitterness, some oak, alcohol spiciness. Mouth feel is heavy body, silky smooth, low-medium carbonation. Overall, very nice beer, very warming and tasty. I enjoyed very much!

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2010 Poured black with a moderate brown head.  The aroma is sweet and chocolately, with some nuttiness, wood, toffee, and coffee.  Flavor is up front molasses and toasty, smokey chocolate malt flavors with the licorice appearing on the midpalate.  Some fruity, dried cherry flavors also come forward.  The finish is complexly bitter as a touch of hops and the oak come through, as well as a bit of alcohol warmth..  For an 11%, the alcohol is quite concealed, and pleasant bitter bite at the end kept me from tiring of the sweetness.   Mouthfeel is smooth, rich, and mouthcoating.  This stuff really lived up to the hype for me.

This is a fantastic brew. The pour is dark brown and opaque, the head is dark brown. The beer itself is fragrant, smelling strongly of roasted malts whos conversion was stopped just short of burnt, chocolate, and molasses. The mouthfeel is thick and tasty, somewhat bitter for some palates, but enjoyable for those who love a slight surplus of IBUs. Both the aroma and taste of The Abyss hold shades of the bourbon barrels this beer was aged in. The finish is dry and pleasant. The 11% ABV goes almost unnoticed against the complex flavors of this beer.

Bottle from 08. Pours black with a nice tan head. Has a smell of licorice and toasted malt. Has a chocolate, woody taste to it. Could use a little time in the bottle and would like to try an older one

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 07,08,09,10 Bottle.  
Black as oil pour and Dark tan head.  Chocolate in the nose, some cream, anise, vanilla and chocolate.  A bit of bitter coffee as well.  Flavor is burnt Dark sugars and ashy coffee, chocolate.  Boozey robust.  Ash is the predominate flavor.  Mouthhfeel is creamy and drinkable.  The Char and ashiness on this one is awesome.  A Big sipper.  
The older vintage smooth out very nicely.  I recently had an 08 I had been saving that was phenomenal, prompting me to raise this score by .1

Bottle from whole foods. Pours like carbonated motor oil with a fluffy coffee colored head. Smells like malts, chocolate, toffee, coffee, graham crackers, and licorice. Tastes like roasted malts, semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, faint licorice, and flowers. Mouth is dry but not too dry, still leaves me thirsty, the alcohol is warming and contagious, I want more...now I¬ím thirsty again...damn, this is a never-ending circle isn¬ít it? Good thing I have my powerade here.

2009 bottle shared by MrPickles - Drank this one side-by-side next to 09 Darkness. Pours beautifully, with a tan head above pure blackness. Yep, it¬ís an impy.
